abstract: The Nomination of
snippet: The Nomination of
lead_paragraph: The Democratic nomination is made. He who did more than any other Northern man to save the rebellion from its enemies in its growth, is fitly put forward to shield it from the finishing blow in its decline. The platform which demands that "immediate efforts be made for a cessation of hostilities," finds its appropriate embodiment in the General, who, of all others, did most to thwart the progress of those hostilities. It being deemed politic, by the majority, to select a military man as the candidate, in order to abate, with the people, the odious associations of a peace policy, the least warlike of the Generals was the very "jack-at-a-pinch" to serve this end. Though the straight-out peace men did not take kindly at first to any such management, they were easily enough reconciled to it by the plea, that, without some such shift, success was impossible; and by the concession of the second place on the ticket to one of their own number, VALLANDIGHAM appropriately, and without hesitation, moved to make the nomination unanimous.

abstract: New-York--Love, Nancy, Poisoned by Husband and his Paramour
snippet: New-York--Love, Nancy, Poisoned by Husband and his Paramour
lead_paragraph: A horrible case of wife murder was, at a late hour on Tuesday night, brought to the notice of Coroner RANNEY, through the police of the Twenty-second Precinct. In times of less excitement we would give the details of this cruel and unnatural homicide; as it is, we barely give the facts. The case is as follows: The police of the Twenty-second Precinct were informed by some persons who are neighbors of the interested parties, that Mrs. NANCY LOVE, wife of JOHN LOVE, residing in Fifty-first-street, near Ninth-avenue, was lying at the point of death, and that her condition had been brought about by the administering of poison, which by degrees had reduced her to a mere skeleton, and that during her illness she was allowed no food or drink, and was denied a physician by her unnatural husband and a woman named, ANN O'NEIL, with whom the victim and her husband boarded. Coroner RANNEY, upon learning this state of the case, repaired at once to the place. He found Mrs. LOVE in a very low condition, almost pulseless, and it was with great difficulty that he was able to obtain, from her the following testimony:

abstract: A dispatch from the Army of the Potomac says that the reports of the losses in the Fifth Corps, in the battles of the 18th, 19th and 21st inst., reach 5,000, greatly exaggerates the facts.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from the Army of the Potomac says that the reports of the losses in the Fifth Corps, in the battles of the 18th, 19th and 21st inst., reach 5,000, greatly exaggerates the facts. It is now definitely known that they do not exceed 3,800; and as the stragglers and others continue to come in, and the sick are all accounted for, it is believed that the aggregate loss will not exceed 3,500. The loss of the Second Corps in Thursday's fight will not exceed 1,500, according to the official statement, and it is believed that when all within our lines report, the entire loss will fall to 1,200. The rebels are said to be using the Weldon Railroad below Ream's Station, and running their supplies thence to Petersburgh around our left by wagon. As this requires a large force to guard the trains and defend the road against our cavalry, it cannot be either a very profitable or pleasant means of communication. Arrangements have been made for burying the rebel dead left on the field of last Thursday's battle. The fact that the enemy did not do this, and also that they did not carry off their wounded, is palpable evidence that although they drove back the Second Corps they did not achieve a complete or creditable victory.

abstract: The Democrats of this City held a mass meeting in the City Hall Park last evening to ratify the nomination of GEORGE B. McCLELLAN by the Chicago Convention.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats of this City held a mass meeting in the City Hall Park last evening to ratify the nomination of GEORGE B. McCLELLAN by the Chicago Convention. Tammany Hall was illuminated, several hundred guns were fired, a brilliant pyrotechnic display provided, and unusual inducements offered to persuade the people to come out, but as far as numbers were concerned the gathering was not a success. Hon. JAS. BROOKS A. OAKEY HALL and Judge DALY were the leading speakers, followed by a host of lesser lights. But most of the speeches intentionally adapted to the tastes of the audience were characterized by the grossest abuse of the private and public life of the President, followed up with low and vulgar epithets heaped upon him, interspersed, at least in one instance, with obscene songs.

abstract: -- From the point where the East Broadway street cars take the outside track, extending from nearly opposite the Comptroller's Office down to Broadway, they actually monopolize a considerable portion of the sidewalk. Run, as they frequently are, at a rapid rate, foot passengers are compelled to clear the path in order to escape being knocked down. To ladies, with their outspreading dresses, the danger is constant. We have had personal experience of the perils of the situation, and can bear witness that these perils are increased by the recklessness of drivers employed on the line. The company should be at once indicted for creating and perpetuating a nuisance. They deserve indictment even were the track arrangements not perilous as they are. It is outrageous that these city companies, which are fast monopolizing every foot of road-way in the principal streets, should claim, in addition, a share of the side path. Let the authorities see to this matter at once, before some fatal accident occurs.

abstract: on McClellan's Nomination; Speech on McClellan's Nomination; on McClellan's Nomination; Speech on McClellan's Nomination; onMcClellan's Nomination; on McClellan's Nomination
snippet: on McClellan's Nomination; Speech on McClellan's Nomination; on McClellan's Nomination; Speech on McClellan's Nomination; onMcClellan's Nomination; on McClellan's Nomination
lead_paragraph: "The announcement of the nomination of GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN for the Presidency by the Chicago Convention, caused great jubilation among the Democracy of the City. Tammany Hall having her posters, flags and transparencies all prepared in advance, decorated with dubious portraits of her nominee, spread them to the breeze and saluted them with one hundred guns. The juvenile Democrats, who have their habitat in the Park, expressed their appreciation of the noise, the smoke and the candidate by spasmodic cheers for MCCLELLAN. The flags on the City Hall, Register's Office and other public buildings controlled by Democratic officials, were raised shortly after the news arrived, by what authority is unknown. Impromptu speeches were made at the stands in the Park, on the City Hall steps and in other convenient places, in which the draft was denounced and Gen. MCCLELLAN lauded. Seedy individuals were started on their travels through the City carrying placards calling upon the friends of GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN to meet in the City Hall Park at 5 o'clock, with the promised inducement that eminent speakers would air their eloquence upon the occasion. The tone of little knots and groups that discussed the nomination in the streets and at the bars in public houses was generally confident, and to the majority success seemed certain, but a few old politicians, congregated in the vicinity of Tam many, expressed themselves as unable to see "a sure thing" for "Little Mac," in spite of the apparent excitement and enthusiasm. Toward 5 o'clock the Park began to fill up again and the big guns were brought out to call the faithful, the unterrified, the unwashed, who like artillery when blank cartridges are used, to attend the ratification of the nomination. Three stands were erected in front of the City Hall. No. 1 on Park-row, No. 3 on Broadway, No. 2 in front of the City Hall steps. Gunpowder was wasted ad libilum, drums beat to arms, German bands discussed their most seductive strains: rockets, Roman candles, bombs and miscellaneous pyrotechnics illuminated the air. Old Tammany was dressed in flags and ornamented with transpariences, but the fact must be stated that in point of numbers the gathering was not up to the usual standard of a mass ratification meeting. But few eminent speakers were present, and the speeches, abstracts of which are given below, were strictly confined to abuse of Mr. LINCOLN and laudation of Gen. MCCLELLAN. The display and proceedings of the evening were closed by the exhibition of a beautiful piece of fireworks, embracing in many colored scrolls and flourishes, the motto

abstract: HOOKER came down from Niagara Falls yesterday morning and went eastward. He expects to spend a short time with his friends in Jefferson County. His presence at the depot was scarcely known until the train was about to leave, as he did not get out of the ear. Those who learned that he was on board, gathered around to catch a glimpse of the hero, and as the train started many passed forward to grasp his hand. The General appeared to be in fine health and spirits. -- Rochester Democrat, Aug 30.

abstract: SOLON W. RICE, aged 28 years, and residing at No. 811 Washington-street, was arrested by Officer MCGUIRE, of the second Precinct, charged with having been guilty of stealing letters from the Post-office, and appropriating the contents to his own use. The accused, who is a clerk in the post-office, was taken before a United States Commissioner and committed. Several letters which he had filched from the mails, were found on his person when he was searched as the station-house.

abstract: The three desperate assaults which the rebels have made in quick succession upon our position on the Weldon Railroad are not likely to be the last of their efforts to retake that fundamental line.
lead_paragraph: The three desperate assaults which the rebels have made in quick succession upon our position on the Weldon Railroad are not likely to be the last of their efforts to retake that fundamental line. The whole of the three assaults, each exceeding the other in ferocity, were made within a week; and the first of them occurred promptly after Gen. WARREN had seized the line. Each and all of them have failed in driving our army from the Weldon road; and the one lesson which Gen. LEE has learned from them all is, that the force he has at present at Petersburgh is utterly incompetent to the work he must achieve. He must have a larger force before he makes another effort.

abstract: Chicago Nomination and New-York Demonstration
snippet: Chicago Nomination and New-York Demonstration
lead_paragraph: It was a serious struggle with the few respectable and loyal Democratic orators who addressed the mixed gathering in front of the City Hall last evening, to know how to reconcile belief in the justice of a war for the maintenance of the Union, with the unconditional peace principles of the Chicago Platform. One great difficulty with these men doubtless was, that the new party makes recruiting, volunteering, or employing any agency whatever for filling up the national army, a grave political crime. The representatives of Tammany cannot occupy such a platform, and at the same time continue to recruit for the Union army. The Hancock Committee has been summarily guillotined at Chicago, and the announcement of the fact was made yesterday by hoisting the Hancock flag almost out of sight in front of the Wigwam, in order to make room for the peace legends of the reorganized Democracy.

abstract: By the arrival of the Europa at Halifax yesterday, we have news from Europe to the 21st ult. The English papers were discussing the Petersburgh disaster. The London Times credits both sides with great valor. The Confederate Loan declined two to three per cent. under the infinence of the latest news from GRANT. The Belfast riots subsided on the 18th, but were renewed on the following day with great violence. Disturbances also occurred at other places. The King of Spain continued the guest of NAPOLEON, and this circumstance led to predictions of a closer alliance between France and Spain. There is nothing new on the Danish question. The International Congress at Geneva was projecting better provisions for the wounded soldiers. Hon. CHARLES HALE had arrived in Egypt. A speedy settlement of the recent difficulties with American parties was expected.

abstract: The time is getting to be very tedious while awaiting our next grand attack. The wooden vessels are merely lying on their oars; the army is, however, very busy in their preparations for attack on Morgan. They completed their first battery on Sunday evening, and at 6:40 P.M., opened on the fort to obtain range,  c., I suppose.

abstract: Magazines for September
snippet: Magazines for September
lead_paragraph: -- Harpers' New Monthly Magazine, for September, comes, as usual, full freighted with instruction and entertainment. The opening article is another leaf from the varied experience of Capt. PARKER SNOW, who is already known to the readers of the magazine, by his adventure, in many lands, or rather many waters, as his experiences have been chiefly of a marine character. It details a perilous incident on the coast of Australia, and is illustrated with wood cuts whose fine execution should not be overlooked. The like excellence is visible in the embellishments to Mr. C.F. BALL's account of "At Home with the Esquimaux," a paper full of interesting facts that may be regarded as a foretaste of the volume, relating his Arctic Explorations, at length, now in press by Messrs. HARPERS. "President MONROE and his Administration," is a vindication of what the author regards as "the golden age of our political history." It is pitched in rather a high oratorical key, as when we are told that the utterance of the Monroe Doctrine "fairly stunned by its boldness the Holy Alliance, and took it down from the height of its arrogance," &c. It is this sort of writing that gives rise to so much loose thinking and inconsequential reasoning among us. "Libraries" is a fruitful subject insufficiently treated. The writer should know that the books of the Beaufort Public Library, (S.C.,) were not sold by auction in New-York. A healthy spontaneous public sentiment was so strongly opposed to the whole proceeding, that the sale was stopped and never took place. "Presentation Week at Yale" reads flatly, like all accounts of college festivities, to those who have rejuvenescent interest in them. "The Cafe Greco" is an Italian sketch after the manner of Mr. STORY's "Roba di Roma." "Our Mutual Friend," by DICKENS, reaches its fourth number, and can scarcely be called up to the average. Far too much space is taken up with heavy satire on respectability, a subject whose inherent dullness seems to overcome even DICKENS when he writes about it. Where DICKENS' true strength lies, and where his weakness, is well exemplified in the powerful sketch of the slouching ruffian who is informing against his quandam partner, and whose every word goes to complete his picture, compared with the tedious and affected nonsense put into the mouths of the two lawyers in the vain hope of catching the prevalent tones of light social persiflage. We see nothing in this number of honest Mr. Boffin, who is worth a dozen of the heavy respectabilities that DICKENS seems to feel bound to make a crusade against. The usual quantity of novellettes, poetry, jokes, &c., go to make up a readable number.

abstract: THE COSMOPOLITAN CLUB. -- This club, composed of some or the leading citizens of this City. Boston and Providence, on Thursday last inaugurated their organization with a grand chowder-feast and clambake, produced in the real old-fashioned Rhode Island style, at Providence. The steamer Plymouth Rock, of the Stonington line, and a special train from Groton, were placed at the disposal of the club by Mr. SIMONS, agent of the line. The affair went off finely; speeches were made by the President and Vice-President; songs and a general and genial flow of champague, wit and sentiment followed. The Cosmopolitan will probably be one of the most select, as it is one of the wealthiest clubs in the City. Its Club House will probably be located in Fifth-avenue, as a committee is already making selections of a site.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamers Yazoo and McClellan, at this port yesterday, bringing NewOrleans and Mobile news to the 24th ult., we have the official report of the capture of Fort Morgan. It appears that Admiral FARRAGUT and Gen. GRANGER so arranged their vessels and batteries as to invest the fort on three sides, and to envelope it with such a terrible raking fire that the guns of the fort could not be worked.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamers Yazoo and McClellan, at this port yesterday, bringing NewOrleans and Mobile news to the 24th ult., we have the official report of the capture of Fort Morgan. It appears that Admiral FARRAGUT and Gen. GRANGER so arranged their vessels and batteries as to invest the fort on three sides, and to envelope it with such a terrible raking fire that the guns of the fort could not be worked. The rebels stood the fire for ten or twelve hours, and then surrendered unconditionally. The prisoners numbered six hundred, including Brig.-Gen. PAIGE and two Colonels. Sixty guns were taken in the fort, and also much material, though the rebels had destroyed considerable, and had spiked the guns. Our loss was but one man killed and seven wounded. The enthusiasm of the sailors at this new success of FARRAGUT is said to be indecribable.

abstract: During the past few days Gen. SHERIDAN's policy seemed to be on the offensive, for no less than four heavy reconnoissances were sent out; two on the left, with one on the right, by the infantry, assisted by a small force of cavalry, and one toward Shepherdstown by the cavalry alone. These repeated forays on the enemy's lines at last were rewarded by the fact having been satisfactorily ascertained that EARLY had at last taken up his line of retreat. But in what precise direction it was at [???]st impossible to say.

abstract: Rally of, and the Union Party
snippet: Rally of, and the Union Party
lead_paragraph: We are to have a rousing canvass. The Opposition have settled their discords, and are plunging with a shout into the work of electing MCCLELLAN. Already they are all aglow. They are earnest and vehement to-day; to-morrow they will be fiery and furious. They have the genuine spirit which shrinks from no daring or doing, and which gathers force as it presses on. They are, moreover, consummately led. The same art which gave them unity is giving them aim and direction.

abstract: By an arrival yesterday from New-Orleans we have interesting intelligence from Mexico. JUAREZ had left the country, and, it was rumored, had sought refuge in the United States. His family has already arrived at New-Orleans. The French and reactionary Mexican forces are said to have advanced from San Luis Potosi, and now occupy Saltillo, sixty-three miles from Monterey, the provisional seat of the Government of JUAREZ. MAXIMILIAN is pursuing a conciliatory course, and, it is said, has again urged SANTA ANNA to return to Mexico. He has forbidden the newspapers to abuse the Mexicans who still hold out against him.

abstract: The Chicago platform means aid and comfort to the rebels -- disgrace and dishonor to every Union soldier, to every loyal man; and its success will bring about one of three things, viz.: 1st. An armistice, which will give the now almost exhausted rebellion a new lease of life; or, 2d, a peace, which shall acknowledge the Southern Confederacy; or, 3d, a cowardly truckling to the rebellion, which shall trail our old flag in the dust at the feet of traitors, and welcome, cap in hand, the chief rebels to the highest seats in our political synagogue. Either of these three results is too terrible to think upon; each of them, in the guise of peace, is only the prelude to a fiercer state of civil war.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago platform means aid and comfort to the rebels -- disgrace and dishonor to every Union soldier, to every loyal man; and its success will bring about one of three things, viz.: 1st. abstract: Semmes, Capt; The Cruise of the Alabama; Alabama; Semmes' Book; the Cruise of the
snippet: Semmes, Capt; The Cruise of the Alabama; Alabama; Semmes' Book; the Cruise of the
lead_paragraph: When the rebellion broke out, RAPHAEL SEMMES was a Commander in the Navy of the United States, on shore duty as member of the Lighthouse Board. He was a native of Maryland, residing at Washington, fifty years old, and had served with fair credit in the navy for thirty-five years. He now wrote to the Confederate leaders, offering his services to fight against the country in whose service he still was. On the 14th of February, 1861, he received at Washington a telegram, requesting him to come to Montgomery, and confer with the Confederate Naval Committee. He telegraphed back that he would come immediately. After he had done this, and virtually enlisted with the Confederates, he resigned his position in the navy of the Union. From Montgomery he was sent back to the North to buy arms and powder, contract for machinery, and get a certain powder manufacturer to set up a powder mill in the Confederacy, and try to procure a cap machine from an "artificer named WRIGHT, at the arsenal in Washington." Moreover, there were, "at or near New-York," a couple of "steamers of speed, light draft, and strength sufficient for at least one heavy gun," which could be bought.

abstract: Wood Workers Meeting on Municipal Reform
snippet: Wood Workers Meeting on Municipal Reform
lead_paragraph: Last evening Cooper Institute was again filled with the workingmen of New-York who came forward to express their dissatisfaction with the present management of our City Government, and to take action which would secure a reform. Early in the evening the men commenced to assemble, and by 8 o'clock the hall was well filled with the sunburned, strong-armed, hardy sons of toil, who, knowing their might and feeling their wrongs, were determined to right them. The speakers were men from their own ranks, and their strong.sensible and eloquent speeches were most enthusiastically received. Every mention of the Citizens' Association and its objects was loudly applauded. GRAFULLA's Seventh Regiment band discoursed some excellent music. The whole audience seemed to enter fully into the spirit of the meeting, and it was in every sense a decided success.

abstract: Pacific Reports; Departure of Juarez
snippet: Pacific Reports; Departure of Juarez
lead_paragraph: There is reason to believe that there is a basis of fact in the Mexican reports, received from New-Orleans by the Yazoo, which arrived here yesterday. By these reports we are assured that President JUAREZ has left Mexico for the United States; that his family have arrived at New-Orleans; that the President himself is on board a vessel which is detained at quarantine below the city; that MAXIMILIAN is winning over the Juarist chiefs to his cause; that URAGA, on arriving at the capital, is to be treated by the Emperor as becomes his rank, and that official circulars have been issued to journalists and political pamphleteers, enjoining them to refrain from issuing articles calculated to irritate the Liberalist party.

abstract: The New-York Mail Steamship Company has added to its line the new steamship Suwo Nada. She is a remarkably fine vessel of 2,000 tons burden. Custom-house measurement, and has elegant accommodations for passengers. Upon her recent trial trip she made the extraordinary speed of seventeen and one half miles an hour. She was built for the China trade, but will hereafter run between this Port, Havana and New-Orleans in connection with the popular steamers Morning Star, Evening Star and Guiding Star, forming a weekly line. She sails on the 10th inst.

abstract: The Duty of the Hour; Lindsay, W S, on Peace Meetings North and West; Northern Traitors' Intrigues with Foreigners; Blockade and the Tallahassee
snippet: The Duty of the Hour; Lindsay, W S, on Peace Meetings North and West; Northern Traitors' Intrigues with Foreigners; Blockade and the Tallahassee
lead_paragraph: Our readers may remember that on the arrival of Lord LYONS in this country, on his return from England, in the Fall of 1862, he was waited upon at his hotel in this city, by Several "leading Democrats," and urged by them to use his influence to bring about the interference of England to put a stop to the war. This infamous and alarming fact was revealed in Lord LYONS' dispatches to his own Government, which were subsequently laid before Parliament. Who the "leading Democrats" were, never came out. Lord LYONS was, of course, bound in honor not to reveal their names, but it is almost impossible to err in conjecturing that some of them, at least, were prominent members of the Chicago Convention.

abstract: The Chicago Convention, to quote Mr. WICKLIFFE'S resolution, which was unanimously adopted by that body, "is not dissolved by the adjournment at the close of its business, but is to remain organized, subject to be called at any time and place that the Executive National Committee may desig  nate." In other words, a permanent, selfconstituted revolutionary body was thus created, to inaugurate civil war at the North in...
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Convention, to quote Mr. WICKLIFFE'S resolution, which was unanimously adopted by that body, "is not dissolved by the adjournment at the close of its business, but is to remain organized, subject to be called at any time and place that the Executive National Committee may desig nate." In other words, a permanent, selfconstituted revolutionary body was thus created, to inaugurate civil war at the North in case the action of the Government should not square with its wishes and plans. A casus belli was stated by the convention to be a repetition of military interference in the State elections of Kentucky, Maryland, Delaware and Missouri. The object of such interference, as is well known, was to prevent those in open arms against the Government from voting at the polls. So large a proportion of the people of Kentucky, for example was traitorous, that the Union population was literally at the mercy of the former, and could oppose no effectual resistance to wholesale robbery and murder, much less defend themselves from invasion from without. Government simply interposed to prevent cut-throats and rebels from outside its borders from seizing the political power of the State. No man, loyal or disloyal, in fact, that was willing to take the oath of allegiance, was prevented from voting. Such interference, the convention resolved, was revolutionary, "and its repetition to be resisted with all the means and power under our control." Hence the necessity of making the convention a permanent body, to raise the standard of revolt, and organize the means of resistance to the action of the National Government. A political assemblage is thus to become the paramount authority of the land, and is to be the judge of the law, as well as of the occasion on which it will exercise its revolutionary power.

abstract: And Military Arrests
snippet: And Military Arrests
lead_paragraph: The history of Gen. McCLELLAN'S connection with military arrests in Maryland is given very fully in the speeches of Mr. HARRIS, of Maryland, and Gen. MORGAN, of Ohio, which we publish without abbreviation. It is a history which is best illustrated by comparing it with the oracular utterances which at a later period began to fall from the lips of the peace candidate of the Democracy, and which now form the standing supports of the Chicago platform. When MCCLELLAN, in September, 1861, issued his order to Gen. BANKS to have certain members of the Maryland Legislature arrested and placed secretly on board a steamer at Annapolis, he was in the full flush and glory of his newly won promotion. He evidently felt that his way to permanent distinction lay in the exercise of his military commission to the full bent of the powers it carried with it, whether in issuing unadvised military orders, such as those hat first disgusted Gen. SCOTT with his subordinate,or in seizing suspected civilians with a military posse, under cover of night. The question how far he should go, was simply limited by the length of his official tether. This was made plain enough a month later, when (on the 29th of October, 1861) he directed his subordinate in command in Maryland to post a military force at certain polling places in the State to look after the purity of the ballot-box. There was then no imaginable limit to his theory of military supremacy. It was only when his judgment, his capacity, and his energy had come to be called in question by the great body of the loyal people and by the Executive, that he laid aside the role of the satrap and commenced his career as a political philosopher. It was only when the country generally began to' doubt whether the Young Napoleon was really so remarkable a General, and after a succession of military blunders, delays and losses had reduced him from the position of a warlike hero to that of a very ordinary sort of soldier, that he began those remarkable series of maxims, platitudes and paradoxes on State rights and rebel amenities which now form the legends of his oracles.

abstract: Chicago Platform and Ultimate Convention
snippet: Chicago Platform and Ultimate Convention
lead_paragraph: The Chicago platform proposes an "immediate cessation of hostilities," and an "ultimate convention" of the States, to change the Constitution, so as to smooth the way for the return of the rebels to its protecting folds. Such convention can be called only by two-thirds of both bodies of Congress, or on application to that body of two-thirds of the States, disloyal as well as loyal. The amendments, to become a part of the Constitution, must be ratified by three-fourths of the States. Should the proposed course be adopted, two years would probably be consumed in calling the convention, in its deliberations, and in the acceptance of its recommendations. In the meantime the rebels would be enabled to realize at least $1,000,000,000 from the sale of cotton, and with its proceeds, to place themselves in an impregnable position of defence. Would not all the time gained be so used?

abstract: The country will this morning hail with rejoicing, the glad news of the final fall of Atlanta, which is conveyed us in a very brief but official bulletin from the War Department. A telegram from Gen. SLOCUM, of the Twentieth Army Corps, is dated in Atlanta. Another dispatch announces that a great battle was fought on the Macon Railroad, that HOOD's army was cut in two, with heavy loss, and the rebel Gen. HARDEE killed. Gen. SHERMAN's advance entered the city yesterday morning, and it was expected that his whole army would enter during the day.

abstract: History of Juarez; Juarez; History of
snippet: History of Juarez; Juarez; History of
lead_paragraph: If it be true that the Republican President of Mexico has arrived at New-Orleans, and is about to make a visit to the United States, we feel confident that he will receive a welcome from our people such as has been accorded to but few of the champions of liberty. JUAREZ was the regular, legitimate and constitutional President of the Mexican Republic, and for two years he has struggled bravely against the large invading army sent by the French usurper to overthrow the Liberal Government. Finally he was compelled to succumb before superior force; and domestic intrigue, dissension and treason have at last completed the overthrow of his Government. But he has borne himself throughout the great trials that have befallen himself and his country with a calm self-possessedness, with a sublime courage, and with a faithful endurance that have extorted the admiration of the world. No offers or bribes of the usurper could corrupt him -- no measures of power could make him yield -- no defection on the part of his friends could shake his faith in liberty. His career, both in adversity and prosperity, has been full o honor to himself; and history will bear witness that even his fall was of such a character, and was borne in such a manner, as became greatness.

abstract: By the arrival, at Halifax, of the Hecla, from Liverpool, and of the Caledonia, from Glasgow, at Cape Race, we have five days' later intelligence from Europe. The Commissioners of Custom in London have issued instructions against allowing national or rebel vessels from entering British ports to be dismantled or sold. The frigate Niagara was in the Tagus, watching the movements of the steamer Georgia. Order had been restored in Belfast, where there had been no rioting since the 19th ult. The King of Spain had left France for Madrid. A prospective marriage is announced between Prince HUMBERT, of Italy, and the Princess ANNA MURAT -- a union which, it is expected, will strengthen the bonds between France and Italy. The Russian army is to be reduced. The Austrians and Prussians have decided to occupy the Duchy of Holstein.

abstract: Farragut's and Granger's Exploit
snippet: Farragut's and Granger's Exploit
lead_paragraph: It must surely astonish our brave and gallant men of the United Service in front of Mobile, who compelled the unconditional surrender of Fort Morgan, after twenty-four hours' bombardment, on the morning of Tuesday, the 23d of August, to find that they have become proper objects for the pity and "sympathy" of the party which has just nominated Gen. McCLELLAN for President of the United States. As FARRAGUT's and GRANGER's men sum up that splendid three weeks' achievement in the Bay of Mobile, the destruction of all the available rebel fleet, the evacuation of Fort Powell, the surrender of Fort Gaines, the capture of Fort Morgan, and the submission of several garrisons of rebel troops with all their equipments, munitions and provisions, it will sadly puzzle our gallant boys, and still more -- if possible -- their noble leaders, to find out why in the name of all that is chivalrous, gallant, loyal, and brave, they are to be treated to the commiseration of a composite crowd of hungry office-seekers and rebel sympathizers assembled in the city of Chicago.

abstract: Organize

lead_paragraph: A political campaign is before us of more terrible moment than any military campaign. One of the latter might fail and be retrieved by another. But if this political campaign fails, it is irretrievable. There will be no subsequent opportunity to undo its effects. It would settle the war decisively, fatally, forever.

abstract: Gen. JOHN MCNEIL, says the Louisville Democrat, reached Rolla, to take command of the District of Southwest Missouri, Saturday evening, and was honored with a popular and most enthusiastic reception. At his hotel a large crowd instantly gathered, with music and cheers, and won the General to attempt a speech. His remarks elicited the most animated applause, as indicating his determination to deal with rebels and rebel sympathizers on radical principles. At night the town was illuminated, with many lights in the dwellings (of the Radicals,) and bonfires on the streets While the earnest loyalists were thus testifying their joy, a clique of "Conservative chaps" were in obsequious and assiduous attendance upon the General, probably, hoping to take charge of him. They will find themselves signally disappointed.

abstract: The rebel steamer Lilian, captured on the 24th ult., off Cape Fear, arrived off the navy yard yesterday afternoon. The Lilian had sailed from Wilmington, N.C., with a load of cutton, 640 bales, and was bound for Bermuda. She was seen by the lookout on the United States steamer Gettysburgh, and she was run under the guns of the United States steamer Keystone State before she was seen from that vessel. The transport steamer Massachusetts aided in the capture of the Lilian. The prize is a splendid iron side-wheel steamer, built in April last. She is about 200 feet long, lies low in the water, and looks like a fast sailer, as she is represented to be. During the chase a small portion of her cargo was thrown overboard, but it was picked up by the capturing vessels. The Lilian was built in England on rebel account, specially for blockade running. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 1.
lead_paragraph: The rebel steamer Lilian, captured on the 24th ult., off Cape Fear, arrived off the navy yard yesterday afternoon. The Lilian had sailed from Wilmington, N.C., with a load of cutton, 640 bales, and was bound for Bermuda. She was seen by the lookout on the United States steamer Gettysburgh, and she was run under the guns of the United States steamer Keystone State before she was seen from that vessel. The transport steamer Massachusetts aided in the capture of the Lilian. The prize is a splendid iron side-wheel steamer, built in April last. She is about 200 feet long, lies low in the water, and looks like a fast sailer, as she is represented to be. During the chase a small portion of her cargo was thrown overboard, but it was picked up by the capturing vessels. The Lilian was built in England on rebel account, specially for blockade running. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Sept. 1.

abstract: Lavallee's Book on Frontiers of
snippet: Lavallee's Book on Frontiers of
lead_paragraph: The discussion of the "rectification" question has been revived in France. Her southern frontier has been "rectified" by the acquisition of Nice and Savoy; why should not her northern frontier be in like manner "rectified" by the annexation of Belgium and the extension of her dominion to the Rhine? The frontiers of ancient Gaul were the Pyrenees, the Alps and the Rhine; why should they not be also the frontiers of modern France? The little kingdom of LEOPOLD, the trans-Rhenish provinces of Prussia, would have to be absorbed by the great Western Power in order to effect this; but Frenchmen would need to have no scruples about their appropriation, since one of the ablest of French Professors has recently published a work, with the title which we have prefixed to this article, to demonstrate to his countrymen the propriety and expediency of seizing territory, the possession of which is indispensable to the integrity and security of the Second Empire. The book of M. LAVALLEE is a curious and instructive volume. In it the learned author traces the history of "Les Frontieres de la France" from the time of the Gauls to the settlement made by the Congress of Vienna in 1815, and winds up by declaring that, as France has recovered her natural frontier on the side of Switzerland and Italy, she ought to, and will, recover it on the side of Germany and the Rhine.
headline: {'main': 'The "Frontiers" of France.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The "Frontiers" of France.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Last evening, the Printers, Bookbinders, Engravers, Lithographers, and the Book Trade, held a grand mass meeting at Cooper Institute, to add their voice of approval, and indorse the principles and objects of the Citizens' Association. The hall was well filled. GRAFULLAS' Seventh Regiment Band rendered in excellent style some of their favorite pieces. The TREMAINE Brothers sang some of their choicest songs and ballads so sweetly and artistically, as to bring forth the hearty plaudits of the entire audience, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed.

abstract: -- About five weeks ago a reward of $1,000 was offered for the apprehension of a party from Philadelphia, who was accused of having committed forgeries to the amount of $79,000. The matter and the reward naturally attracted the attention of the police force throughout the Province and some of the most able members of that body were placed on the alert. Owing to some peculiar process best known to Constable FORD, that officer arrested the forger this day week on board of one of the Montreal line of steamers. The wife of the accused, who resides in Brantford on hearing of her husband's arrest, proceeded to Philadelphia, and so managed matters there with the sufferers and Provost-Marshal that there was not sufficient evidence to warrant the committal of the party for trial. Constable FORD deserves much credit for the shrewdness of manner adopted by him to arrest the party, and it is too bad that not even the reward will remunerate him for his labors. No good would result from the publication of the name of the party charged with the crime, hence it is repressed. -- Hamilton (Canada) Times.

abstract: The regular annual meeting of the Bogert-Club took place last evening, at No. 167 Bleecker-street, the President, Mr. E.R. WUNDER, in the chair.
lead_paragraph: The regular annual meeting of the Bogert-Club took place last evening, at No. 167 Bleecker-street, the President, Mr. E.R. WUNDER, in the chair. There were a large number of members present, and the proceedings throughout were of an interesting character. After the transaction of some business concerning the affairs of the club, the President delivered an address in which he said it afforded him great pleasure to meet so many of the members at their yearly gathering. He gave a brief history of the club, and stated that since its organization it had never been more prosperous. He concluded by referring pleasantly to the numerous fishing adventures of different members of the society.

abstract: Since the recall of the English leader, GORDON, no important success has been achieved by the Imperialists. They are still besieging the Taeping cities of Woo-chow and Nankin, but are making little progress toward the reduction of either.
lead_paragraph: Since the recall of the English leader, GORDON, no important success has been achieved by the Imperialists. They are still besieging the Taeping cities of Woo-chow and Nankin, but are making little progress toward the reduction of either. The former, in fact, can hardly be said to be besieged at all, for the rebels have a strong force encamped without the walls, which has hitherto so kept the Imperialists in check, that they have not been able to approach within twenty miles of the city, though supported by the Franco-Chinese Legion. Nor are affairs in Nankin in a much better condition. That capital is invested, but its defences are yet unassailed, either because their strength deters the besiegers from the enterprise or because TRENG-KWOFAN, their Commander, is in no hurry to reduce the place, lest such a feat should lead to the disbanding of his army, and the diminution of his own power and influence. Already the withdrawal of the English leader from the Imperialist service is beginning to produce its effects. The Imperialists are becoming dispirited and timid, while the Taeping rebels are growing so elated at the disappearance of their most formidable foe, that it is commonly apprehended they will presently resume the offensive, and attempt to recover the places they have lost. Even Shanghai is not considered safe in its existing condition, and the officer in command of the British forces at Hong-Kong has recently repaired thither to make arrangements for its protection in the event of another rebel irruption.

abstract: -- ABSALOM BRIGGS, one of a gang of "scalpers," and the father of the notorious GEORGE BRIGGS, was arrested in the city to-day on a charge of violating the Foreign Enlistment Act. BRIGGS, it appears, had made overtures to a seafaring man named ROSE, living on Wolfe Island, advising him to join the American Army, and promising him $1,000 bounty. ROSE gave his consent, and BRIGGS drove him in a wagon to the foot of the island, where a boat was in w iting to convey the two to Cape Vincent, the headquarters of the BRIGGS firm. As things narrowed down to this verge, with but the distance of the American channel to separate him from the scalpe[???]'s clutches. ROSE took second thought and declined, returning to his home. He subsequently gave information to the Kingston police, and our authorities determined to furnish the constable on Wolfe Island with a warrant and assist him in making the arrest whenever BRIGGS should again make his appearance in that portion of British territory. It was ascertained to-day, however, that ABSALOM BRIGGS was in the city, and the police promptly secured him, and he now lies contined in prison, awaiting his examination before the Police Magistrate on Monday morning. -- Kingston (Canada) News, Aug. 27

abstract: The War in; False Issues Raised By
snippet: The War in; False Issues Raised By
lead_paragraph: The McClellan organs here resent the imputation of having raised the Hancock recruiting banner of Tammany Hall out of sight to make room for the peace legends of the party. They admit having deposed the gallant HANCOCK and supplied his place on the forefront of the old wigwam with a device which may be one of war or one of peace, but which really looks to the uninitiated like the outline of an enraptured chipmunk. Under this, moreover, (they desire us to admit,) they have placed the Jacksonian motto declaratory of the perpetuity of the Union. Well, supposing we admit the motto in question. It is there in mixed red and black letters, very illegible and evidently very much out of place. But having admitted this, we must also claim the attention of the soi disant war organs of the Democracy to the fact that peace legends do superabound in all the popular assemblies, and in all the places of resort, of the new Democratic party. Thus the Daily News of Saturday, which represents the personal, and political interests of Mr. PENDLETON, and which claims for itself and its friends the credit of having framed the Chicago platform, tells us that

abstract: The Nashville Union, of Sept. 1, says WHEELER'S main force, it is now ascertained, was in Sparta, up to Monday evening: All demonstrations in this direction were made by small bodies of men, evidently with the intention of deceiving the authorities. The rebel commander, however, completely failed of his object.
lead_paragraph: The Nashville Union, of Sept. 1, says WHEELER'S main force, it is now ascertained, was in Sparta, up to Monday evening: All demonstrations in this direction were made by small bodies of men, evidently with the intention of deceiving the authorities. The rebel commander, however, completely failed of his object. Gen. ROUSSEAU as well aware that he would move in the direction of the Chattanooga Railroad, and that his design was to cut that road, and he also was aware that the points most likely to be threatened, were the bridges over Elk and Duck rivers, and he accordingly made the necessary preparations to meet him. Yesterday, it became evident that his surmises were correct, and accordingly a large force, not only enough to save the road, but also to meet WHEELER, and defeat him in the open field, was dispatched in that direction -- the General himself taking command in person. We shall probably hear of a fight soon, as Gen. ROUSSEAU is not the man to be idle on such an occasion.

abstract: Nomination and City Hall Flags
snippet: Nomination and City Hall Flags
lead_paragraph: When the news of the Chicago nomination of McCLELLAN reached this City, our Copperhead municipal authorities had the City Hall profusely decorated all over with flags, great and small, which were still there on Friday night. But when the news of the great and glorious victory of the Union arms at Atlanta reached the City yesterday, they were all hauled down, and did not appear during the entire day. The building looked dismal and desolate, like some old barn, while all the buildings around and all the splendid buildings up Broadway, from end to end, were gaily ornamented with the glorious banner of our country -- the banner under which SHERMAN, GRANT and FARRAGUT are marching on to victory.

abstract: We are sorry to learn that Mr. JOHN T. MOODY, who has been connected with the Chicago and Milwaukee Railroad for several years, as Master of Transportation, has resigned his position and accepted a similar one on the Hudson River Railroad. During the many years that Mr. MOODY has attended to the interests of the Chicago and Milwaukee Railroad in this city, he has won the esteem and confidence of the public, while his genial and obliging manner of transacting business has gained the respect and friendship of all with whom he has been brought in contact. The company will scarcel[???] find a man who will discharge his duties so satisfactorily to the public as Mr. MOODY. -- Milwaukee Sentin[???]l.

abstract: Morality of, and Collie >amp; Co.
snippet: Morality of, and Collie >amp; Co.
lead_paragraph: We are assured, by no less an authority than the Richmond Examiner, that the Confederate Government has been engaged in the business of blockade-running. Encouraged by the success of the British in that traffic, the Administration of JEFF. DAVIS determined to embark in it themselves, and commissioned a rebel firm at Bermuda, with whom they agreed to share profits, to order seven new steamers to be built, equipped and manned in England, for the express purpose contemplated. The order was sent to ALEXANDER COLLIE & CO., an English house, prominent among shipbuilders and blockade-runners, who, in due season, executed the order and started the steamers for Bermuda, between which place and Wilmington they were destined to trade. All of them were peculiarly unfortunate, the whole seven being lost in the first or second voyage, though commanded by experienced Captains, who were invariably successful in evading the cruisers and running the blockade, but who, strange to say, almost as invariably contrived to run the vessels ashore, after escaping capture. These successive disasters, which involved the loss of the cargoes as well as the ships, were not, of course, very agreeable to the statesman-contrabandists at Richmond, and, before long, they began to doubt the integrity of the Captains, and to surmise that evil-intent had more to do with the matter than chance or adverse elements. At first it was affirmed that the Captains had been bribed by the Yankees to destroy vessels and cargoes. On second consideration, this idea was abandoned, for had the Yankees been at all concerned in the affair, they would have been more likely to bribe the Captains to let their vessels and cargoes fall into the hands of the blockaders. The Yankees were, therefore, acquitted of the charge, and Confederate suspicion fastened on other parties. All the accused Captains had, it seems, been appointed by Messrs. COLLIE & Co., who, as has been already mentioned, were themselves notorious blockade-runners, and as fortunate as notorious, not one of their ships [???]ing been captured or lost, though several [???] them had made from three to nine voyages each, Here was ground for suspicion certainly, and the treatment which the delinquents invariably received from COLLIE & CO., after every disaster, tended to give confirmation to it; since what would have disqualified them for any office of trust in the estimation of other men, immediately led to their promotion to new commands in the blockade-running fleet of said parties. The fact is, that the agents of the Confederate Government had made a bad choice of a person to see about the building and equipment of the rebel steamers, it being rather too much to expect that COLLIE & CO. would furnish JEFF. DAVIS and his colleagues with the means of driving himself out of the most lucrative trade he has ever been engaged in. The rebel theory is that COLLIE appointed those Captains expressly on condition that they should wreck their respective vessels and destroy their respective cargoes, after running the blockade, and that the new commands which they subsequently got in his own ships were the reward of their perfidy. Were such a charge made against any man of average respectability, it would, doubtless, be at once pronounced far-fetched and false, but who would look for honesty or morality in a blockade-runner? And, therefore, what might be regarded as utterly unfounded, if asserted of the one, may be admitted to be by no means improbable, when predicated of the other.
headline: {'main': 'The Morality of Blockade-Runners.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Morality of Blockade-Runners.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

snippet: New-York--Attempted, of Policeman Arnoux
lead_paragraph: On the morning of the 29th ult., about 2:30 o'clock, a most unprovoked and brutal outrage was perpetrated upon Policeman JOHN H. ARNOUX, of the Eighteenth Precinct, while he was patrolling his beat in First-avenue, near East Nineteenth-street. The principal facts of the case have hitherto, for reasons unknown to our reporter, been kept from the public, not from any neglect of the police, however. abstract: In the Matter of the Petition of Edward Ivers, for the Custody of Jane Ivers, an Infant. -- The petition for this court set forth that the petitioner, on behalf of Joseph Ivers, his father, applied for the custody of his sister, a child of nine years of age, who was retained by the respondents, Andrew Campbell and his wife, and it alleged that the said Andrew Campbell and his wife were the keepers of a house of assignation at No. 97 Crosby-street, in this City, where the child lived with them and was there exposed to improper and evil associations and companions. The respondents claimed that the child had been given them by its parents, that they had reared it and provided for it, and that they were not the keepers of such a house, but engaged in a reputable business. His Honor dismissed the suit, owing to some informality, but granted a new one returnable this morning, when the case will be heard on the merit.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of the Petition of Edward Ivers, for the Custody of Jane Ivers, an Infant. -- The petition for this court set forth that the petitioner, on behalf of Joseph Ivers, his father, applied for the custody of his sister, a child of nine years of age, who was retained by the respondents, Andrew Campbell and his wife, and it alleged that the said Andrew Campbell and his wife were the keepers of a house of assignation at No. 97 Crosby-street, in this City, where the child lived with them and was there exposed to improper and evil associations and companions. The respondents claimed that the child had been given them by its parents, that they had reared it and provided for it, and that they were not the keepers of such a house, but engaged in a reputable business. His Honor dismissed the suit, owing to some informality, but granted a new one returnable this morning, when the case will be heard on the merit.

abstract: Kendall, Amos and John Forsyth
snippet: Kendall, Amos and John Forsyth
lead_paragraph: As AMOS KENDALL was one of the builders of the Chicago platform, on which the "Democratic" candidate for President must stand pledged to make immediate efforts "for a cessation of hostilities, with a view to an ultimate convention of all the States," that "peace may be restored on the basis of the Federal Union of the States," it may not be unwholesome for Mr. KENDALL, his party and his country, to know how his Southern friends are likely to receive a proffered olive-branch on that basis. JOHN FORSYTH, once a personal and political friend of Mr. KENDALL, and fellow member of Mr. VAN BUREN's cabinet, (FORSYTH, Secretary of State, and KENDALL, Postmaster-General,) discourses to that gentleman in the columns of a late number of the Mobile Register of Advertiser in the following manner:

abstract: Action of Proprietors at Pittsburgh
snippet: Action of Proprietors at Pittsburgh
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Chronicle of Tuesday says: "A meeting of the Coal Exchange was held at 11 o'clock to-day, Mr. GEORGE LYSLE in the chair. The attendance was not very large, but more than usual interest in the proceedings was exhibited. The minutes of the last meeting were read and accepted, after which resolutions were adopted: first, that a committee of two be appointed to wait on the Mayors or the two cities, and request them to call a meeting of the citizens to get their indorsement of the measures now being taken to resist the extortionate demands of the diggers. Secondly, that a similar committee be appointed to wait on the different newspapers and secure their cooperation to the same end. Thirdly, that a committee be appointed to make a record of all the coal banks and works, with a view of ascertaining which are working and which are not, and to report at the next meeting. After the transaction of some further business of importance, the meeting adjourned. The movement to checkmate the diggers has now been fairly started, and it will be the fault of the people if they are not soon brought to terms. There is no justification whatever for their extortionate demands, and it is due to every coal consumer that he resists it to the last."
headline: {'main': 'The Strike at the Coal Mines Extortionate Demands Resisted Important Action at Pittsburgh.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Strike at the Coal Mines Extortionate Demands Resisted Important Action at Pittsburgh.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the City Circuit  Court yesterday, before Judge ALEXANDER, an injunction was granted on the prayer of PRUDENOIO DEMURGUIONDO, restraining EDWARD K. COOPER and WALTER E. LAWTON from proceeding further in the ...
lead_paragraph: -- In the City Circuit Court yesterday, before Judge ALEXANDER, an injunction was granted on the prayer of PRUDENOIO DEMURGUIONDO, restraining EDWARD K. COOPER and WALTER E. LAWTON from proceeding further in the sale of certain guano islands in the Caribbean Sea, known as the "Navassa Islands." According to the prayer of the petitioner, it appears that on or before the 1st of June, 1864, EDWARD K. COOPER, of Baltimore, was in full possession of the island of Navassa, in the Caribbean Sea, in the enjoyment of which he was protected by an act of Congress, having been its first discoverer, in 1856. About the 1st of June last, COOPER entered into an agreement with MURGUIONDO to sell to him, and such others as he might associate with him, in a company to be organized agreeably to an act of the General Assembly of Maryland, chartering the "Navassa Phosphate" Company, all his privileges, rights, grants, &c., in said islands. COOPER was to receive in payment 5,500 shares of the capital stock of the company, at the par value of $100 per share, and $37,000 in cash, to be derived from the sale of the remaining shares of stock. It was also agreed that COOPER should pay into the treasury of the company $85,000 as working capital, and he, also, the petition alleges, agreed to pay MURGUIONDO, as compensation for organizing the company, 500 shares of the capital stock at its par value of $100 per share. The complainant then went on organizing the new company, interesting his friends and the capitalists generally, to subscribe to the stock; and in order to fully set forth the value of the Islands, Professors LEIBIG and FISK were dispatched thither to make an examination and report thereon. Their report, made a short time ago, declared the property much more valuable than even Capt. COOPER, the discoverer, every dreamed of. Since the report of these scientific gentlemen were made public. Capt. COOPER, the complainant avers, declines carrying out his previous agreement with him, and has sold or is about selling the islands to WALTER E. LAWTON and other capitalists of New-York. It is for the purpose of stopping this latter sale that the injunction is prayed for. The injunction having been granted, a hearing will be had at an early day, when the full merits of the case will come out. It is currently reported that Capt. COOPER has been offered a million and a half of dollars for his rights and interests in the Navassa Islands by capitalists in New-York. -- Baltimore Sun, Thursday.

abstract: For some time past a  fashionable lady named Mrs. DAVIDSON has been stopping at the Pianters' House, where her ladylike deportment and conversational powers attracted a good deal of attention, and induced a number of our most respectable citizens to make her acquaintance.
lead_paragraph: For some time past a fashionable lady named Mrs. DAVIDSON has been stopping at the Pianters' House, where her ladylike deportment and conversational powers attracted a good deal of attention, and induced a number of our most respectable citizens to make her acquaintance. She was quite handsome withal, and certain susceptible young gentlemen were captivated by the charms of the dashing young widow. She was gallanted to the theatre, to ice-cream saloons, and treated to numerous buggy rides by her ardent admirers. Yesterday the veil of mystery which surrounded the fair stranger was rudely lifted by Constable MCBRIDE, who entered the apartments of the charmer with a search warrant for a $200 diamond ring which had been stolen from Mr. DEFRIEZ, the jeweler. The lady was at first indignant at the accusation, and stoutly asserted her innocence. Then she pumped a few pearly tears into the sparkling fountains of her eyes; but such strategic movements could not deceive an old sworder like MCBRIDE, and he coolly informed her that he intended to search her. At the mention of the word search the lady fainted but the marble-hearted constable quietly, waited until she revived, and then proceeded to explore the premises in search of the missing ring. He round in her trunks and boxes a large quantity of jewelry and about $15,000 in greenbacks, but the [???]lag had not yet appeared to view. He then politely requested permission to search her person. Oh, dear! The proposal was too much for her delicate nerves, and over she tumbled in a second fainting fit. MCBRIDE sat down in the rocking chair and watted until the lady recovered her equilibrium, and then continued diving into the mysteries of her toilet for the ring. Before he had proceeded far in the manipulations she keeled over a third time. Coming to her senses once more she thrust her hand into her pocket and pretended to turn it inside out. but MCBRIDE, not being satisfied, crammed his own huge paw into the cavity, and on drawing it form brought up the ring. At the sight of the glittering jewel the lady fainted a fourth time, but the officer having secured the object of his search, told her it was useless to trouble herself in that way, and bade her good bye. The young gentlemen who had loaned her a number of valuable rings and other tokens of love, & c., were so shocked on learning the character of the lady that they declined to prosecute her, and advised the "waywa[???]d sister" to "depart in peace" -- a piece of advice which she was not slow in adopting, and the same day started for the Chicago Convention. -- Missouri Democrat.

abstract: -A son of ex-Mayor JOSEPH M. WARREN. of this city, died yesterday afternoon, under peculiarly painful circumstances. The deceased, a lad twelve years of age, had been in the habit of bathing in the University pod, near his father's residence, in which cows were in the habit of drinking and wading. It is supposed that some animal poison was thus communicated to the lad. The disease first developed itself in the form of a carbuncle on the nose, which soon spread over the face. The boy was not considered dangerous until yesterday morning, when Dr. ALDEN MARCH, of Albany, was called as counsel by the attending physician, Dr. BRINSMADE. The disease had the assumed an alarming form, and the boy died at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. We make this public allusion to a family affliction, by way of a general caution. The vaccine virus is derived from cows, and they are capable of communicating fatal as well as harmless innoculation. -- Troy Times, Sept. 2.

abstract: The public impatience to hear further from SHERMAN and his victorious army at Atlanta cannot be gratified this morning, owing to the interruption of railroad and telegraph communication south of Nashville by the rebels under WHEELER. Secretary ST ANTON, in an official dispatch, however, says there can be no doubt of the correctness of the news, and that communication will soon be restored, when we may expect a full account of the glorious achievement. The accounts of rejoicings which come to us from all quarters show how deeply this great success is felt.

abstract: We have, through Secretary STANTON, an official dispatch from Gen. SHERMAN, giving details of his great victory at Atlanta. On Tuesday last, SHERMAN broke the West Point road, and reached a good position from which to strike the Macon road. HOWARD found the enemy in force at Jonesboro, some twenty-six miles south of Atlanta, and easily repulsed the assault which they made in the...
lead_paragraph: We have, through Secretary STANTON, an official dispatch from Gen. SHERMAN, giving details of his great victory at Atlanta. On Tuesday last, SHERMAN broke the West Point road, and reached a good position from which to strike the Macon road. HOWARD found the enemy in force at Jonesboro, some twenty-six miles south of Atlanta, and easily repulsed the assault which they made in the afternoon. Finding strong opposition, SHERMAN advanced his left and centre rapidly to the railroad, broke it for a great distance, and interposed his whole army between Atlanta and the part of the enemy at Jonesboro. We made a general attack on Thursday, the Fourteenth Corps carrying the rebel works handsomely, with ten guns and 1,000 prisoners; and in the night the enemy retreated South. HOOD at Atlanta, finding SHERMAN on his road, blew up his magazines and decamped in the night, when the Twentieth Corps entered Atlanta. These and other details are well stated by Gen. SHERMAN.

abstract: Gilmore's J. R., Reply to Rebel Secretary Benjamin
snippet: Gilmore's J. R., Reply to Rebel Secretary Benjamin
lead_paragraph: In a circular of the State Department of the (so-called) Confederate States, which is addressed to the Commissioner to the Continent under the date of Aug. 25, 1864, and published generally in the Northern papers. I notice that Mr. J.P. BENJAMIN, "Secretary of State," etc., gives a statement of an interview between himself, Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS took place at JAMES F. JAQUES and myself, which took place at Richmond on the night of the 17th of July last. From it may be, the lapse of time, or an infirm memory, Mr. BENJAMIN has fallen into some errors of fact in this circular, and with a view to eliminating the truth, I propose to notice very briefly a few of his statements.

abstract: the Fall of
snippet: the Fall of
lead_paragraph: Five telegraphic words -- "Gen. SHERMAN has taken Atlanta," on Saturday, thrilled the nation with a joy not lees heartfelt, if somewhat less demonstrative, than that of France, when through the streets of Paris ran the cry: Sebastopol est pris. Indeed, the Sebastopol of Georgia has fallen, and with this splendid achievement one-half of the great campaign of the Summer is finished, and the seal of success already set upon the military operations of the year 1864. With nothing more done, the sum of that which has been done is victory.

abstract: Lyons, Lord, on McClellan and Democratic Party; Military Adventures; Democrats Seeking Interviews on Mediation
snippet: Lyons, Lord, on McClellan and Democratic Party; Military Adventures; Democrats Seeking Interviews on Mediation
lead_paragraph: There is not one military critic of eminence, either European or American, who has not pronounced Gen. McCLELLAN an unsuccessful, and what is worse, an incapable General; and foreign observers have ever since his downfall puzzled themselves in vain over the strange worship which he continues to receive from a certain portion of our people. They do not comprehend it, and owing to the surface view of our affairs which they are in the habit of taking, they probably never will comprehend it. And even posterity, too, which will be able to review the whole war, and will witness its consequences -- an advantage which we do not possess -- will probably experience just as much difficulty as our European cotemporaries, in finding a satisfactory explanation of so extraordinary a phenomenon as the elevation in the bosom of an ardent mobile, Democracy, a of slow, timid and beaten General into the rank of a political hero.
headline: {'main': "McClellan's Military Adventures The Intrigues with our Foreign Enemies.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "McClellan's Military Adventures The Intrigues with our Foreign Enemies.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Farragut; Chicago Platform
snippet: Farragut; Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: The Commander of Fort Morgan asked for terms. "The only terms we can make are unconditional surrender," was the reply. Thus FARRAGUT in the last stage of the war reiterates the words of GRANT in the first. These words make the rule of the war There is no different policy known in either army or navy. The champions of our flag invariably refuse to accept anything short of an absolute yielding to it. They will have the rebel bunting lowered flat to the earth before making a single concession. They are too jealous of the authority and dignity of the nation to chaffer, in its name, with defiant treason.

abstract: Richard Kane vs. Blind Mechanics' Association. -- This action was brought to recover $200 damages upon a failure of the defendants to furnish 92 dozen mats, a balance agreed to be furnished by the defendants to the plaintiff. The plaintiff testified that he made a contract with defendants to deliver to him 150 dozen mats, and that 58 dozen had been delivered in three different parcels at different times subsequent to the making of the contract -- it was not in writing. The defendants deny that they ever made any agreement to sell any mats to the plaintiff, and that the mats delivered were separate and independent sales.
lead_paragraph: Richard Kane vs. Blind Mechanics' Association. -- This action was brought to recover $200 damages upon a failure of the defendants to furnish 92 dozen mats, a balance agreed to be furnished by the defendants to the plaintiff. The plaintiff testified that he made a contract with defendants to deliver to him 150 dozen mats, and that 58 dozen had been delivered in three different parcels at different times subsequent to the making of the contract -- it was not in writing. abstract: Griefs and Military Successes; Convention at P I Island
snippet: Griefs and Military Successes; Convention at P I Island
lead_paragraph: One of the phenomena of the times is the gall of the Copperheads over the capture of Atlanta. It first took the shape of spiteful incredulity; afterward of bitter spleen. It is shown in all the Copperhead presses. It is indicated in the bare flag-poles which had just before been flaunting their colors to the breeze at MCCLELLAN's nomination. It can be read in the sullen face of the Copperhead who passes you in the street, or sits next you at the table. There is no denying the fact, everywhere patent, that the Copperheads, as a party, take the capture of Atlanta as a party misfortune.
headline: {'main': 'Military Successes and Copperhead Griefs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Military Successes and Copperhead Griefs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: the rebel privateering corvette Georgia by the frigate Niagara, off the coast of Portugal, seems, so far as we have the facts, to have been a perfectly justifiable affair. We have no doubt that the Captain of the Niagara, satisfied himself fully as to the character borne by the Georgia before he took possession of her. The fact that the latter made no defence in the presence of such a formidable adversary, argues nothing; and the trick of hoisting the English flag is one that has been adopted by all the pirates on every opportunity. The Georgia was engaged last Autumn and Winter in destroying our vessels on the high seas; and we had no doubt, when she lately passed out of a French port after refitting, that it was for the purpose of again engaging in her nefarious work.

abstract: The questions which for some time past have agitated the public mind, viz.: Whether the naval enlistments would be allowed and whether we should have a draft, seems at last to be settled.
lead_paragraph: The questions which for some time past have agitated the public mind, viz.: Whether the naval enlistments would be allowed and whether we should have a draft, seems at last to be settled. An official telegram from Assistant Adjt.-Gen. J.B. STONEHOUSE to Supervisor BLUNT, states the War Department has decided to allow the credits, and that Gen. HAYS has been instructed to enter them at once. The total naval enlistments allowed to New-York by the Commissioners is 18,448, Brooklyn 6,046, and the balance to other portions of the State. This division the Supervisor says he cannot understand. He thinks New-York is entitled properly to every man claimed in his report. His lists contained the names and full particulars of every man's enlistment, and were supported by transcripts of the records of the receiving ship North Carolina, of all men enlisted in New-York City and County, and received on board said ship, from April 15, 1861, to Feb. 24, 1864, and these were sworn to as being correct. Brooklyn, he thinks, cannot produce affidavits which will prove the justness of her claim; and why these men have been given to her, he bas yet to learn.

abstract: In the Matter of Anne Hughes. -- Many of these summary conviction by inferior magistrates without the intervention of a jury, if not in express violation of constitutional right, are at all events in derogation of the common law, always so jealous and careful of the liberty of the citizen. The statutes giving this power to inferior magistrates must be strictly construed. I cannot believe that the Legislature, in allowing the Police Justices of the City of New-York to place a person guilty of what is called disorderly conduct to bail for good behavior, in addition to imposing a fine of $10, or to commit to the City prison for ten days, intended that such person should be incarcerated for an indefinate period at the will of any magistrate. If they did intend that an exercise of despotic power they transcended their own power. The punishment is cruel, and the deprivation of liberty which it inflicts is without due process of law. This conviction should be set aside and the prisoner discharged.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Anne Hughes. -- Many of these summary conviction by inferior magistrates without the intervention of a jury, if not in express violation of constitutional right, are at all events in derogation of the common law, always so jealous and careful of the liberty of the citizen. If they did intend that an exercise of despotic power they transcended their own power. The punishment is cruel, and the deprivation of liberty which it inflicts is without due process of law. abstract: is not only the great entrepot of foreign supplies for the rebels, but it is the means through which the rebel credit is kept up in Europe. An eminent citizen of this country, of foreign birth, and now resident in Paris, writes in a recent letter, these words: "Let Wilmington be shut up or destroyed, so that the Cotton Loan in London will receive its last blow, and the Confederate cause in Europe will soon sink down to zero." Now that so great a part of our navy is released from duty in the Gulf by the victory at Mobile, and now that we have so powerful an iron-clad as the Tennessee fit for duty, we have no doubt that the crying case of Wilmington will speedily be attended to.

abstract: A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press writes from Washington that it is stated on good authority that there is a letter in Washington from Gen. GRANT, in which he either takes de-...
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Philadelphia Press writes from Washington that it is stated on good authority that there is a letter in Washington from Gen. GRANT, in which he either takes decided ground against the Chicago platform or decided ground in favor of the reelection of Mr. LINCOLN. The same writer adds: "All my information is to the effect that the Army of the Potomac, and nearly all its leaders, regular and volunteer, feel that a great slight has been put upon them by the resolutions of the Chicago Convention, and especially by the nomination of PENDLETON, of Ohio, the steady enemy of the war, as a candidate for Vice-President."

abstract: The telegraph has informed us that delegates from Nova Scotia, New-Brunswick and Prince Edward's Island, have been in session or several days at Charlottetown, in the lastnamed Province, for the purpose of considering the question of a Legislative Union for the whole of the Maritime Colonies. It is also reported that the convention has admitted to an informal participation in its deliberations, several members of the Government of Canada, who have constituted themselves -- with the approval of Lord MONCK -- a deputation to; sound the political leaders of the eastern colonies on the broad question of a Federal Union of the whole organized Provinces of British America. The immediate work before the Maritime Provinces -- that of establishing a common Government and Legislature for the whole, will probably be carried to a successful conclusion. It is not a party movement, but one growing out of a general conviction among all parties, that a Legislative Union is at once desirable and practicable. The graver matter which the Canadian delegation seek to urge on the attention of the sister colonies will probably invite more consideration there than it has done hitherto. But it is a delusion to suppose that it is going to be put through in a single session, or in half a dozen sessions, of any inter-Provincial Convention. It is equally vain to look for the completion of a scheme of federation embracing the whole of British America within the lifetime of the coalition avowedly framed in Canada to bring it about. Coalitions are not long-lived. But the present Government of Canada will, probably, survive long enough to bring the question of a Federative Union several degrees nearer a solution than it is today. And if so, they will not have altogether lived in vain.
