abstract: For months past the feeling in Richmond respecting the fate of Atlanta has been one of the gravest anxiety, in spite of the attempts to conceal it under a show of bravado. Said the London Times correspondent, writing from Richmond on the 14th of July: "It must be admitted that great and increasing anxiety is here felt, as telegram follows telegram announcing that Gen. JOHN-...
lead_paragraph: For months past the feeling in Richmond respecting the fate of Atlanta has been one of the gravest anxiety, in spite of the attempts to conceal it under a show of bravado. Said the London Times correspondent, writing from Richmond on the 14th of July: "It must be admitted that great and increasing anxiety is here felt, as telegram follows telegram announcing that Gen. JOHNSTON has again and again fallen back, until the Chattahoochee has been passed, and his bold antagonist, Gen. SHERMAN is seen to be within three leagues of Atlanta." To oppose SHERMAN, the same writer tells us, the rebels had not more than 55,000 effective bayonets. But these were every where spoken about as comprising the finest portion of the Southern troops; and since then HOOD has been reinforced by the whole of the graybeard and juvenile militia of Georgia forced into the field under Gov. BROWN's late order, which militia force, if we may believe rebel authorities, amounted to several myriads.

abstract: Steamship Charles C. Leary, Savage, New-Orleans Aug. 27, 8 A.M., and Belize 5 P.M., with mdse. and passengers to Arthur Leary. Passed steamship Ariel, bound up. abstract: the Chicago Convention adopted a resolution demanding an "immediate cessation of hostilities." It was on Friday, just three days after this, that the victorious army of Gen. SHERMAN marched into Atlanta. The Chicago resolution seems to have been very well timed to save the great rebel stronghold from capture by the forces of the Union, and had the Government immediately acceded to the immediate and imperative demand from Chicago, JEFF. DAVIS would have proudly carried on negotiations from behind its impregnable works, instead of being brought to humiliation upon its ruins.

abstract: The Inman steamer City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 24th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult., arrived here yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The Inman steamer City of Washington, from Liverpool on the 24th, and Queenstown on the 26th ult., arrived here yesterday morning. Her news was generally anticipated. She brings, however, the important intelligence that the rebel pirate Georgia was seized twenty miles from Lisbon by the frigate Niagara. The legality of this seizure may become a subject of controversy, but the latest telegrams via Queenstown, indicated that the British Government is disposed to acquiesce in the justice of the capture. It is even reported that the capture was effected with the full knowledge and consent of that Government.

abstract: the Rebel Ram
snippet: the Rebel Ram
lead_paragraph: The story of the capture of the rebel ironclad ram Tennessee in Mobile Bay must form one of the most remarkable chapters in naval warfare. It was no ordinary sort of sea monster that could bear the concentrated attack of thirteen vessels of war, six of them iron-clad, with an armament of two hundred guns, and yet come out of the engagement with but a few splinters detached from her inner casing to mark the damage in her interior. The Tennessee lay in the rear of our fleet after the forts had been passed on the morning of the 5th of August. And of the fourteen vessels at Admiral FARRAGUT's disposal for the attack, all were perfectly sound and uninjured (except the Tecumseh which had been sunk by a torpedo) when the order was given, shortly after eight o'clock, to 'bout ship and give battle to the ram. A signal was given to all the fleet not only to commence the attack with guns, but to run her down at full speed. The Monongahela, a new steam frigate, not iron-clad, was the first to strike the Tennessee, but the shock, tremendous as it must have been to an ordinary craft, had no apparent effect upon the ram. The Lackawanna, a fast sloop-of-war, next struck her, but with no greater effect. The Admiral's flagship, the Hartford, next dashed against her with her bow at full speed, immediately following up the terrific stroke with a whole port broadside of 9-inch shot and thirteen pounds of powder, at a distance of twelve feet; but still the oaken and iron thews and sinews of the monster showed no perceptible loosening or feebleness. The monitors and the remainder of the fleet then closed in upon her; and she surrendered, simply when she had no longer seaway left to move in. The pounding lasted for a full hour and a half, and at the end of that time she was given up by her commander, BUCHANAN, in a condition which enabled the engineers of our fleet to report on the 13th oi August -- eight days after the fight had taken place -- that she was "in a state to do good service."
headline: {'main': 'A Remarkable Chapter in Naval Warfare.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Remarkable Chapter in Naval Warfare.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Matter of the Petition of Sarah C. Bouton for the custody of her two children, Charles Bouton, Jr., and Alice Bouton. -- This was an application on the part of a mother to obtain the custody of her two children, who had been removed from this City to Connecticut, pending a divorcement between the lady and her husband. It was alleged that the father had taken them out for a ride, and then gone with them out of the State. An order was made requiring the children to be produced on Wednesday morning.

abstract: Opdyke vs Marble; World Libel Suit
snippet: Opdyke vs Marble; World Libel Suit
lead_paragraph: George Opdyke vs. Manton Marble and others. -- In this case the plaintiff commenced a suit to recover $50,000 damages for an alleged libel published in the World newspaper, and based on the T.W. letters. The plaintiff obtained an order directing Manton M. Marble and Elon Comstock to make discovery of their books and papers, in order to allow the plaintiff to discover who are the proprietors of the World, in order that they may be joined as defendants in the suit. The defendants now applied to vacate such order, on the ground that the same was irregular, being ex parte and obtained without notice, and also that the affidavit on which the same was based was defective.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: The political skies begin to brighten. The clouds that lowered over the Union cause a month ago are breaking away. The most careless observers cannot fail to notice a marked change in the tone of public sentiment within that time. It was not to be denied, and we did not attempt to conceal, that a profound despondency had taken possession of the public mind. Distrust and dissatisfaction pervaded the Union ranks; the Union candidates seemed to be losing their hold on the public confidence; and the enemies of the Administration were open and loud in their exultant predictions of disaster to the Union cause.

abstract: A very complete Union victory was achieved by Gen. GILLEM, commanding a portion of the Union forces in East Tennessee, at Greenville, on the morning of the 4th. The camp of the notorious guerrilla and raider JOHN MORGAN was surprised, MORGAN himself killed, his Staff and one piece of artillery captured, and his force entirely dispersed, with a loss of from fifty to one hundred in killed alone. This is the end of MORGAN.
lead_paragraph: A very complete Union victory was achieved by Gen. GILLEM, commanding a portion of the Union forces in East Tennessee, at Greenville, on the morning of the 4th. This is the end of MORGAN.

abstract: Appointed N Y Collector of Port
snippet: Appointed N Y Collector of Port
lead_paragraph: -- It is already generally known that SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., has been appointed Collector of this port, in place of HIRAM BARNEY, resigned. We understand that he takes possession of the office to-day. No man in the City is more thoroughly acquainted with all the duties and requirements, official and political, of the position, than Mr. DRAPER. He has great promptness and decision of character, and is familiar with the routine of commercial business, and of everything connected with it. The commercial community which is especially interested in the vigilant and vigorous administration of the affairs of the Custom-house, welcomes the appointment of Mr. DRAPER as a marked concession to the claims of commercial men. Mr. BARNEY retires from the post, whose laborious duties and responsibilities he has met for three years past, with the respect and esteem of the whole community.

abstract: The Bandiera Nacional, a paper published at Matamoras, declares that the French and Algerine troops now in Mexico were utterly defeated in four pitched battles with the Mexicans. The date of these conflicts is not given. They occurred at Brea, in the State of Guerrero. The Mexicans were led by Gen. DREGO ALVAREZ, and in accordance with the terms of the battle, which included "no quarter," the prisoners taken were put to death. Col. RIVA PALACIO has made an official report, in which he claims to have won on the 5th of July, at Zetacuaro, in the State of Mexico, a victory over 2,000 Imperialists, putting them to flight. Don. R.G. PAEZ, formerly private secretary of JUAREZ, has given in his adhesion to the French rule.

abstract: The hospital ship Florence Nightingale, stationed in the Lower Quarantine, has now no sick men on board. The few fever patients that have been placed on the ship during the season have been treated with much success by Dr. THEODORE WALSER, the physician in charge. The deaths have borne a very small proportion to the number of cases received. There are but six vessels at present detained at Quarantine, and those temporarily -- for observation. The arrangements made by the Quarantine Commissioners and the Health Officer, Dr. SWINBURNE, have prevented any unusual sickness, and the diseases incident to the season have been confined within proper limits.
lead_paragraph: The hospital ship Florence Nightingale, stationed in the Lower Quarantine, has now no sick men on board. abstract: Palmerston's, Lord, Tiverton Speech
snippet: Palmerston's, Lord, Tiverton Speech
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON, in a recent speech to his constituents at Tiverton, referring to this country, said that the hope was warranted "that many months will not elapse before some progress will be made toward healing the tremendous breach that now exists." We are happy to inform his Lordship that some progress, and that of a very decided character, has been already made in that direction. The occupation of the Weldon Railroad, the capture of the forts and the rebel fleet at Mobile, the defeat of HOOD'S army and the fall of Atlanta, and the defeat and death of JOHN MORGAN, are all decided steps in the progress of which he speaks. And it is gratifying to think how pleased the Premier also will be to hear of this decided progress toward the realization of the hope which he thus expressed.

abstract: The steamship Scotia, from Liverpool, Aug. 27, via Queenstown on the 28th, arrived here yesterday afternoon. The seizure of the pirate Georgia, by the Niagara, attracted much comment, but the general impression of the English press, is to the effect that the seizure is legal, and that the purchase of any enemy's vessel of war, when said vessel is blockaded in port, without means of escape, must take the risk of subsequent seizure. The London Daily News, editorially quotes a decision by Lord STOWELL, in a case exactly similar to that of the captured rebel steamer Georgia, as conclusive evidence that the seizure by the Niagara was perfectly legal. The rebel cruiser Florida arrived at Santa Cruz, Teneriffe, on the 3d of August, from Bermuda, and sailed again on the 4th. The news from France is unimportant. The Emperor was about to visit the Camp at Chalons. Prince HUMBERT, of Italy, would arrive in Paris on the 27th. The Opinions of Turin denies the rumor that a marriage has been arranged between Prince HUMBERT and the Princess ANNA MURAT. Our correspondent at Paris, however, reaffirms it. The Duke of AUGUSTENBURG had dispatched to Frankfort a memorial establishing the validity of his claims to the Schleswig-Holstein throne, as demanded by the Federal Diet.

abstract: This morning, a large number of convalescents and detached service men arrived at Harper's Ferry, and are now being distributed to their respective commands. This arrival will reinforce this army to the extent of three thousand. The general feeling among the rank and file of the army of Western Virginia is of a most cheerful character.

abstract: The rebel pickets refuse to believe that Atlanta has fallen. They have become very friendly, and approach close to our lines, with passes from their officers, for the purpose of trading apparently, but all having their pockets filled with the proclamation of JEFF. DAVIS, offering protection and safe conduct to deserters.
lead_paragraph: HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY OF THE POTOMAC, Sunday, Sept. 4, 1864.

abstract: -- The assurance comes to us on excellent authority that a satisfactory basis of compromise has been reached by the two sections of the Democracy, which will at once "carry the country" and save a split in the party. Gen. MCCLELLAN is to issue a letter of acceptance of a violently blood-thirsty character, and on the back of this the chiefs of the Wigwam here are to get up a genuine war-dance. Pari passu with these proceedings, Mr. PENDLETON is to announce his acceptance of the nomination and the Chicago Peace Platform, with no mental reservation whatever. On the latter a new Mozart requiem is to be composed, and all will be serene.

abstract: -- Senator SEMMES, of Louisiana, does not hold the same view of the insignificance of the loss of Atlanta as the Daily News of New-York. In a speech delivered at Jackson, the capital of Mississippi, just before SHERMAN's capture of Atlanta, the rebel Senator said: "he did not desire to excite any undue expectations or alarm -- that everything depended upon SHERMAN being kept out of Atlanta; that Richmond was safe, and Atlanta would be the great battle-field of the war."
lead_paragraph: -- Senator SEMMES, of Louisiana, does not hold the same view of the insignificance of the loss of Atlanta as the Daily News of New-York. abstract: -- All the great Generals whom JEFF. DAVIS sends to command his chief army in the Southwest, seem to be quickly attacked by some mysterious malady, whose chief symptom is the appetite for moving backward. SIDNEY JOHNSTON was first seized by this disease, and after it had driven him across the entire State of Tennessee, he communicated the infection to BEAUREGARD. BEAUREGARD gave it to BRAGG, who had a shocking attack. BRAGG left it as a legacy to JO. JOHNSTON, whom it assailed furiously. JO. JOHNSTON gave it to HOOD, who by suddenly staggering back from Atlanta, shows that his case has had a bad beginning. HOOD swore but a fortnight ago that he would never retreat, that he would stand his ground in spite of fate, or die as in other days KIRBY was wont to give up the ghost. But what was the use of his attempting to resist the power of a malady which he inherited through four generations of rebel predecessors? We expect to see his affliction take on yet more violent manifestations before long.
lead_paragraph: -- All the great Generals whom JEFF. abstract: The Fifth Precinct police reported yesterday, that while a number of soldiers connected with the Third Regiment Rhode Island Volunteers were escorting a squad of recruits from the Battery Barracks to the steamer Fulton, lying at Pier No. 37 North River, one of the recruits, named JOHN CLEMENS, made an attempt to escape. He suddenly threw off his coat, and ran rapidly up West Broadway to Leonard-street, pursued by the guard, who fired upon him as he ran, but without effect. As CLEMENS passed the Fifth Precinct Station-house, Policeman FIELD joined in the chase, and finally succeeded in arresting him in the yard of No. 64 White-street. He was conveyed by Officer FIELD to the steamer, and delivered into the charge of Lieut. DARLING.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth Precinct police reported yesterday, that while a number of soldiers connected with the Third Regiment Rhode Island Volunteers were escorting a squad of recruits from the Battery Barracks to the steamer Fulton, lying at Pier No. 37 North River, one of the recruits, named JOHN CLEMENS, made an attempt to escape. He suddenly threw off his coat, and ran rapidly up West Broadway to Leonard-street, pursued by the guard, who fired upon him as he ran, but without effect. As CLEMENS passed the Fifth Precinct Station-house, Policeman FIELD joined in the chase, and finally succeeded in arresting him in the yard of No. 64 White-street. He was conveyed by Officer FIELD to the steamer, and delivered into the charge of Lieut. DARLING.

abstract: The long-anticipated match, at two-mile heats, between the brown stallion George Wilkes (late Fillingham) and the black gelding General Butler, which has occupied the entire attention of the sporting world for weeks past, and on which an enormous amount of money is staked; comes off at the Fashion Course. Long Island, to-day, provided it is fair, otherwise as all parties are equally determined that this shall be the great event of the modern era, and all are equally desirous that the record of time made shall be something extraordinary -- it will be postponed until to-morrow or the next fair day, of which due notice will be given on the bulletin-boards in season to prevent, disappointment; but as the storm has deased and the wind changed at the hour at which we are writing, we have every reason to anticipate "a fair day and good track," the largest attendance and the most intense excitement that has ever been known on any occasion within the last quarter of a century. So much has been said and written about this great match that nothing remains but to await the result, which will cause over $100,000 to change hands.

abstract: and Our Generals
snippet: and Our Generals
lead_paragraph: It is part of the plan of Copperhead operations against the Administration, whenever a General fails in the field, to declare, before anything whatever is known of the circumstances, that it was "LINCOLN" that was the cause of it; either by refusing reinforcements changing the plan of campaign, or performing some other knavish trick. "LINCOLN" plays the same part on Southern battle-fields, according to these commentators, that "ce monstre PITT et les guinees Anglaise," according to the French Jacobins, played in all murders, conspiracies and emeutes in Paris during the first revolution, or as PALMERSTON has, according to Austrian politicians, played in Italian and Polish outbreaks during the last thirty years. Whenever anything goes wrong, he is sure to be at the bottom of it. Occasionally, an attempt is made to lend a touch of solemnity to the farce by summoning LINCOLN and STANTON to answer to an imaginary indictment, for the failure of an assault in Georgia or the loss of a battle in Louisiana, before an imaginary tribunal, composed of the editor of the World or of the Daily News, or "any other man," where the two culprits receive a frightful "wigging," and are discharged with the assurance that if they are caught any more causing the loss of battles, of which they knew nothing until they were over, something still more dreadful will happen to them.

abstract: Cook, Rev. Russell T.
snippet: Cook, Rev. Russell T.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the remains of the Rev. R.S. COOK, late Secretary Of the New-York Sabbath Committee, were buried in Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral services were conducted by the Rev. Dr. GANSE, at the Dutch Reformed Church, in Twenty-third-street, near Sixth-avenue. The reverned gentleman paid a just and touching tribute to the memory of his departed friend. Mr. COOK was no common man, and very prominently connected with some of the most important enterprises of American Christianity and philanthropy. He had a large share in organizing the Colporteur system of the American Tract Society, in promoting the observance of the Lord's day in the City of New York and throughout the country, and in setting in motion the United States Christian Commission. He did an immense amount of good to our foreign, especially the German population, whose spiritual welfare he had deeply at heart. He was a man or commanding person, strong will, indomitable energy, rare executive genius, of extensive knowledge of human nature, and burning zeal in the service of his Master. He has done a great and good work. A considerable number of the leading ministers and Christian laymen of the City paid him their last tribute of honor. His memory will live as long as the American Tract Society and the American Sabbath, to which he devoted the best energies of his useful life.

abstract: INCREASE OF TEACHER'S SALARIES. The Brooklyn Board of Education has been engaged at nearly every meeting for some months past, in discussing the propriety of raising the salaries of teachers of the public schools. At a regular sessionheld Tuesday evening the matter was again brought up by Mr. WHITING, who offered a resolution to the effect, that...
lead_paragraph: INCREASE OF TEACHER'S SALARIES. -- The Brooklyn Board of Education has been engaged at nearly every meeting for some months past, in discussing the propriety of raising the salaries of teachers of the public schools. At a regular sessionheld Tuesday evening the matter was again brought up by Mr. WHITING, who offered a resolution to the effect, that $100 be added to the salaries male principals and that $50 be added to the salaries of all teachers other than male principals -- one half of the mentioned amount being payable on the passage of this resolution, and one half on the 24th of December. It was stated there was no money on hand for the purpose, and no appropriation could be made without the consent of the Common Council. Considerable debate ensued on a motion to refer to the same committee for report as to the legality of transferring money from one fund to another for a purpose not provided for in the estimates. The motion was eventually carried.

snippet: Personalities in the Canvass
lead_paragraph: We are entering upon a Presidential campaign of unequaled importance. To our own judgment and that of great numbers of our citizens, the success of the Chicago platform and the Democratic nominee, would involve ultimately the acknowledgment of the independence of the rebel Confederacy, the permanence of Slavery on this continent, and the destruction of our national unity and imperial power.

abstract: Union State Nomination
snippet: Union State Nomination
lead_paragraph: The Union State Convention at Syracuse, yesterday, nominated Hon. REUBEN E. FENTON for Governor of the State of New-York. He received 247 votes, to 69 for Mr. TREMAIN, and 35 for Gen. Dix. Mr. FENTON has had a long experience in public life having served as a Representative in the Thirty-third, Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Congresses, and being also a member of the present (or Thirty-seventh) Congress, where he achieved distinction both for his general ability and as a hard-working member of the Committee of Ways and Means. He is a native of Chautauque County, which forms a part of the district he represented in Congress. His patriotic and persistent labors, both in and out of Congress, to advance all measures for the benefit of the soldiers of the Army of the Union, greatly endeared him to the army, -- where he is spoken of as the "Soldier's Friend" -- and will secure him warm support from the loyal people of the State. Mr. FENTON is a lawyer by profession, but was long and successfully engaged in mercantile life.

abstract: On last Wednesday a railroad collision took place about tour miles east of Canton, Stark County, between two freight trains on the Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, resulting in the death of two men who had succeeded in getting on the train at Alliance, without the knowledge or permission of the conductor. The trains met in going round a short curve, and the two engines were upon each other in a moment. The locomotives were badly smashed, and the cars shivered to kindling wood. The engineers and firemen jumped off and were uninjured, but the two men were horribly mutilated and instantly killed. From papers found upon them, it was ascertained that their names were IMPERITUS MOTT and ISAAC SMITH, both from Deerfield, Portage County, Ohio. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, Sept. 1.

abstract: THE CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY. -- The corner-stone of the Church of the Holy Trinity, Madison-avenue, corner of East Forty-second-street, will be laid at 4 o'clock this afternoon. This is a new enterprise, started by Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, Jr., in the Rutger's Institute Chapel, early in the last Spring. The building is to be of blue and Ohio yellow stone, and brick laid in black mortar. JACOB W. MOULD is the architect. We are assured that the ceremony of to-day will be an occasion of great interest.

abstract: THE GERMAN OPERA. Mr.GROVER'S brief inaugural season of German opera is announced to commence at the Academy of Music on Monday next, with GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust" in a complete and unmutilated form, with a new mise en scene, and an entirely new and splendid wardrobe, imported...
lead_paragraph: THE GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr.GROVER'S brief inaugural season of German opera is announced to commence at the Academy of Music on Monday next, with GOUNOD'S opera of "Faust" in a complete and unmutilated form, with a new mise en scene, and an entirely new and splendid wardrobe, imported expressly for the occasion. With a man of enterprise and activity (as Mr. GROVER has proved himself to be in other matters of amusement) at the business head of affairs, and with CARL ANSCHUTZ in charge of the music only, there is a far more flattering prospect for German opera than there has been hitherto -- the more so as Mr. GROVER has ample means at his disposal, and expresses his determination to leave no means unapplied or expense spared to achieve success. Mr. BERGFELD has been employed by him for some time in Europe in the engagement of new artists, the selection of fresh operas, and the purchase of new and complete wardrobes, &c. Until the arrival of the fresh singers, the company comprises the majority of last season's favorites, including Madame FREDERICI, Messrs. HIMMER, HABELMANN, HERRMANNS. &c. -- an engagement with CARL FORMES, is also contemplated. The inaugural season will only last two weeks," when the company proceeds to Boston, for a like period. Mr. GROVER has signed contracts for the sole right of giving German opera at all the opera houses in the large cities.

abstract: The opposition steamboat Washoe exploded her boiler in Sacramento River last night. Her upper works were shattered and stern blown off. One hundred and fifty passengers were killed and wounded. Fifty persons are dead or will soon die. The boat was running at a high rate of speed. The engineer said before he died that the cause of the explosion was rotten iron in the boiler.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRNNCISCO, Tuesday, Sept. 6.

abstract: Pirate Trade; The Georgia Case
snippet: Pirate Trade; The Georgia Case
lead_paragraph: Without attempting to forestall the judgment which will shortly be delivered before a United States Prize Court in the case of the Georgia, there are one or two points not unworthy of notice that seem to have been hitherto overlooked in the disquisitions to which the subject has given rise, Mr. BATES, the "Liverpool merchant of great respectability," who purchased the Georgia, from the Confederate agents, was advised that the transaction was one out of which the very difficulty which has occurred might arise. It is true, the vessel was registered at the Liverpool Customs in the name of Mr. BATES, so long ago as the 30th of June last. It is equally true, that the British Customs' Order interdicting the sale and refitting of such vessels in British ports was not issued for some weeks subsequent to the registration in question. But Mr. BATES, in spite of all this, was so well informed of the questionable legality of his purchase, that before chartering her to the Portuguese Government for mail service on the coast of Africa, he had her fully insured against capture at the hands of the Federal cruisers.

abstract: From the Army of the Potomac there comes a rumor of the return of a part of EARLY's force, and that another attack was premeditated upon our position on the Weldon Railroad. As all of EARLY's force, two days ago, was still in the Valley, and as his troops don't travel on wings, there can be but little truth in the report. The Copperhead organs here, yesterday afternoon, bulletined the reported recapture of Atlanta by HOOD, the only foundation for which was a dog-tail-tin-kettle sell, perpetrated by the rebel pickets in front of Petersburgh.
lead_paragraph: From the Army of the Potomac there comes a rumor of the return of a part of EARLY's force, and that another attack was premeditated upon our position on the Weldon Railroad. As all of EARLY's force, two days ago, was still in the Valley, and as his troops don't travel on wings, there can be but little truth in the report. The Copperhead organs here, yesterday afternoon, bulletined the reported recapture of Atlanta by HOOD, the only foundation for which was a dog-tail-tin-kettle sell, perpetrated by the rebel pickets in front of Petersburgh.

abstract: Memminger and Confederate Finances; Finances; Trenholm >amp; Memminger; Trenholm on Confederate Finances
snippet: Memminger and Confederate Finances; Finances; Trenholm >amp; Memminger; Trenholm on Confederate Finances
lead_paragraph: When Mr. MEMMINGER and his chief hit upon the grand scheme, last winter, for the restoration of the credit of the Confederacy, by the forcible conversion of the Treasury notes then in circulation into Government bonds bearing interest, we took the liberty of respectfully pointing out that this was repudiation pure and simple; that it totally destroyed the confidence of the Southern people in Confederate money; that the depreciation of the paper would become worse than ever; and that though the new issue might not amount to $100,000,000 while the old one reached $700,000,000, the new one would reach a lower point of worthlessness than had ever been attained by the old one. The matter was very simple. The Confederate Treasury had issued enormous quantities of paper, which was in use as the circulating medium, and which kept diminishing in value every day. So the Richmond sages rushed to the conclusion that it was losing its purchasing power solely because there was too much of it; that the confidence, or want of confidence of the people in its ultimate redemption, had nothing to do with its purchasing power, and that all that was needed to make it worth coin was to out down the quantity.

abstract: Rebel Secretary of War, Report
snippet: Rebel Secretary of War, Report
lead_paragraph: A report of the rebel Secretary of War, some four months old, has been sent North for circulation as a campaign document in the interest of the Peace Democracy. We publish the chief portion of it in other columns, that our readers may gain some notion of its contents. The general reader would find much more to interest him in the report if the retrospect which it takes covered the Summer campaigns. But for the partisans of DAVIS, among ourselves, it will serve a much better purpose than if it had come down to a later date, and taken a survey of the rebel disasters in Georgia and Mobile Bay, the rebel disasters in Virginia, and the shutting up of the grand rebel army, under LEE within a space of a few square miles around the Confederate capital. Viewing the matter in this light, one of the McClellan organs here introduces its readers to the report with the remark that "it is an able document, clear and well written, and presents the Southern face of the war in a light so favorable as to attract, without doubt, the attention of other nations."

abstract: Tho proprietor of the Old Bowery Theatre gives the Masonic Mission a benefit to-night. The piece is a local Masonic drama entitled the "Signets of King Solomon." This is the first theatrical benefit of the mission, and from the intensely interesting character of the play, and the evident intent on the part of the fraternity and public at large to make it a benefit indeed, it will prove worthy of being the first. The funds raised by the benefit are to be used in sending forward nurses and supplies to our soldiers. With such attracting considerations the house will, no doubt, prove a full one.

abstract: Report
snippet: Report
lead_paragraph: The report of JAMES A. SEDDON, Secretary of War to the Confederate States, has made its appearance. It is published without date, but the fact that it makes mention of the defeat of Gen. STURGIS' expedition from Memphis in February last indicates that the document must have been written as late as March. In the course of his review of the military operations, Secretary SEDDON alludes to the death of the gallant DAHLGREN, and thus reiterates the slanders against him.

abstract: Rev S H Tyng, Jr; Corner-Stone Land
snippet: Rev S H Tyng, Jr; Corner-Stone Land
lead_paragraph: -- The corner-stone of the new Church of the Holy Trinity, corner of Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street, was laid yesterday afternoon with appropriate exercises. Rev. Dr. TYNG officiated on the oocasion, in the absence of the Bishop, and at 4 o'clock he headed a procession, consisting of several of the clergy, the rector, wardens and vestrymen of the parish, and others, and proceeded to the site of the new edifice. After the customary prayers and lessons. Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, Jr., Rector of the Holy Trinity, placed, in a tin box prepared for the purpose, a copy of the Bible, a copy of the Constitution of the United States, and other documents wrapped around with a small American flag. The box was then deposited in the stone, and the usual ceremonies of laying it were conducted by Dr. STEPHEN H. TYNG, assisted by the Rector. The new church is situated on the northeast corner of Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street. The building to be erected will be of bricK, in the Gothic style of architecture, and capable of seating a large congregation. It will probably be finished some time next Spring.

abstract: -- JOHN and BELLA WILLIAMS were arraigned yesterday before Justice DODGE, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged, on the complaint of Mr. MARK RICH, living at No. 103 Orchard-street, with having robbed him of $50. Complainant was passing through Grand-street at an early hour yesterday morning, and when in the vicinity of Mercer-street he was met by BELLA, who thrust her hands into his pocket and abstracted the money. He seized hold of her for the purpose of recovering it, when JOHN, the other prisoner, came up and knocked complainant down. While he was prostrated, BELLA passed the money to JOHN, and the latter escaped with it. Officer ROBERTS, of the Eighth Precinct, hearing an alarm, went in pursuit of the thieves, and after a long chase effected their arrest. They were committed, to default of $1,000 bail each, to answer.

It was announced that a plot had been discovered for the destruction of the steamers running on the Sound. Three emissaries, it was stated, were recently...
lead_paragraph: A special dispatch from New-London in the Commercial Advertiser of yesterday gives some particulars of the great scare which has prevailed for a day or two on the Sound. On Monday last the various steamboat offices of the lines from Boston to New-York were profoundly excited. It was announced that a plot had been discovered for the destruction of the steamers running on the Sound. Three emissaries, it was stated, were recently sent North to ascertain the best point and time at which to strike these boats; and after fixing upon that hour of the night (about 10 P.M.) when the steamers going to Stonington, to Norwich, and to Newport are commonly in sight of each other off the Connecticut shore, they were about to make off with their report to the pirate steamer Electric Spark, which, armed and equipped for the business, is hovering about our coast, when one of their number, struck with remorse, or with the hope of reward, appeared at the Custom-house and revealed the nefarious design. All was bustle and alarm. The gunboat lying at New-London got up steam on Monday night, and ran out into the Sound, with orders to warn all boats against paying attention to any signals whatever. Monday being a stormy night, the boats were all detained on the Sound, and great fear consequently fell upon all concerned. Four revenue steamers have been ordered to look after the Electric Spark, and it is hoped that the danger is over. it is asserted that the Tallahassee ran into Newport harbor about three weeks ago, looked at things in general, quietly steamed around theGuerriere, then lying there, and steamed out again unchallenged. As the Electric Spark is the prize and consort of the Tallahassee, it may be that the present scare grew out of this circumstance.

abstract: Between 11 and 13 o'clock yesterday morning, while two painters, named WM. HENDRICKS and WM. BURNS, were at work on a ladder scaffold, painting near the roof of the six-story building on the corner of Broadway and Worth-street, one of the ropes of the end of the ladder gave way; and both the men were precipitated to the ground, a distance of over fifty feet. HENDRICKS struck the sidewalk, and was so badly injured by the fall that there is no hope of his recovery. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital by Officer BEATLEY, of the Twenty-fifth Precinct. Fortunately, BURNS had sufficient presence of mind to seize hold of a rope in his descent, and for this reason was not so much injured. He was taken to his residence, corner of Ninth-avenue and Thirty-second-street. HENDRICKS lives at the corner of Hudson and Grove streets.

abstract: Power of Evil Possessed by Confederacy
snippet: Power of Evil Possessed by Confederacy
lead_paragraph: "The skillful and pertinacious resistance which the slaveholders have made only proves how formidable a power of evil they will be if allowed to establish themselves as a nation." So observes that profound political philosopher, J. STUART MILL, in a private letter to a friend in this city. It is a pregnant truth. There are not a few men who make the fierceness and stubborness with which this war is kept up by the rebels reasons for abandoning it; when in truth they are the very strongest of all reasons for our maintaining it to the very last limit of our endurance.

abstract: Meeting in Union-square, New-York; Resolutions of
snippet: Meeting in Union-square, New-York; Resolutions of
lead_paragraph: The Democracy of the City assembled at Union Square last evening to ratify the nominations of the Chicago Convention. Taking into consideration the fact that neither of the candidates hare as yet signified their acceptance of the nomination, there was a considerable display of fireworks and noisy enthusiasm, but the speakers and the audience were evidently embarrassed and puzzled to know whether they had a standard-bearer for the Presidential campaign or not. Loud and numerous were the quories from the crowd, "Has he accepted? "and the answer invariably came back, "He has not, but he will." This was very unsatisfactory, but the pyrotechnics were very satisfactory, and the large portion of the audience who were drawn together to witness the unusually fine display of rockets, Roman candles and illuminated bombs, cared very little who headed the Democratic ticket or who declined to stand on a peace platform in a Major-General's uniform. Although the speaking was much better and the presence of many distinguished men l[???]nt eclat to the meeting, the attendance was not nearly as large as at the MCCLELLAN meeting gotten up by HIRAM KETCHUM several weeks ago.

abstract: Sympathy for Jeff. Davis
snippet: Sympathy for Jeff. Davis
lead_paragraph: It is related of a distinguished gentleman of this City, who was supposed to be identified with foreign nationalities, but who held his own means with very tight grasp, that on one occasion an eminent exile, in great distress, called upon him for help, but was dismissed empty-handed, and as the forlorn stranger went forth to hunger and poverty, his host opened the door after him to say, "You have my sympathy, Sir; you have my sympathy!"

abstract: Recruiting; The Duty of To-day
snippet: Recruiting; The Duty of To-day
lead_paragraph: There is a duty before earnest and loyal citizens even more urgent than that which awaits them at the ballot-box. The Union forces are moving with steady and unfaltering step from victory to victory. GRANT has his subtle adversary by the throat, where he can only escape by the surrender of all that gives form, consistence and cohesion to the rebel States as a confederated Power. SHERMAN, striking home where the productive energies of rebeldom have had greatest scope, and have been in most vigorous and successful exercise, has cut the Confederacy in twain, and reduced what was once the best disciplined army of the South to a disjointed force, which has saved itself from utter extinction only by inglorious flight. The boasted invasion of the North by the Shenandoah Valley has resolved itself into a mere bluster and parade of offensive strength, which, while serving the purpose of a momentary blind to the opinion of the world, has cost the invaders the loss of their main line of communication south of Richmond, and destroyed the prestige of their chief General alike for caution and for judgment.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, MARIA WOODRUFF and LOUISA PAYNE plead guilty to grand larceny, and were sent to the State Prison for two years each. SARAH HAGAN and MARIA BARRETT, alias Davidson, plead guilty to petit larceny, and were sent to the Penitentiary for six months. ANN MCFADDEN plead guilty to an attempt at grand larceny, and was sent to the State Prison for two years. ANN BURNS plead guilty of an attempt at grand larceny; was remanded for sentence. JOHN BURNS, previously convicted of an assault and battery, second offence, was sentenced to be confined in the Penitentiary for one year.

abstract: Authors; Profits of Various
snippet: Authors; Profits of Various
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. TENNYSON's new volume, Enoch Arden, seems to have met with remarkable success in England. Though issued at the "dead time" of the publishing season, when every family is scattered about the world from Norway to Switzerland, sixteen thousand copies were sold in two days. This is an extraordinary demand for England, where to buy new books is an exception to the custom that generally prevails of borrowing them, instead. So important a branch of trade has the lending or circulating library system become there, that there are now three joint stock companies engaged in the business, with a full staff of directors, officers, &c. The latter of these companies has grown out of the famous establishment originated by Mr. MUDIE. He has recently given up his interest in it to a joint stock company, established for the purpose, with a capital stock of £100,000, or $000,000, retaining a share in the management which he has hitherto conducted with so much success.

abstract: Annual Celebration
snippet: Annual Celebration
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the eighth annual celebration of the New-York Caledonian Club took place at Jones, Wood. The genuine old-fashioned Scottish games were entered into with a zest seldom equaled, and the feats accomplished were generally superior to any ever witnessed here. The grounds were densely packed, and it is estimated that there were over twenty-five thousand people present. Yet, notwithstanding this immense gathering, there was not a single disturbance of any kind, and the police report that not one arrest was made. A higher compliment to the gentlemen composing the club and their visitors it would be almost impossible to offer.

abstract: Letter of Acceptance
snippet: Letter of Acceptance
lead_paragraph: The response of the Chicago nominee has been awaited with a good deal of interest. The nine days' grace he had taken had shown the extreme unpopularity of the platform on which he was nominated. Would he repudiate that platform and yet keep the nomination? Such an inconsistency would disgust everybody. Would he renounce the nomination? Nobody who knew what he had been so long in training for, believed that. Would he accept the platform squarely? It would ruin him. How then was he to manage? Naturally the people were curious.

abstract: The Bohemian and Polish Societies of this City paid a complimentary visit to Mayor GUNTHER yesterday forenoon. About one hundred members were present, who marched into the Pa[???] accompanied by a band of music, and displaying two handsome banners, representing the two nationalities. The Mayor went out to receive them, and was addressed by the President of the Polish Society, who spoke of the sufferings undergone by the two nations, and the hope of freedom that yet survived among them. Mayor GUNTHER briefly replied, assuring them of his entire sympathy, and his desire to [???] the societies in any way that lay in his power.

abstract: Smith, Goldwin; Life and Works of; Smith, Goldwin; Life and Works of
snippet: Smith, Goldwin; Life and Works of; Smith, Goldwin; Life and Works of
lead_paragraph: The arrival of this distinguished gentleman as a visitor to the United States deserves more than the briet notice which it has as yet received. It is only once or twice, we believe, that a Professor from the University of Oxford has ever cared to visit the country, or inspect the working of the institutions with with which that venerable institution has never been suspected of feeling any special sympathy. Prof. CONYBEARS, a few years since, made, a short tour in this country, but as his sphere was that of natural history, there was no special dishonor or danger incurred by allowing him to cross the Atlantic. Prof. SMITH, however, comes not merely as a guest from Oxford -- a phenomenon sufficiently infrequent and marvelous -- but what is still more rare, as an Oxford Professor, who has been candid and courageous enough to defend the cause of this nation against the force of those anti-American prejudices and associations which are supposed to be most deeply and strongly rooted in the always Tory University.

abstract: HELLER'S SALLE DIABOLIQUE. This neat and brilliant little establishment was reopened for the season Thursday evening, and was graced with an audience numerically strong, and of a quality that gave abundant evidence of the fact that Mr. HELLER'S Salle is regarded as a permanent and acceptable institution.
lead_paragraph: HELLER'S SALLE DIABOLIQUE. This neat and brilliant little establishment was reopened for the season Thursday evening, and was graced with an audience numerically strong, and of a quality that gave abundant evidence of the fact that Mr. HELLER'S Salle is regarded as a permanent and acceptable institution. The hall has been very prettily decorated, and is as bright as a new two-cent piece. Mr. HELLER's programme was almost entirely new, and his execution of the various tricks left nothing whatever to be desired. There is always something more than manual dexterity in these very enjoyable entertainments. Mr. HELLER talks well, and is a tremendous punster. He Knows his audience thoroughly and is never tedious. As a pianist he is admirable. The two solos, which he plays every night, are in themselves an attraction sufficient to bring a large class to his entertainment and to adequately reward the listener. In a word, Heller's Salle Diabolique is admirable, and just the place where young and old may pass a couple of of hours delightfully. Programme No. 3 will be continued until further notice.

abstract: Thanksgiving for Victories
snippet: Thanksgiving for Victories
lead_paragraph: The President calls upon the Nation to celebrate, with pious thanksgiving, the success which has crowned the arms of the Republic. It is customary to say, in reference to the early events of the war, that, with all its terrible train of calamities, the country needed the defeat of Manassas. And, in truth, to a nation, as to an individual, there is something in disastrous fortune of far more worth, if wisely used, than in cheaply earned success, or in a triumph which enervates and intoxicates, while it steals away vigilance and energy. It was the defeat on Lexington Common, which won the American Revolution. It was the victory at Cannae which lost to Hannibal the conquest of Italy. Had we gained Bull Run, we might have patched together a superficial peace, based on profound ignorance of the vital principles at issue, North and South. We never then had evoked the solid and heroic virtues of fortitude, self-denial, fraternal sympathy, glowing patriotism, which now add priceless lustre to the national character. We never then had passed through the purifying furnace, nor tasted the sweet uses of adversity.
headline: {'main': 'Gratitude for Victory The Thanksgiving To-Morrow.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gratitude for Victory The Thanksgiving To-Morrow.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gen. A.J. SMITH'S last expedition into Northern Mississippi and probably it will for a long time be the last into that quarter has terminated by the arrival of the force at Memphis. abstract: New-York; Calcium Light Accident; Inquest on Ellen Meehan
snippet: New-York; Calcium Light Accident; Inquest on Ellen Meehan
lead_paragraph: Coroner RANNEY yesterday afternoon concluded the investigation in the case of ELLEN MEEHAN, the woman who died from injuries received by reason of the explosion of what is popularly known as a calcium light, at Union-square on the evening of the 8th inst., at the McCLELLAN ratification meeting. A sister of the deceased, named MARGARET MEEHAN, was also dangerously injured at the time. She was at once conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where she now lies. No hopes are entertained of her recovery, ELLEN, it will be remembered, died while on the way to the hospital. The testimony of Mr. ROBERT GRANT, who prepared and put into operation the calcium light which exploded, is of considerable interest to the public, and we therefore publish it as follows:

abstract: We learn from the officers of the steamer Mattie, which arrived from White River on Sunday, that the guerrillas in force had made a dash on the Little Rock Railroad, within a mile or two of Duvall's Bluff, and after burning about four or five thousand dollars' worth of feed, tore up the rails and ties for the space of a mile. A force was sent to drive them, but they proving of greater strength than was reported, drove our troops into the fortifications of the Bluff, taking several prisoners, and for two days hovered in the vicinity, alternately threatening and retiring, having also cut the telegraph wire between that point and Little Rock. After the "scare" subsided, some fifteen or twenty rebels came within the lines, and, surrendering, took the oath of amnesty, expressing themselves satisfied that the Confederate cause was "played out." When the Mattie left quiet reigned, though railroad or telegraphic communication with the capital was still impossible. -- Memphis Argus, Sept. 1.
lead_paragraph: We learn from the officers of the steamer Mattie, which arrived from White River on Sunday, that the guerrillas in force had made a dash on the Little Rock Railroad, within a mile or two of Duvall's Bluff, and after burning about four or five thousand dollars' worth of feed, tore up the rails and ties for the space of a mile. abstract: Annual Celebration and History of
snippet: Annual Celebration and History of
lead_paragraph: During the last century the German pedagogues, and after them many public men of other nations, have resumed gymnatics exercises as part of the education of the young, and seeing clearly the truth of the old adage, that in "a strong body lives a strong soul," these exercises have found their way among the grown up; yea, even the old men of Germany. The first step toward this system was taken by the philosopher BASEDOW, who in 1776, in an educational work entitled the "Philantropin," called the attention of the public to this branch of popular education. His ideas were favorably received by the great pedagogue SALZMANN, who introduced the Turner into his educational institute at Schnepfenthal, where JOHN C.F. GUTS MUTHS perfected the plan, and became so enraptured with it that he purchased a country seat, where up to his death in 1839, he had free turn classes for the people. The Turner received its further and most powerful impetus at the hands of FREDRICK LUDWIG JAHN, who well-known as a demagogue all over Germany during the invasion of the French under NAPOLEON, used his political influence for the propagation of this manly art. The popular mind at this time, quite susceptible for anything originally and thoroughly German, gave the new enterprise its support, and in 1830, Mr. JAHN, who had received a tutorship at the Berlin (Kolnischer) College, erected the first public "Turn Anstalt," or gymnasium, and adopted for it the name the exercises now have, "Turner," derived from the old Saxon word, "turn." All sorts of apparatus for the development or the human body were introduced, and it cannot be denied that these exercises, which soon found their way all over Germany, had not a little to do with furnishing good soldiers for the Army of Liberation, which vanquished the French in 1813, '14 and '15. At the close of the war the Turn exercises were again resumed, by order of the Prussian Government, but soon the hostility of the Turners to every false social refinement created many enemies for the new art. KOTZEBUC, WADZECK, and other statesmen of those days, and even METTERNICH, soon found too much feeling for liberty among the Turn Vereine, and commenced to persecute them, but the more vehement these persecutions the greater was the love of the people for them, and especially among the students at the universities of Germany. The "Wartburgfest," on the 18th of October, 1817, the Tercentary of the Reformation, furnished a sufficient ground for official interference, and soon alter JAHN, who had received the cognomen "Vater JAHN," was arrested and incarcerated for five years, by order of the King of Prussia. The Turner, thus effectually squelched, remained dormant for several years, but it revived again, and soon reached a greater perfection by more scientific teachings, as in the Old Country no Turn Vereine is permitted to have any political tendency. These Turn Vereine, however, had considerable influence in the agitations of 1848 and 1849, and many of our own political leaders among the Germans, such as CARL SCHURZ, Gen. WILLICH, FRED. CAPP, and others, received their political education in the Turn Vereine, which, though excluding all political discussion, still always gives its influence to the cause of liberty.

abstract: on the War
snippet: on the War
lead_paragraph: Those who would wish to gather instruction from the observations of a disinterested and distinguished cosmopolite on the philosophy and scope of this rebellion, may find no little gratification in turning to other columns, where there appears a communication from Don RUFINO M. DE ALFARRERO Y CAMPEON. Our correspondent, with courteous deference toward all who may differ from him, ventures the prediction, that the present war will prove to be the revolution of the entire continent, that it will change the system of government now most prevalent in the Western Hemisphere, introducing centralization where diffused sovereignty now prevails, and converting political communities now existing under the form and character of mere "Unions" into defined, compact and consolidated nationalities.

abstract: Losses and Profits of the War
snippet: Losses and Profits of the War
lead_paragraph: We hear every day statements of the losses of property caused by this war, brought forward as a crushing argument in favor of peace. We are told how much the labor of the army would be worth if engaged in peaceful pursuits; how much the national debt present and prospective amounts to; how much has been lost by the high rate of foreign exchange; how much by the depreciation of the currency; how much by the languor and timidity which the political uncertainty imparts to all business operations. A few days ago a Copperhead engaged in a discussion with a Unionist, informed him as a "clincher," that he had just been obliged to transmit nearly $20,000 to Canada in payment of $3,500, under a contract made three years ago. In the presence of this fact, he was satisfied that nothing short of a sudden and violent interposition of Providence could save us from ruin. The war had turned out badly as a speculation, and therefore the sooner we had peace the better.
headline: {'main': 'Profits and Losses of the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Profits and Losses of the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Presbyterian on Rebellion by the Hand of God
snippet: Presbyterian on Rebellion by the Hand of God
lead_paragraph: The Southern Presbylerian, in a recent article, after declaring that the rebellion was brought about by the band of God "in order that the South shall continue unconstrained in its Christian mission as the educator of the black race for time and for eternity," calls loudly upon them to be bold. "This view of the object of the secession of the South," it says, "inspires unfaltering confidence in the final and glorious triumph of Southern arms." And it adds, "Worthy of imitation was the unfaltering confidence of one who laboring alone to further a righteous cause, was ridiculed and contemned. 'Tell me not,' he nobly and triumphantly replied, 'tell me not I am in a hopeless minority; one, with God, is a majority.'"

abstract: A friend was to-day introduced by a McClellanite to a member of the august Democratic conclave, who, supposing him a McClellanite, remarked, "McCLELLAN will carry every State but Massachusetts and Vermont; his prospects are brightening every day." My quizzing friend said, "I presume the capture of Atlanta will help McCLELLAN materielly." Delegate "I don't see how that is going to help him any." Introducer quickly enlightened him he was talking to a Lincolnite.

abstract: We published an official order several weeks since, dismissing from the service Maj. HENRY M. ALLES, Seventy-fourth New-York Volunteers. In consequence of representations made by his superior officer, the case of Maj. ALLES has been reviewed, the order revoked, and he has been honorably discharged. He is now preparing to reenter the service, having been offered a higher rank than that which he previously held.

abstract: -- The Niagara Falls Gazette says: It was prematurely announced a few days ago that our townsman, JOHN T. BUSH, had purchased the Clifton House and the adjoining ZIMMERMAN estate, on the other side of the river. The contract has since been perfected, and Mr. BUSH takes full possession on the 1st of January. The purchase includes over 30 acres of land and several valuable buildings besides the Clifton House.

abstract: London Times on Niagara Conference Plotters; London Times on the Niagara Conferences
snippet: London Times on Niagara Conference Plotters; London Times on the Niagara Conferences
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the ignorance, malignity, and mendacity of the Northern correspondent of the London Times, when speaking of the general military and political affairs of the country, there is no doubt that he is well informed as to the intrigues of the foreign and domestic plotters of the peace and Secession faction. One of his letters, which returned to us by a recent mail, is dated at Niagara Falls, and gives some account of the projects, purposes and opinions of the men who have there been hatching plans -- one portion of them for the destruction of the Union at all hazards, and another portion of them for the success of the Democracy at all hazards. He begins by declaring that the Union has "perished and vanished" -- that the South "will under no circumstances renew the partnership which the sword has cut asunder, and will carry on the war for thirty years, rather than make or listen to any terms that shall not rest upon Southern independence as their basis." After this he goes on to say:

abstract: Georgia, the; Legality of Seizure of
snippet: Georgia, the; Legality of Seizure of
lead_paragraph: The Liverpool Courier and the London Daily News take very different views of the seizure of the ci-devant rebel privateer Georgia. The former avers that it was a gross outrage on the part of the American Commodore, an insult to the British flag, and what not. The latter attempts to demonstrate that it was neither an outrage per se, nor an insult to the British flag, nor aught else that is criminal or abnormal, but an act sanctioned by law, precedent, and the decisions of the ablest jurists. From the facts and arguments adduced by the opposing journals, a very complete history of the case could be made out.
headline: {'main': 'The Seizure of the Georgia Was it Justifiable?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Seizure of the Georgia Was it Justifiable?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Magan >amp; Sons, of $15,000, by D. Duff, Clerk
snippet: Magan >amp; Sons, of $15,000, by D. Duff, Clerk
lead_paragraph: Several days ago a man named DAVID DUFF, who for the last fourteen years has been the confidential clerk of Messrs. M. [???] & SONS, bankers, at No. 37 William-street, suddenly and without notice left his desk in the office, and the fact that he did not return excited the suspicions of his employers. Yesterday morning one of the members of the above-named firm, called at the Bank of America in Wall-street, where they were in the habit of doing business. He there learned that about five minutes before, Mr. DUFF bad been there and drawn from the bank the sum of $15,000, on a check purporting to have been drawn by M. MORGAN & SONS. An examination of the check was then made, when it was found to be a forgery.
headline: {'main': 'Heavy Forgery by a Bank Clerk.; HE OBTAINS $15,000 ON A FORGED CHECK ARREST OF THE CLERK AND THE RECOVERY OF THE MONEY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Heavy Forgery by a Bank Clerk.; HE OBTAINS $15,000 ON A FORGED CHECK ARREST OF THE CLERK AND THE RECOVERY OF THE MONEY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The funeral of the late Capt. E.P. BROWNSON, Aid-de-Camp to Gen. HANCOCK, and Commissary of Musters, Second Corps, Army of the Potomac, took place from the residence of his father, Dr. O.A. BROWNSON, Elizabeth, on Monday morning last. The remains were taken to St. Mary's Church, Elizabeth, where a Solemn Mass of Requiem was celebrated for the repose of his soul. An eloquent and appropriate sermon was delivered by Rev. Father HEWIT. Gen. HAYES and his Staff were present, and accompanied the remains to this city, where they were interred in the burial-ground connected with the Cathedral. -- Newark Advertiser, Sept. 8.

abstract: A gentleman named H. NICHOLS, while walking in Fifty-first-street, near Second-avenue on Friday evening, was assaulted and knocked down by two men. While he was lying on the walk, the men robbed him of his gold watch and $278 in money, with which they made their escape. Mr. NICHOLS states that one of them was stout built, had dark hair, whiskers and mustache. The other one was quite tall, wore a white hat and dark clothes. The Nineteenth Precinct Police are making efforts to secure the robbers. Mr. NICHOLS thinks he can readily identity them.

abstract: A shooting a[???]ray occurred in the dining saloon No. 345 Grand-street, about 7 o'clock last evening, between a man named LUKE LACKEY and some parties as yet unknown. LACKEY, becoming excited, drew a revolver and fired at random into the crowd. The shot took effect in the left shoulder of a young man named PETER JOBES, who was eating his supper. LACKEY was arrested by Capt. DAVIS, of the Tenth Police. Dr. PURDY dressed the wound and the young man was taken home.

abstract: Armistice on and Seddon's Report
snippet: Armistice on and Seddon's Report
lead_paragraph: Among the generalities which make up McCLELLAN'S letter of acceptance, there is one point which looms into view with sufficient distinctness; and we venture to say it is the only point on which JEFFERSON DAVIS and his emissaries had any doubt as to MCCLELLAN's elegibility. He will grant the conspirators an armistice. And an armistice granted under any pretence or plea -- we care not what it is -- will be worth to the Confederacy more than 100,000 armed and disciplined soldiers before the 4th of March next.

abstract: Surgeon RICHARD S. SATTERLEE, Medical Purveyor United States Army, who ranked as Major, has received the successive brevets of LieutenantColonel, Colonel, and finally Brigadier-General, the latter dating from Sept. 2. The gratifying honors are bestowed, as is officially stated, "for diligent care and attention in procuring proper army supplies, as Medical Purveyor, and for economy and fidelity in the disbursement of large sums of money."

abstract: The Academy of Music reopens for a brief series of operatic performances, to-night, under the direction of Mr. LEONARD GROVER, of Philadelphia. The announcement will be found in another column, and we direct attention to it as a fine specimen of what may be called the evasive style of composition.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music reopens for a brief series of operatic performances, to-night, under the direction of Mr. LEONARD GROVER, of Philadelphia. The announcement will be found in another column, and we direct attention to it as a fine specimen of what may be called the evasive style of composition. It will be seen that Mr. GROVER carefully avoids any reference to the nationality of the company. The reader pauses in vain to discover if the artist contemplates singing in Italian, French, German or English. There is treasonable prospect, to be sure, that the latter tongue will be spared, for the quantity at the command of the director does not appear to be extensive. But why endeavor to confuse people, and what necessity is there to be ashamed of the title of German opera? It is a paltry pride that blushes at its own necessities, and something worse, that by suppression would imply an untruth. Fortunately, however, no one will be deceived by the vagueness of Mr. GROVER's announcement. The "inaugural season of grand opera" means twelve nights here and in Brooklyn of German opera. Monsieur FRANK HIMMER, (why not FRANCOIS?) means our old friend Herr HIMMER, and Mademoiselle MARIE FREDERICI means that tenor's charming wife. Those portly Teutons, the Herr HERMAN and STEINECKE are also furnished, with dapper Gallic prefixes to their names. The first-named gentleman in addition is crushed beneath an inexplicable weight of eulogy conveyed in such a junkey shape that it must astonish him as much as it has astonished the public. Here it is:

abstract: Shortly before 3 o'clock on Sunday morning two persons, named JOHN QUINN and MARTIN CHURCHILL, became involved in a quarrel at the house No. 205 William-street, during which the latter alleges that JOHN QUINN drew a revolver and fired at him, fortunately without doing any great harm. The Fourth Precinct Police were soon on the spot, and QUINN was arrested. Yesterday he was taken before Justice DOWLING at the Tombs, where he was confronted by CHURCHILL, who made an affidavit in which he stated that JOHN QUINN had shot at him with a revolver, with the design of taking his life. JOHN was on the point of being committed on the charge of attempting to commit murder, when a man came forward and offered himself as a witness. He said his name was DANIEL QUINN, a brother to the accused. The magistrate admitted him as a witness, and he swore positively that he was present during the whole quarrel, saw the whole of it, and that JOHN QUINN did not fire the pistol. When asked who did it, he hesitated. Upon being closely pressed for an answer, he suggested that he was not bound to criminate himself. The Justice of course admitted the soundness of that doctrine as a principle of law, but at the same time reminded the witness that he must remember the peculiar and unusual manner in which he had forced himself before the court as a witness, and that the object of the magistrate was to ascertain, if possible, who had been guilty of the heinous offence charged by Mr. CHURCHILL DANIEL was furthermore informed that, having volunteered as a witness, and been accepted as such, he was bound to divulge the whole truth, or go to prison. The witness then stated that he fired the pistol at Mr. CHURCHILL, but said he did it in self-defence. DANIEL was therefore locked up, and the original prisoner, JOHN, was discharged. There is no affidavit against DANIEL, however, and he will doubtless be discharged to-day.

abstract: The latest intelligence from the Army of the potomac, is that on Friday the batteries on the right and centre of our lines kept up a lively fire at intervals through the day. The enemy, attracted by the noise made by the cars as they passed toward the front, endeavored without...
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from the Army of the potomac, is that on Friday the batteries on the right and centre of our lines kept up a lively fire at intervals through the day. The enemy, attracted by the noise made by the cars as they passed toward the front, endeavored without success to interrupt the operations of the road. The rebel picket line just west of the Jerusalem plank road, was attacked on Friday night by the Second Division, and nearly the whole line captured. The movement was a complete surprise to the rebels, who made vigorous but unsuccessful efforts to regain the lost ground. Fifteen hundred will cover, it is reported, our losses from all causes during last week.

abstract: Beside the enjoyment, long denied me, of spending a cool and pleasant Summer and Autumn in a Northern State, I have had the grateful task imposed upon me of engaging in the political campaign. For the last three weeks the State has been literally in a blaze of excitement. Meetings have been held everywhere, in every county, village and hamlet. The Union men have been much more active than the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: The Boston Traveller says: "If the Gloucester fishermen are not disturbed by pirates or privateers this year, they will enjoy a season of unparalleled prosperity. All of the vessels are coming home with full fares, and the mackerel are bringing great prices and meet with a brisk demand. More than two hundred fine schooners are at the bay of St. Lawrence, and will probably land at Gloucester before Thanksgiving sixty thousand barrels of mackerel, worth more than one million of dollars. The total receipts for sale of codfish, mackerel, oil and other products of the fisheries of Gloucester this year, must nearly reach three millions of dollars.

abstract: The Threatened Bolt
snippet: The Threatened Bolt
lead_paragraph: It would seem at this moment that there is likely to be something like a bolt from the support of the Chicago nominees by the extreme left wing of the Copperhead peace faction. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM delivered a speech at Dayton, Ohio, on Wednesday last, supporting the Chicago platform and nominee; but two days after, while at Columbus, on his way East to continue his electioneering speeches, he got a copy of Gen. MCCLELLAN's letter of acceptance. Upon reading it, according to a telegram which we are assured is accurate, he at once authorized the withdrawal of his name from the appointments in Ohio, and returned home -- the dispatch adding to this announcement that the "peace men have determined to maintain their integrity, and will soon call a meeting to determine their course of action." On Wednesday, he declared that until the great work of the political campaign was accomplished, "every day, every hour of his existence, every thought, all that was dearest to him, should be yielded up cheerfully and freely, until upon the 8th of November, or the morning of the 9th, when the sun shall rise to record a country about to be redeemed, regenerated, and disenthralled." Thus he faced on Wednesday, but in forty-eight hours after he appeared to be facing in an opposite direction. This from the author and writer of the Chicago platform -- from the member who moved in the convention that MCCLELLAN's nomination be made unanimous -- from the orator who at once took the stump for the nominee, and declared that "there was not a man in America more fit for the choice -- that there was not a man whose "personal character, whose morality, whose attachments to the principles, and whose obedience to the precepts of Christianity -- a man whose devotion to his country -- a man who in every sense of the word is a gentleman -- I say there is not a man in any respect above or beyond Gen. MCCLELLAN" -- such action, we remark, from the representative chief of the Copperheads looked at first blush rather ominous.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths last week was 170, of which 19 were men, 20 women, 64 boys, and 67 girls. The principal causes were: Cholera infantum, 30; marasmus, 28; convulsions, 17; consumption, 16; inflammation of brain, 9; diarrhoea, 6; diptheria. 5; dysentery and whooping cough, 4 each; scarlet fever, 2; croup, 2, &c., &c. Under one year of age, 50. Natives of the United States, 130; Ireland, 26; England, 2; Germany, 1; unknown, 3; British America, 2.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths last week was 170, of which 19 were men, 20 women, 64 boys, and 67 girls. The principal causes were: Cholera infantum, 30; marasmus, 28; convulsions, 17; consumption, 16; inflammation of brain, 9; diarrhoea, 6; diptheria. 5; dysentery and whooping cough, 4 each; scarlet fever, 2; croup, 2, &c., &c. Under one year of age, 50. Natives of the United States, 130; Ireland, 26; England, 2; Germany, 1; unknown, 3; British America, 2.

abstract: on Hand to Save the Union
snippet: on Hand to Save the Union
lead_paragraph: -- "Nothing," says Gen. WOOL, "for aught that I can discover, will save the Union and its Government but the successes of GRANT, SHERMAN, FARRAGUT, and SHERIDAN." These are perfectly true words; and therefore the chief duty of all who desire to save the Union is to fill up the ranks of the army which marches to its glorious work under these eminent soldiers.

abstract: On Saturday right a young man named THOMAS A. TAYLOR, of No. 283 Greenwich-street, was riding on the front platform of an Eighth-avenue car, when he observed three men enter the vehicle. They rode about three blocks up the avenue, when one of them rudely pushed against TAYLOR, and immediately jumped off the car. TAYLOR at once discovered that his watch had been stolen, and jumping from the car pursued the man whom he supposed had taken it. After running some distance he overtook and seized the thief by the neck, where upon the latter turned, drew a pistol, and shot TAYLOR in the forehead, just above the nose Fortunately the wound received is not fatal, the ball passed upward and produced only a flesh wound. The thief made his escape. The Ninth Precinct Police have a description of him in full, and be will doubtless be taken into custody.

abstract: Recruiting of
snippet: Recruiting of
lead_paragraph: -- When the last call of the President for troops was made, there was a general impression prevalent in many of the States -- and this State among the rest -- that they could fill up their quotas by sending agents off to the Southwest and enlisting negroes. We corrected this notion at the time by means of facts and authentic documents in our possession. It has been pretty effectually corrected by the very small success of the agents that were actually sent out on this work by some of the States. Gen. SHERMAN, who has penetrated further into the slave country than any other of our soldiers, also gave his views to the same purpose, in a letter we published some time ago, and he gave his opinion again a few days since, in a conversation with an agent for the recruitment of negroes, who called upon him. Gen. SHERMAN, according to the report of this agent, said that he had repeatedly written to the Secretary of War that there were no able-bodied men in the Southwest who were not either in his army or the other; that the rebels had swept every able-bodied nigger before them, and taken them down into the corn-growing regions of Georgia; and that he "would agree to eat every nigger the agent could recruit without salt." He furthermore applied a little Attic salt to this agent by informing him that when there were enough recruiting agents down there he would organize them into a regiment -- he had no doubt they were loyal men -- and put them in front to fight the enemy.

abstract: Did he Accept the Platform; did not Train with Peace Democrats
snippet: Did he Accept the Platform; did not Train with Peace Democrats
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN's letter of acceptance is essentially a dishonest document, intended to obtain votes on false pretences. The main question at issue before the people of these United States at the coming election is not whether peace is desirable. All agree that it is. It is not whether the "resources of statesmanship" should be employed to obtain it. All agree that they should be employed in their proper place. The question at issue is -- What shall be done with the war? shall it be prosecuted with vigor, or checked in its course? The Democratic party at Chicago declared that the latter course was the proper one. They declared that "Justice, humanity, liberty and the public welfare demand that immedaite efforts be made for a cessation of hostilities." Perhaps we should hardly admit that Copperheads demand what is demanded by justice, liberty, humanity and the public welfare, but Democrats could not claim that they did not demand what they say is thus demanded. Nor can they deny that they demand a cessation of hostilities when they demand that immediate efforts be made to obtain one. This platform was not approved by many men who have heretofore been called Democrats. They agreed with Gen. DIX, that putting down the rebellion was to be effected "by a steady and unwavering prosecution of the war." And no man can honestly hold this opinion and accept the Chicago platform.
