abstract: A table giving a list of one hundred and two Oil Companies, with a capital stock, the number of sharps, the prices asked and bid and the dividends declared, is publishedin the Philadelphia Commercial List and Price Current. The nominal capital of these companies exceeds $52,000,000! Of the whole number of companies only twenty-four have declared dividends. The Commercial List, which has devoted much attentionto oil matters and is good authority on the subject, also gives a list of the off refineries in Pittsburgh, their capacity and owners' names; likewise a list of all the oil companies of Philadelphia, location of office end name of President and Secretary, similar in style to the table of Mining Companies given some time since in the Commercial Bulletin. The Commercial List also gives a description of a few of the companies who peremptorily refuse to inform the public of what their assets consist. and are therefore set down as worthless. The exitement in these stocks lately, so well as the sales, have been unprecedented. The excitement runs high all through the oil region, parcels of real estates frequently changinghands at a high valuation; but in the estimation of those concerned all this is only a faint premonition of what is to come. The preserve production of oil is estimated at 6,000 barrels per day, and from present appearances the large number of new wells going into operation will enhance materially this aggregate.

abstract: -- A strong effort was made to induce Gen. JOHN A. LOGAN, of Illinois, to accept the nomination for Vice-President on the Copperhead ticket. JOHN B. HASKIN, ex-member of Congress from New-York, and a personal friend of LOGAN, wrote him, some weeks ago, an urgent letter to allow his name to go before the convention for Vice-President. Several other prominent politicians wrote him on the subject. HASKIN sent him a second letter stronger, if possible, in language than the first one, beseeching him to be a candidate, and assuring him of the party support of the New-York and other Eastern delegates. Gen. LOGAN unqualifiedly refused. He told those gentlemen that he did not train with that crowd; that he was a War Democrat -- not a Peace sneak; that he was opposed to bowing down and supplicating for forgiveness at the feet of JEFF DAVIS; that he was for an honorable, permanent peace, which could only be obtained by overthrowing armed rebellion, and compelling the insurgents to yield obedience to the Constitution and the laws, and that he would never consent to make peace on any terms that did not embrace a complete restoration of the Union, in all of its territorial integrity. -- Chicago Tribune.

abstract: Military Career of; on McClellan and Saving the Country
snippet: Military Career of; on McClellan and Saving the Country
lead_paragraph: When Gen. SCOTT retired from his military position, his successor was appointed without any of those contentious wranglings which so often attend high military preferment. With the disinterestedness that has characterized every act of the present Executive, he was selected from a remnant of the only pofaction which showed any signs of opposition. We doubt whether history records another appointment, at once so important and enviable, and so unanimously sustained, as that so magnanimously proffered by Government to Gen. MCCLELLAN.

All the quid nuncs and everybody else were on the qui vive, as to who could be the distinguished stranger. One rather nervous and excited young gentleman with fair hair and large eyes, was heard to say that the new-comer war, at the very least, a rebel Major-General in disguise. The entrance of his name on the book was the signal for a general rush to the clerk's desk.

abstract: and Our Successes
snippet: and Our Successes
lead_paragraph: Well, God was thanked yesterday in our churches according to proclamation, and sincerely we doubt not. But is that all? The most heroic character in Scripture we think did something more. He "thanked God and took courage." We take it, that one is as much a duty as the other, or rather that if the one is thoroughly performed the other is a sure consequence. Is it so with us? Has our thankfulness for our recent successes braced up our souls? That is the practical point, for it is the point which concerns not the past but the future.

A great panic ensued among the tenants, who, it seems, were taken entirely by surprise, and, for a...
lead_paragraph: UNSAFE BUILDING IN CENTRE STREET -- THE WALL OF A TENEMENT HOUSE CAVED IN. -- Between eight and nine o'clock yesterday morning the rear wall of the three-story tenement house, No. 76 Centre-street, corner of Worth, fell in with a loud crash. A great panic ensued among the tenants, who, it seems, were taken entirely by surprise, and, for a time, owing to the great confusion, it was supposed that some persons had lost their lives. Information was immediately sent to the Sixth Precinct Station-house, and Capt. JOURDON, with a squad of men, went to the place. Upon examination it was found that no one had received serious injuries. Capt. JOURDON, seeing that the wall on the Worth-street side was much sprung and cracked, and in such condition that it might fall at any moment, therefore stationed a number of men near the building to prevent people from endangering their lives. The tenants occupying that portion of the house near the defective walls have been compelled to abandon their apartments. Capt. JOURDON has notified the Inspector of Unsafe Buildings, and it is thought it will be necessary to demolish the entire structure. It is owned by Mr. HORACE F. CLARK.

abstract: Georgia the, and the British Press
snippet: Georgia the, and the British Press
lead_paragraph: It is creditable to the British press that, with two or three exceptions, it has been disposed to view the seizure of the Georgia as a case not properly referable to diplomatic treatment, but as one which an ordinary prize court will make a proper disposition of. The exceptions to this common-sense view of the matter are barely worth naming. The London Shipping Gazette is one of them. But that journal, on international questions generally, has ceased to be the organ of any interest outside of Mr. W.S. LINDSAY's particular clique, and its opinions, both at home and abroad, have come to be valued accordingly.

abstract: Capture of Atlanta, and Washington Intelligencer
snippet: Capture of Atlanta, and Washington Intelligencer
lead_paragraph: It ill accords with the party exigencies of the Opposition to be driven to the admission, that the capture of Atlanta by SHERMAN, with a loss of only fifteen hundred men, is a great national victory. To qualify it, a Copperhead sheet reproduces with much satisfaction the statement of some nameless correspondent, to the effect that military critics are puzzled to know why HOOD was allowed to escape by a Southern route, entirely unmolested.

abstract: The satisfaction with which we read that two noted blockade-runners, the Elsie and the Lord Clyde, have been captured within the past week, is sadly marred by the news that the Tallahassee was to leave Wilmington on Tuesday, (to-night,) that another blockade-runner, the Edith, converted into a privateer, is almost ready to follow the Tallahassee on the same errand, and that a dozen or more blockade-runners are in Halifax harbor, some of them bound for British ports with valuable cargoes of cotton.

abstract: The Germans in this City and vicinity are very indignant at the action of Superintendent KENNEDY, in forbidding the performance of the Oratorio of the...
lead_paragraph: -- The Germans in this City and vicinity are very indignant at the action of Superintendent KENNEDY, in forbidding the performance of the Oratorio of the "Creation" at Jones' Wood, on Sunday; and it is said that, but for the timely interposition of rain on that day, they would have endeavored to carry out their programme, at the risk of provoking a collision with the police. Sober second thought will probably teach them that the storm was their best friend on this occasion, and that they would better leave the correction of whatever grievance they may have suffered to the courts. It is understood that the Superintendent had no objection to the performance of the Oratorio itself, but to several pieces of operatic music, and other accessions, which brought the performance under the ban of the statute prohibiting theatrical performances on Sunday; and if it be true, as reported, that discharges of cannon were to form a prominent feature of the performance, this would have been in violation of a statute expressly forbidding the firing of cannon, guns or pistols, in any park or other public grounds within the City limits on Sunday. The proposed concert was not a charity, it was a money-making project, and Superintendent KENNEDY probably felt that while a law existed against opening th theatres on Sunday, it would be unjust to have an operatic performance in Jones Wood.

abstract: By the arrival of the America, at this port yesterday, from Southampton, we have advices to the 31st of August. The London Times, discussing American affairs, says that nothing is so evident as the incapacity of either belligerent to...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the America, at this port yesterday, from Southampton, we have advices to the 31st of August. The London Times, discussing American affairs, says that nothing is so evident as the incapacity of either belligerent to prevail against the other. This is pleasant reading, in the light of our recent successes, especially as the Times announces that HOOD is rather gaining than losing at Atlanta. The seizure of the Georgia is still discussed by the English press, but no new facts have been thus far developed. The matrimonial alliance between Prince HUMBERT and a daughter of Prince MUHAT appears to have fallen to the ground. No progress has been made in adjusting the Danish question. Revolutionary movements are feared in Venetia, and several persons have been arrested by the authorities. The disturbances in Tunis have been mainly quelled. Senor FRAZIO, the representative of the Emperor of Mexico to Spain, has arrived at Madrid.

abstract: New-York and Paris
snippet: New-York and Paris
lead_paragraph: In one of the most important reforms of the present day -- the improvement of the homes of laboring people -- New-York is very far behind some of the cities of the Old World. In London and Paris especially, movements in behalf of comfortable dwellings for working people have been in progress for years, and have been attended with marked success. On his accession to power the present Emperor of France found the laboring population of his capital living in vile, narrow lanes and alleys, which it were an unconscionable stretch of courtesy to call streets, from which huge piles of buildings, in every stage of ruin and decay, shut out the light and breath of Heaven, and where every form imaginable of uncleanness, vice, disease and wretchedness held carnival. One of his earliest measures of policy was to cut magnificent channels for light and air through the most infected districts. The downfall of the huge, unwholesome piles was immediately decreed. Narrow and tortuous alleys were widened and straightened into handsome streets, adorned by the elegance and convenience of modern structures; and in the course of ten years Paris was transformed from one of the most unsightly into the most beautiful city of modern Europe. The whole population gained by the change; but by far the greatest gainers were the working people. Instead of living in vile rookeries and kennels, breathing an atmosphere laden with poisonous exhalations, the majority of the working classes of Paris can now find pleasant, convenient homes on clean and roomy streets, which leave very little to be desired in the way of light and air. Of course, in so large a city as Paris a complete reformation of this character cannot be accomplished in the short sp[???]ce of ten years; much still remains to be done; but if the work of renovation goes on as rapidly in the future as it has hitherto, we venture to say that ten years from now there will not be an unsightly lane in Paris, or one where a working man cannot find a cheerful and comfortable home. Contrast this rapid progress of improvement with the state of things in the largest, wealthiest and fastest City of the New World. Here in New-York, the condition of the dwellings provided for our laboring population appears to be going on from bad to worse. In another column will be found some facts bearing on the past and present state of the tenement and lodging houses of this City, which prove this to be the case, and which show that nearly, if not quite, two-thirds of our entire population are perhaps the worst-lodged people in the civilized world.
headline: {'main': 'Houses for Workingmen New-York and Paris Contrasted.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Houses for Workingmen New-York and Paris Contrasted.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Three valuable blockade-runners have just been caught. The British steamer Elsie, which was captured on the 5th by the gunboats Quaker City and Keystone State, arrived here yesterday, on her way to Boston. She had on board 320 bales of cotton. On the 9th inst. the prize steamer Georgia arrived at Beaufort, N.C., and would also proceed to Boston. She was cotten-laden.
lead_paragraph: Three valuable blockade-runners have just been caught. The British steamer Elsie, which was captured on the 5th by the gunboats Quaker City and Keystone State, arrived here yesterday, on her way to Boston. She had on board 320 bales of cotton. On the 9th inst. the prize steamer Georgia arrived at Beaufort, N.C., and would also proceed to Boston. She was cotten-laden. On the 11th inst. the U.S. steamer Santiago de Cuba chased and captured the steamer A.D. Vance, one of the most notorious of the blockade-runners. She had a cargo of over 400 bales of cotton. A dispatch from Halifax, dated yesterday, announces the arrival there on Saturday and Sunday of the blockade-runners Old Dominion and the City of Petersburgh. They have about 1,800 bales of cotton on board, destined for England, said to be in payment of the interest for the rebel loan. They left Wilmington last Monday night, 5th inst. They report that the pirate Tallahassee was to leave on a piratical plundering cruise on Tuesday night.

abstract: Houses of our Laboring Population
snippet: Houses of our Laboring Population
lead_paragraph: The reports made to the Citizens' Association by the Council of Hygiene upon the condition of the tenement houses occupied by full two-thirds of our population, should awaken the public to a sense of the dangers that threaten the City from this quarter. The truth of these reports is unimpeachable. Under the direction of the Council a thorough and very systematic survey has been made, or is in progress, of every street in the city -- and not by any means a sham survey. There is no outside show about it. It is not an easy and luxurious ride in carriages through streets where everything has been swept and garnished for the occasion, but a downright, honest inspection of every street, every block, and, in many wards, of every house. The facts developed by this thorough inspection are of the most alarming character, and demand the prompt attention of the municipal authorities and of private citizens of wealth and influence.

snippet: Union Course; Shot,Cardinal, >amp;c; Trot; New-York vs Newark, single wicket
lead_paragraph: The Fall meeting of the Passaic County Association commences to-day under the most favorable suspices, and with every prospect of the most brilliant results in the magnitude and quality of the attendance, and the affluent character of the racing. Having given previously, in extenso, a full description of the several stakes open to contest during the three days to which the meeting extends, it only remains for us to add that up to a late hour yesterday all the horses were well, and each owner, as a matter of course, equally confident of success. There is a train from the foot of Chambers-street at 8 o'clock A.M. The special train with ladies' cars leaves at 11 1/2 A.M., but those who desire to be in season, go comfortable, and avoid the crowd, will do well to take the 10 A.M. train, which will take them bright and early direct to the course, and enable its patrons to examine the horses and be posted in their market prices long prior to the starting hour.

abstract: LOST. -- During Sunday last the store of CHAS. W. BAKER, No. 29 Beekman-street, was entered by very skillful burglars, and the two safes, made by MARVIN & CO., No. 265 Broadway, were tested most severely, both with drills and chisels, and then charged with powder, but yet were not opened. The large number of holes and their localities, show that the operators were not only industrious, but that they understood their business. One or the safes had over $3,000, and the larger one over $80,000 in revenue stamps. We understand that Mr. BAKER's books have been preserved twice from fire in MARVIN's safes, and now he has good reason to congratulate both himself and them on their security.

abstract: Smith, Prof Goldwin; Opinions of
snippet: Smith, Prof Goldwin; Opinions of
lead_paragraph: Whatever difference of opinion English journalists may have held respecting the political views entertained and avowed by Mr. GOLDWIN SMITH, we are safe in saying that, until his arrival here, no one of his intelligent countrymen ever accused him of seeking to win applause by flattering the United States and depreciating Great Britain. This charge it has been left for an obscure British organ on this side of the Atlantic to invent and propagate. The essays on the colonial connection by which Mr. SMITH was first known as a political thinker, are characterized by a more rational apprecition of the just relation of the Imperial Government toward the dependencies than can perhaps be imputed to any ether living Englishman, with the exception of Lord GREY. And his loyalty to his country and to his country's interests will at least bear comparison -- even if it is not so loudly and offensively asserted -- with that of his maligners here, who envy the respect which his name and character inspire.

The promises have all been realized." It seems the martyr was a little too fast. He finds that the promises have not all been realized; and on seeing McCLELLAN'S letter of acceptance, he discards him on the instant.

abstract: Should he Resign his CommisIion
snippet: Should he Resign his CommisIion
lead_paragraph: It seems to be generally expected that Gen. MCCLELLAN will resign his commission as Major-General, and rumors are afloat that he has resigned it. We confess, however, that we do not see that he is called upon to do so on public grounds. If he is eligible for election while holding his rank in the army, it is hard to see what injury it can do to the country to hold it until he is elected. If it be, as we believe, an unwise thing to adopt the practice of placing soldiers in the highest office in the State, and the people think so, he will not be elected; if the people do not see it in this light, and do not object to him on other grounds, he will be elected. His resignation would not mend matters, for he would be as much a soldier after it as before. Taking off a man's epaulets does not change his habits, character, training or mode of thinking, and Mr. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN would possess precisely the same virtues and defects as Maj.-Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN.

abstract: and the Charleston Press; Charleston Press and an Armistice
snippet: and the Charleston Press; Charleston Press and an Armistice
lead_paragraph: From a file of late Southern journals, received direct from Charleston, we gather not a little of what ought to interest those who have faith in the ameliorating influence which a suspension of hostilities is to exercise on the alienated heart of the South. The Charleston Mercury boasts loudly that "every paper of the Confederacy, with one accord, advise and urge the instant and emphatic rejection of a proposition for an armistice." The reasons advanced to support this high-spirited resolution are rather singular, it is true, but such as they are, we do well to make a note of them. The Mercury tells its readers that a pause in the conflict would redound more to the credit of the President of the United States than to the cause of the Confederacy, since "SHERMAN is at a stand. "If," continues the Mercury, "he is forced to retreat, there is no doubt before he has proceeded far on the road to Chattanooga his army, pressed by the gallant spirits under HOOD, will be demoralized, routed, cut to pieces, scattered, if not utterly destroyed!" Putting the case in its own hypothetical way, the Mercury's view is a very logical one. An army "cut to pieces," "routed" and "scattered" will come very near being "utterly destroyed." And the case is further argued with equal pertinence when the Mercury concludes that an army thus demolished might profit by a ninety days' armistice. The only weak point in the whole argument is that it happened to be the army of HOOD that was "scattered," "demoralized" and "routed." The Mercury's hypothesis was stated two days after Atlanta had been evacuated by HOOD; but it would perhaps have been a reflection on the spirit of Southern journalism to allow such a small matter as the defeat of HOOD to disturb a train of reasoning so perfect in all its parts as that which we have noted.
headline: {'main': 'The Charleston Press and an Armistice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Charleston Press and an Armistice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mexican Empire, Troubles of
snippet: Mexican Empire, Troubles of
lead_paragraph: The difficulties of MAXIMILIAN'S reign accumulate much faster, we fear, than the ill-advised Prince had bargained for. The news which we publish from Mexico, this morning, brings into strong relief the more immediate sources of trouble which surround the throne and its inexperienced occupant. The Emperor of the French presses for the release of his janissaries, at a rate which does not comport with the Emperor MAXIMILIAN'S views of the public weal or of his own personal safety. The Imperial Mexican army proper, apart from the French, amounts practically to nothing. All the victories that have been of any account to the Imperial arms are now credited to the French. The native Mexican who swears allegiance to the Empire is a miserable failure in the field, fighting either against the native guerrillas or the regular forces of JUAREZ.
headline: {'main': 'The Troubles of the New Mexican Empire.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Troubles of the New Mexican Empire.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A scene more characteristic of the German character than that which was seen on Monday morning in Orchard-street, in front of the Turn Halle, one rarely meets in this great City. The weather was gloomy, and a fine drizzling rain kept the streets in that state so well known to New-Yorkers, but nothing daunted, the Germans of this and the adjoining cities, were out in force to do honor to their visitors from all parts of this vast continent who were to be entertained with a grand excursion and pic-nic at Jones' Wood.

abstract: Intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army, before Petersburgh, assures us that vigorous preparations are going forward for dealing the rebellion a decisive blow. The Richmond Examiner, of the 9th, says: "GRANT has massed a great many troops on the railroad, two miles south of Petersburgh, and has, within the last ten days, pushed his left a quarter of a mile across to the west of the railroad. He will, at an early day, make a grand burst, and try to reach the Southside Railroad at some point near the town. This is to be his next grand movement."

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr. GROVER's inaugural season at the Academy of Music opened Monday night, with so generous an attendance on the part of the public, that it left nothing to be desired except better accommodation at the doors. In building the Academy, provision was made for the extraordinary "rushes" which sometimes occur -- only too seldom, we are sorry to say. There are plenty of doors for entering and leaving the house, but, by a strange perversity, which we hope to see corrected, theyare generally closed when the public demands that they should be open. Mr. GROVER is an experienced manager, and will undoubtedly profit by the lesson of his extraordinarily successful first night.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- Mr. GROVER's inaugural season at the Academy of Music opened Monday night, with so generous an attendance on the part of the public, that it left nothing to be desired except better accommodation at the doors. In building the Academy, provision was made for the extraordinary "rushes" which sometimes occur -- only too seldom, we are sorry to say. There are plenty of doors for entering and leaving the house, but, by a strange perversity, which we hope to see corrected, theyare generally closed when the public demands that they should be open. Mr. GROVER is an experienced manager, and will undoubtedly profit by the lesson of his extraordinarily successful first night.

abstract: PARK BENJAMIN, the well-known lecturer and poet, died Monday evening at his residence in this City, after a brief illness. He was of Welsh cescent, and was born at Demerara, British Guiana, on the 14th of August, 1818, and was 55 years old at the time of his death. An illness in childhood improperly treated caused him a permanent lameness, and he was sent to his father's home in New-England for medical advice and to be educated. He studied two years at Harvard College, graduated at Trinity College, Hartford, in 1829, began to practice law in Boston in 1832, and was one of the original editors of the New-England Magazine. In 1837 he removed to New-York, edited, in connection with C.F. HOFFMAN, the American Monthly Magazine, and subsequently was associated with HORACE GREELEY in editing the New-Yorker. He was next engaged, in connection with EPES SARGENT and RUFUS W. GRISWOLD, as editor of the World New, a cheap weekly periodical, which republished the best articles of English magazine literature, and received original contributions from many spirited writers. After five years he sold his interest in this journal, and has since appeared frequently before the public as a lecturer both in prose and verse. His poems, which embrace many popular lyrical and satirical pieces, have never been collected, but are found scattered through the recent periodical literature of the country.
lead_paragraph: PARK BENJAMIN, the well-known lecturer and poet, died Monday evening at his residence in this City, after a brief illness. He was of Welsh cescent, and was born at Demerara, British Guiana, on the 14th of August, 1818, and was 55 years old at the time of his death. An illness in childhood improperly treated caused him a permanent lameness, and he was sent to his father's home in New-England for medical advice and to be educated. He studied two years at Harvard College, graduated at Trinity College, Hartford, in 1829, began to practice law in Boston in 1832, and was one of the original editors of the New-England Magazine. In 1837 he removed to New-York, edited, in connection with C.F. HOFFMAN, the American Monthly Magazine, and subsequently was associated with HORACE GREELEY in editing the New-Yorker. He was next engaged, in connection with EPES SARGENT and RUFUS W. GRISWOLD, as editor of the World New, a cheap weekly periodical, which republished the best articles of English magazine literature, and received original contributions from many spirited writers. After five years he sold his interest in this journal, and has since appeared frequently before the public as a lecturer both in prose and verse. His poems, which embrace many popular lyrical and satirical pieces, have never been collected, but are found scattered through the recent periodical literature of the country.

abstract: On Monday evening a number of gentlemen of this City, held a preliminary meeting for the purpose of taking measures to organize in New-York a Canadian Society, on a plan similar to that of St. George's and St. Andrew's. A line of action designed to bring together and form into a body the Canadians of the City whose association would conduce to the ends in view, was decided on; there was entire unanimity as to the main principles on which the society should be formed; and a circular, embodying the sense of the meeting, was drawn up and adopted. This document sets forth the reasons which induced the movement; explains the wants and views of the Canadians, gives some details as to the proposed organization, and explains the main objects of the society, which have already been alluded to. The circular will soon be issued.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Roanoke at this port yesterday, we have late news from Mexico and St. Domingo. Gen. MEJIA had entered Victoria City, and was reported to be marching on Matamoras. It is said that Gen. CASTAGNY had defeated a force of Juarists near Saltillo, but lost among other officers, his Chief of Artillery. The Mexican vessels Librador and Mericano, from Mazatlan, were captured by the Diamant, and sent to Acapulco. It is reported that the Russian fleet in the Pacific has received orders to rendezvous at Acapulco and salute the new Mexican flag. The Spaniards appear to be making but little headway in St. Domingo. They do not hold a single point more than ten miles from the coast, and several detachments sent into the interior have recently been defeated by the rebels. A cargo of slaves has been successfully landed near Remedios.

lead_paragraph: On Tuesday of last week the World had an editorial on the September elections, in which it gave the figures of the vote in Vermont and Maine last year, and closed with the words, "These figures will be whittled down terribly next week. Mark the prediction." We, in our turn, recommend to the World not only to "mark" but to "inwardly digest" it, unless it finds the process too difficult.

snippet: on Emigration and Labor in New-York; State Elections, Significance of
lead_paragraph: For five months there had been no State elections previous to those which have just occurred in Vermont and Maine. The popular sentiment had nowhere been tested on any scale at all significant. Five months is a long period in a national crisis like this.; and the strength of the war feeling last Spring could be no guarantee of its present control. Two great campaigns have since been prosecuted with varying fortunes, and one of them is still undecided. A call of unprecedented magnitude had been made for more men. Gold had risen from 150 to 250. Taxes had been multiplied and doubled in weight. Peace plotters on the Canada border had set up their false lights; and demagogues at home had plied every art to deceive the people. The rebel armies, though on the whole worsted, were still full of fight; the Richmond Government showed not the slightest sign of yielding; and the Southern people remained, to all appearance, just as submissive to their leaders as ever.

abstract: In accordance with an order issued by Collector DRAPER for the closing of bonded warehouses, whose owners charge extortionate rates for storage, Deputy Collector STUDWELL has closed two of them. It appears that in consequence of unusually heavy importations, the fluctuations in the price of gold, and the general rise in prices, the rates for storage were increased, and attained in some cases extraordinary figures, so that complaints of merchants were frequent, and the late Collector, after a full consideration of the circumstances, decided that no more then the rates approved by the Chamber of Commerce in 1857, with the addition of one hundred and fifty per centum, should be charged for storage. This note was satisfactory to the merchants, but many of the storekeepers did not abide by it, and continued charging heavy prices, claiming that they could obtain from merchants on private account as much money as they charged for public storage. Recently, a case in which eight times the enhanced rate allowed by Mr. BARNEY, had been enforced, came before Collector DRAPER; and another case in which nearly three hundred dollars were charged, where the legal amount was less than one hundred dollars. These alleged extortions caused the closing of the stores; and Mr. DRAPER has sent to Washington for further instructions. Other complaints have been lodged with the Collector, and he is investigating them as rapidly as possible.

abstract: As the handle of the City Hall clock touched the ghostly hour of twelve last night, a procession of about six persons, accompanied by drum and fife, might have been seen wending their way up Chatham-street, bearing aloft a paper lantern, upon the four sides of which was inscribed the legend "No North," "No South," "No East," "No West." We suppose this immense procession was in honor of somebody or something -- we know not who or what.

abstract: Legion of Honor, Suggestion for a
snippet: Legion of Honor, Suggestion for a
lead_paragraph: The time, long looked for, is now to all appearance approaching, when the great rebellion will crumble to dust before the sledgehammer blows of the Union armies. A few more brave men, a few more well-directed strokes, and the base fabric that has so long vexed our eyes will be no more. In this condition of affairs, the surprising alacrity with which volunteers are coming forward, is a most auspicious sign, especially when it is considered that this new material is of the best. The stalwart farmers, who, having done up the chief part of their harvesting, now hasten to the scene of conflict to be "in at the death," will do good service when placed in the ranks of war-worn regiments, the best of schools for learning the soldier's duties.

abstract: Ten days ago despondency prevailed among the Union men of Vermont, as elsewhere at the North? The announcement made in caucus was followed by an outburst of applause almost involuntary, and by prolonged cheering. The spell of despondency...

abstract: About 5 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the storage warehouse of JOHN B. HOBBY, a five-story building, known as Nos. 110, 112, 114 and 116 Washington-street. abstract: Escape from Drowning at Chicago when young
snippet: Escape from Drowning at Chicago when young
lead_paragraph: A careful examination, on a good map, of the position of the Army of the Potomac on James River, will convince any person capable of understanding a military situation, that it is one highly avantageous. We hold the peninsula between the James and Appomattox Rivers, at Bermuda Hundred, elaborately fortified, and made impregnable. On the right we have an important post north of the James River, also well fortified, and connected with Bermuda Hundred by our fleet which rests in James River, over which, when required, a pontoon bridge can be thrown. On the left, Bermuda Hundred is connected with the position in front of Petersburgh by a pontoon bridge which is fully protected by fortifications on either shore and a portion of our fleet. The base of our operations is City Point, just, below the junction of the Appomattox with the James. A railroad runs from this point, on the east side of the Appomattox, up to Petersburgh, and is employed in carrying supplies to our troops. Our lines about Petersburgh now envelop the city so far as to include the Weldon or Great Southern Railroad. Now it will be seen at a glance that GRANT can, without the knowledge of the enemy, or leaving any part of his line insecure, throw the main body of his army either south of Petersburgh, or between Petersburgh and Richmond, or against Richmond, north of the James. Out of this situation it is reasonable to expect the most important and favorable results will be obtained.

abstract: Large as was the attendance on the opening day of the meeting, it faded into insignificance by the side of the immense gathering that was congregated on the Paterson Course yesterday immense alike in numbers and respectability. If we were called upon to cite a model management and a model race-course, we should say: Paterson " bears off the belle." It is refreshing to have gentlemen at...
lead_paragraph: Large as was the attendance on the opening day of the meeting, it faded into insignificance by the side of the immense gathering that was congregated on the Paterson Course yesterday -- immense alike in numbers and respectability. If we were called upon to cite a model management and a model race-course, we should say: Paterson "bears off the belle." It is refreshing to have gentlemen at the head of affairs -- gentlemen of wealth, intelligence and determined purpose; not men intent on gate money speculations, but men whose sole interest and purpose is the revival of racing in its most legitimate sense, and whose only aim, end and purpose is the encouragement or the breed of the thorough-bred horse, and whose greatest delight is good racing, -- financial success being quite a secondary consideration.

abstract: Peace Meeting at; John Mullally, Pres
snippet: Peace Meeting at; John Mullally, Pres
lead_paragraph: A reunion of about fifty Peace Democrats took place on Tuesday evening at the St. Nicholas Hotel, for the purpose of denouncing Gen. MCCLELLAN's letter, and of advising about the best means of organizing a peace party, and of selecting a peace candidate. The meeting was called to order by Mr. MULLALY, the editor of the Metropolitan Record, who was appointed President for the occasion. Among the gentlemen present were Messrs. Orton, of the Day Book, Macmasters, of the Freeman's Journal, Ben. Wood, of the Daily News, Gen. Singleton and Green, of Illinois Geo, K. Shell, of Oregon, S.T. Suit, of New-York, Chauncey Burr, W.T. Smith Anderson, and a lot of others. All the members present seemed to be moved by the bitterest feelings against Gen. MCCLELLAN, denounced him as having broken his pledge toward the Democratic party, and compromised its success in the pending election. Mr. SHEIL, Gen. SINGLETON and CHAUNCEY BURR were among the prominent speakers of that meeting, at the conclusion of which S.T. SUIT, of New-York, presented the following resolution:

abstract: Exhaustion; Signs of; Press on Impossibility to take Atlanta
snippet: Exhaustion; Signs of; Press on Impossibility to take Atlanta
lead_paragraph: We trust our readers are in no way affected by the bold and confident tone which the Richmond press continue to hold. They are the paid organs of an oligarchy, and, as long as the rebellion has a leg to stand upon, they will keep up this bold key. They are employed for that. Even when the Jeff Davis tyranny is just on the eve of destruction from within, we shall hear from the Richmond writers of the "unassailable power" of the Confederates and "the gracious terms" which they will grant to the detested Yankees. Now and then, however, they let out, even at this time, the poor "dodge" which the braggart employs.

abstract: Campaign Documents; Three for Slavery
snippet: Campaign Documents; Three for Slavery
lead_paragraph: -- We observe in an advertised list of "Democratic Campaign Documents," twenty-seven in number, three whose titles indicate that they are devoted to the defence of human Slavery. They are Bishop HOPKINS' Bible View of Slavery, Prof. MORSE on the Ethical Position of Slavery in the Social System, and Results of Emancipation in English, French and Spanish America. Three out of twenty-seven devoted specifically to Slavery -- this is only one-ninth of the whole, though we think it altogether likely, that of the remaining eight-ninths the greater part are really, under various guises, on the same side of the same topic.

abstract: The Passionist Fathers have erected a splendid quilding at West Hoboken, which is to be called St. Michael's Monastery. This building will be used as a monastic institution, and carried on strictly in accordance with the rules and regulations laid down in that clerical order of the Roman Catholic Church designated the Passionist Fathers. The structure has been erected at the cost of thirty thousand dollars. Attached to it are sixteen acres of ground, for which sixteen thousand dollars have been paid. As to the locality in which it is situated, there could scarcely be a more picturesque or healthful one. From it a view can be had of the surrounding country for miles, with New-York City and Brooklyn in front and Jersey City to the right. The tender influences of religious meditation could scarcely have a more agreeable retreat for exercise. The Reverend Fathers have left nothing undone in order to make this institution one of the finest of its class in the country. This monastery is about three miles from the Hoboken Ferry, and accessible by the railroad cars or by the Union Hill line of stages. On Sunday, the 25th inst., it will be solemnly dedicated. In the meanwhile the public are invited to visit the institution, and judge for themselves of its usefulness. A fair for the benefit of the monastery is about being held at Hoboken, and subscriptions are solicited. The following clergymen will be in charge of the institution: Rev. Father DOMINICK TARLETINI, Provincial; Rev. Father GANDENTIUS ROSSI, Vice-Provincial; Rev. Father VICTOR CAMUOHIO, Rector.

abstract: This interesting trial of skill will commence at the Hippotheatron, Fourteenth-street, at 7:30 o'clock this evening. Both players are in most excellent health and practice, and it is anticipated that the winner's average will be greater than anything yet on record. Thus far there has been very little betting on this match; but the friends of KAVANAGH, who is decidedly the favorite, are unwilling to give odds, and as TIEMAN's friends claim they should be allowed at least $100 to $80, it prevents investments. The public can rest assured that Mr. PHELAN has arranged to have this game conducted in the most orderly and satisfactory manner. The game is 1,500 points up, on a four-pocket Phelan & Collender table, with 2 3/3 inches balls, for $1,000, the championship, and the possession of the golden cue. KAVANAGH has been champion since June, 1863, and the present encounter is the fourth he has been forced to contend in to maintain his supremacy.

abstract: Letter on Subsidized Emigration
snippet: Letter on Subsidized Emigration
lead_paragraph: The letter of Mr. GUNTHER on subsidized emigration, which may be found in another column, is about as atrocious a libel upon the country as we remember to have read in some time. Mr. GUNTHER was appealed to in his official capacity to lend his encouragement to the practical organization of the scheme of emigration sanctioned by the late act of Congress. And to this appeal the Mayor's reply in brief is, that "these importations (by which he means the emigrants, like his own immediate ancestors, who arrive here) are to be either food for powder, or to paralyze the laboring population, so as to prevent strikes caused by an inflated currency;" and to these objects he cannot give his support. The liberal and carefully-prepared act of Congress passed during the last session, he characterizes as "a bait, under fraudulent pretences, to enlist foreigners."
headline: {'main': 'Mayor Gunther on Emigration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mayor Gunther on Emigration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We ought to have the whole number of men called for by the President in the shortest possible time. Prompt action in filling our armies will have more effect upon the enemy than a victory over them. They profers to believe, and made their men believe, there is such a party North in favor of recognizing Southern independence, that the draft cannot be enforced. Let them be undeceived.
lead_paragraph: WAR DEPARTMENT, Sept. 14, 1864.

abstract: -- It is certainly amusing to read the arguments which we are still receiving by each successive mail from England, to prove that SHERMAN can never capture Atlanta. The reasoning in some cases is quite plausible, and it is sent forth clad in a pomp of rhetoric which is really stunning; while the jeers and taunts about the insanity of the North in fancying that it ever can succeed in the job, are really terrible to bear -- they make one laugh so. Now that they must have got the genuine news about the matter, what wry faces they must be making; and how their former declamations and reasonings must rise up before them as monuments of madness.
lead_paragraph: -- It is certainly amusing to read the arguments which we are still receiving by each successive mail from England, to prove that SHERMAN can never capture Atlanta. abstract: Union in Georgia; Andersonville
snippet: Union in Georgia; Andersonville
lead_paragraph: -- The rebels seem to be in some fear that the thirty thousand or more Union prisoners confined at Andersonville, in Western Georgia, will rise up against their keepers and guards and make an attempt at escape; and they also tell us that when Gen. SHERMAN visited the rebel hospitals at Jonesboro, a few days since, he told the rebels that he was going to Atlanta to rest his army, and would next proceed to Andersonville. The idea of Gen. SHERMAN going round and narrating his plans and purposes to wounded rebels, is decidedly novel.

abstract: the New Law on
snippet: the New Law on
lead_paragraph: -- Congress, at the last session, passed an act in reference to collisions upon the water, to which it is very important that the attention of shipping men should be attracted, and which we therefore publish in another column. As will be seen, it has created a new set of rules with relation to lights, to fog-signals and to the navigation of vessels when approaching each other. All vessels, whether steam or sailing vessels, except pilot-boats and open boats, are now required to carry the green and red lights, which have heretofore been confined to steamers. Different lights are provided for steamtugs, for pilot-boats and open fishing-boats. Fog-signals are required to be sounded on all vessels every five minutes during a fog. Some of the common rules of navigation for vessels when approaching each other, have been put into the form of positive regulations of law, but there are variations enough in them to require every navigator to thoroughly familiarize himself with them. The law went into operation on the 1st of this month, and all vessels not complying with these rules, of course run the risk of being held liable for the consequences of any collision which may occur. We understand that these rules are similar to the new rules recently adopted in England. We have not been able to compare them all but those which we have seen are in the same words; and the importance of having the same rules of navigation apply to the vessels of one nation as well as of another is so obvious, that a change could hardly have been made. Both nations should at once exert themselves to have the same rules adopted everywhere, in order that the uniformity of the law of the sea may still be maintained as it has been for so many centuries.
headline: {'main': 'THE NEW LAW OF NAVIGATION AND LIGHTS; ON VESSELS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE NEW LAW OF NAVIGATION AND LIGHTS; ON VESSELS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Two Factions
snippet: Two Factions
lead_paragraph: It is no new thing for the leaders of the Democratic party to carry on a political campaign by wearing two faces, by having platforms which are susceptible of a double construction, by shouting one war-cry in one place and the opposite one in another. The phrases, "POLK, DALLAS, and the Tariff of '42," and "BUCHANAN and Free Kansas," will at once recall to our readers' minds instances of such action. These leaders have not forgotten their successful use of such means, and they had determined to use them again. The present campaign was to be fought by them under the opposite cries of "MCCLELLAN and the Prosecution of the War," and "MCCLELLAN and PENDLETON and a Cessation of Hostilities."

abstract: The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool Aug. 30, via Queenstown Aug. 31, arrived at this port at 9 o'clock last evening. Her advices are barely one day later than those by the America, from Southampton Aug. 30. The...
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool Aug. 30, via Queenstown Aug. 31, arrived at this port at 9 o'clock last evening. Her advices are barely one day later than those by the America, from Southampton Aug. 30. The Arabia, with three days' later news, arrived at Halifax shortly before midnight, but her news was received at so late an hour that we are unable to give a summary of it here. The Pennsylvania also arrived at this port yesterday morning, but her dates were anticipated. Queen VICTORIA had visited Perth, to attend the dedication of a monument to the Prince Consort. She was enthusiastically received. The Mersey ram Scorpion had had a trial of speed, and averaged nearly 13 knots an hour. The Emperor of France and Prince HUMBERT were at Chalons.

abstract: The Cleve land Herald says that Mr. CHARLES E. WILSON, who went down to Georgia and Alabama on behalf of the city, to obtain negro substitutes, returned on Monday last without having bagged a single "black-bird." He says the endeavor to obtan substitues in those States is not only exceedingly unsuccessful but decidedly unthankful business. A man who goes down in the vicinity of our armies to obtain black substitutes for able-bodied men remaining at home, is looked upon by officers and soldiers, as engaged in about the smallest business that can be found in the whole United States.

abstract: Congratulatory Dispatch to Gov Smith, Vermont
snippet: Congratulatory Dispatch to Gov Smith, Vermont
lead_paragraph: A communication in the Express clears up the mystery which has hung over the fate of the Electric Spark, recently captured by the Florida off the Capes of the Delaware: Shortly after her capture by the Florida, she, with the Florida, proceeded to one of the small keys, not over fifty-four miles from Nassau, where her cargo, which was a very valuable one, and especially adapted for the rebels -- there being a large quantity of Winter clothing, and shoes and boots on board -- was reshipped on a blockade-runner, and has long ere this been safely in Dixie. The vessel was then to be put in order to carry guns, and to be altered as much as possible for a cruise, so that ere long, most likely, she will be prowling along the coast. The Electric Spark also had a very large mail on board, with a considerable sum in greenbacks, all of which was nabbed by the rebels. As there is a prospect ere long of a visit in force from another fleet of fast-sailing cruisers, it would be well for New-York merchants, and particularly the pilots, to run their vessels and boats with 20-pound pivot rifle guns. Any of the pilot-boats can carry one on her bow, and as the range of these guns are over 2 1/2 to 3 miles, it will be the best safeguard for them, and more particularly as the principal portion of these cruisers will be of iron. A good shell out of one of these guns will almost cripple any of these iron blockade-runners, like the Tallahassee.

lead_paragraph: Admiral FARRAGUT is not disposed to rest upon his oars. Although the main channel near the head of the bay, across Dog River bar, is still blockaded by a sunken rebel ironclad, four vessels of the Union fleet have run over, or through, the obstructions, and are now anchored within three miles, or easy shelling distance of the City. The vessels that have made this advance are the Winnebago, (double-turreted monitor,) the Metacomet, the Sebago, and the Kennebec. The Winnebago has reached a point where she can throw 11 and 15-inch shells into the heart of the city. The place is simply as good as captured. A few hours' shelling would leave it a mass of ruins. Probably, the municipal authorities will be able to compel Gen. GARDNER to accept, on their behalf, terms of surrender, which will save the painful necessity of reducing the city. And if so, the completion of the task to which the gallant Admiral and Gen. GRANGER set themselves on the 5th of August, will be reported probably before many more days elapse.

Since the rebels were so completely surprised on Saturday last, they have kept up a constant picket firing, as if apprehensive that something of a like nature might occur again. The Richmond journals gravely announce that GRANT is receiving heavy reinforcements, and sending them to his left, which portion of his line, they say, he is slowly but steadily extending.

abstract: The Rebels' Candidate
snippet: The Rebels' Candidate
lead_paragraph: Of all the leaders of the Army of the Potomac, not one was so acceptable to the rebels as Gen. McCLELLAN. That fact is beyond dispute. He was habitually spoken of by the rebel journals with complaisance and professions of respect. While they exhausted the slang vocabulary for epithets against every other leader of that army, and even then apparently could find nothing abusive enough to satisfy the spite and gall within them, they always used none but gracious language toward Gen. MCCLELLAN. In this simple distinction thus made by them, there was a volume of meaning. Why should it have been made but for a feeling on the part of the rebels that it was a good thing for them that Gen. MCCLELLAN should be at the head of our armies? They rave like demons against GRANT. "Butcher GRANT" is their ordinary designation of him, but that is only their childish prattle when compared with some of their billingsgate. No Northern Copperhead dares say that Gen. GRANT is not every whit the equal of Gen. MCCLELLAN in personal respectability. The difference in rebel treatment can be owing to nothing else than to the fact that MCCLELLAN's generalship was of a character to please them, and GRANT's is not. There is no other possible explanation of it.

abstract: Armistice for Atlanta; People to go South
snippet: Armistice for Atlanta; People to go South
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN has issued an order which will save his army a vast deal of needless and most distasteful labor, and relieve the non-combatant people in and around Atlanta, who still consider themselves "Confederate" citizens, from many of the necessary hardships of the new military administration. He has effected a ten days' armistice with HOOD to enable the non-combatants to go southward, with all their movable effects, including so much of the negro property as may be disposed to go with the other chattels. He does not force negroes to leave with their masters, nor does he adopt the equally inhumane rule of dragging them away from their dear protectors on a spurious plea of philanthropy. He takes the rational and philosophic, and, we will also add, the philanthropic ground, that, except where military necessity clearly requires a different policy to be followed, the negro may be left some choice in working out his own future destiny. That is, that we are not bound by any law of national benevolence to lay theftuous hands on enslaved persons, even for the high object of ushering them into the domain of freedom.

abstract: Confederacy Utters Sound Sense on Grant
snippet: Confederacy Utters Sound Sense on Grant
lead_paragraph: -- Among our extracts from Southern papers this morning, will be found a sensible, though amusing, article from the Atlanta Confederacy of Sept. 1. The sensible part of it is its comments upon the foolish attempts of the Richmond papers to belittle SHERMAN'S progress and his attempts to take Atlanta, prior to its capture, pointing out very forcibly the fact that SHERMAN'S army had advanced from the Ohio River to the Chattahoochee, captured Nashville and Chattanooga, and held them.

abstract: More than ordinary interest was manifested among the lovers of billiards throughout the country in the trial for the championship, which came off between Messrs. KAVANAGH and TIEMAN, in this City, on Thursday evening last. New-Yorkers have long since concluded that the Champion, KAVAHAGH, was invincible at the game; but when the rumors of the immense prowess which TIEMAN had been exhibiting for the last four months became public, a great many persons, among them some of the most competent judges, were wavering in their opinions, and many thought that the Golden Cue was about being carried Westward.

abstract: Renomination and Politics
snippet: Renomination and Politics
lead_paragraph: GOV. SEYMOUR was renominated with acclamation; and it is with acclamation that the nomination is welcomed by Union men. It is an excellent thing that the Opposition candidate for our highest State office is to be a man so completely understood. What we have had to fear most is deception. The Copperheads, since their unfortunate candor at Chicago, have taken to dissembling. They are trying to cajole the people with new war professions. They have now discovered that here is their only possible chance of success. But whatever mischief might have come of this is averted by such nominations as this of SEYMOUR. Party professions amount to nothing, where the candidates have a thoroughly known character. No display of false colors would lure a merchantman, when SEMMES himself was seen on the quarter-deck.

abstract: Movements and Richmond Examiner's Surmises
snippet: Movements and Richmond Examiner's Surmises
lead_paragraph: -- The Richmond Examiner, judging by the looks of the thing, seems to have stopped its press last Saturday to insert the following terrible paragraph in its issue of that day: "It is reported that there is little doubt that Grant is receiving reinforcements, and that he is conveying them to his left. Where they come from, or what the object of collecting them on our right can be, is a mere conjecture."

abstract: The Legislative Assembly met in this city on the 1st inst., and offer scrutinizing the votes cast for President in the late election, declared Gen. SANTACOLOMA unconditionally elected for the coming period. For some days previous to the meeting of the Assembly, a great deal of excitement existed, and it was generally believed that a revolution was inevitable; but with the announcement of the relection of SANTACOLOMA all fears of an uprising have entirely disappeared.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Sunday, Sept. 5.

abstract: The British mail steamship Bogota, from Valparalso and intermediate ports, arrived at Panama on the 4th inst. She brings dates from Valparalso and Santiago de Chill to Aug. 16, Bolivia to the 20th, and from Lima and Callao to the 27th August. The Bogota brings $372,000 in specie and a cargo of wool, cotton, bark, , principally for England. For New-York she has 77 bales cacao, 83 bales wool, 31 bales goatskins and 61 hides.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Tuesday, Sept. 6, 1864.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "Der Frieschutz" last evening was excellent. Herr HABELMAN never sung better, and Frau FREDERICK was, in the second act, most admirable. It was in this opera that the lady made her debut, and her first success. The vocal gymnastics necessary for the second part of the aria are not completely at her command, but the memorable slow movement that precedes it has rarely been given with better feeling or more quiet melodiousness. Fraulein CANISSA, as Anna, displays symptoms of improvement, but her voice yet needs the strength of age. The choruses and orchestra were spirited, and the entire performance, gave abundant satisfaction to the audience.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "Der Frieschutz" last evening was excellent. Herr HABELMAN never sung better, and Frau FREDERICK was, in the second act, most admirable. abstract: Aspect, the
snippet: Aspect, the
lead_paragraph: Appearances in war are proverbially deceptive. The day may dawn in peaceful quiet, and the evening fall upon a field of blood. Operations may seem to have come to a long pause, when suddenly there is the fierce resumption of hostilities. At this moment the general public are quite incapable of forming any opinion as to the chances of speedy activity on the part of either of our two main armies, or what will be the character and direction of the movements which GRANT and SHERMAN will next attempt. It is common to represent SHERMAN's campaign as closed by the capture of Atlanta. That triumph did, in one sense, and the campaign; but in a large sense, SHERMAN's campaign cannot be said to be closed until he destroys the army of HOOD. The geographical objective was Atlanta, and that is ours; the real body at which he struck was HOOD's army, and that has still, in some shape, a vital and substantive existence. It was assuredly fearfully crippled even before the fall of Atlanta, and it staggered back from that place in dismay and panic. But it still waits for the death-blow which will send it reeling into the last ditch, on the verge of which it now stands. That death-blow SHERMAN will, we believe, give it, with energy, before the snows of Winter fall upon the mountains of Upper Georgia.

abstract: on Who Can Make Peace
snippet: on Who Can Make Peace
lead_paragraph: -- JOHN VAN BUREN wrote to the Albany Convention that there were obviously two men who never could make a peace that would be sanctioned by the people, viz.: ABRAHAM LINCOLN and JEFFERSON DAVIS. He did not mention, however, that there are obviously two men who can make a peace, and the only kind of a peace which the people will sanction, viz.; Gen. GRANT and Gen. SHERMAN.

abstract: We remarked in Wednesday's issue on the gross misrepresentation made by Mayor GUNTHER, in his recent letter upon the new Emigrant Act. The economical and political utterances which he there makes are, however, even more unfounded. We are informed that immigration will add to the number of those 50,000 operatives in this City who are already "suffering under the oppression of capital."
lead_paragraph: We remarked in Wednesday's issue on the gross misrepresentation made by Mayor GUNTHER, in his recent letter upon the new Emigrant Act. The economical and political utterances which he there makes are, however, even more unfounded. We are informed that immigration will add to the number of those 50,000 operatives in this City who are already "suffering under the oppression of capital." Mr. GUNTHER is himself a capitalist, and, like thousands of his countrymen, has made a respectable fortune by employing certain of these unfortunate "operatives" of whom he speaks. Does he consider the large sums of money which, in the course of years, he has paid out to this ill-treated class as a portion of those "oppressive" dealings to which he alludes? Or does his conscience now accuse him of "oppression," because his income has been measured by thousands of dollars, while that of his laborers was only hundreds? is he about to propose an equal division of profits between the ground-down victims of oppression employed in the fur-trade and their wealthy employers? The public feel a natural anxiety to know what exactly the oppression may be to which the 60,000 operatives of New-York are continually subject, and what remedy the Mayor of the City would propose. Our worthy Magistrate seems to connect a portion of the wrongs of this unfortunate class with the "inflation of the currency." But when it is remembered that a day laborer gets in the City $2 50 where before he only received 75 cents, and that $3 a day and board will not secure men in the country for the harvest, it is difficult to see what great sufferings these workers can attribute to the currency. In fact, most householders in the City -- who may be considered as belonging to the ranks of. the oppressors -- would in their simplicity have concluded that the oppression was mostly on the other side -- that laborers charged a price far in advance of the rise in values, and did their work indifferently at that. And how increased immigration is to injure this class, as is urged by the Mayor, is certainly a point not easy to make clear to the common mind. Hitherto, our laboring class has welcomed the immigrant, and even aids his coming by money advanced, which, in the aggregate, amounts to millions of dollars per annum. Every one here knew the simple axiom in political economy that labor is one of the sources of wealth, and that the whole country would be the richer for additions to its producers, and therefore each individual be the better off. Our operatives have hitherto understood that our cheap railways and canals, our immense improvements and buildings for the public and individuals, are due to the fact that we have had so much labor supplied us continually from Europe.
headline: {'main': 'Mayor Gunther on Political Economy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mayor Gunther on Political Economy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Express Companies and Income Tax Decision
snippet: Express Companies and Income Tax Decision
lead_paragraph: -- A decision recently made in the United States Circuit Court in this District, in relation to the Income Tax, will be of interest to all persons who hold stock in Express Companies. It has been claimed that the dividends received upon stock in such companies were exempted from the Income Tax. A suit was brought against a collector to test the question, and the court has decided that the dividends are subject to the tax. The opinion will be found in our legal columns. The effect of the decision will be to put the stockholders in Express Companies upon the same footing, as regards Income Tax, as stockholders in railroads and steamboats, and there is no apparent reason why they should not be so.

abstract: Repudiates Chicago Platform
snippet: Repudiates Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: -- The Copperhead papers have falsely stated that this distinguished officer recently expressed himself decidedly in favor of Gen. McCLELLAN for the Presidency. We are able to deny the assertion on the very best authority. While desiring to keep aloof as much as possible from political associations, and looking to the welfare of the country from a purely military point of view, Gen. HOOKER utterly repudiates the principles of the Chicago platform and its candidate, and urges the most vigorous and unrelenting prosecution of the war, until the rebels lay down their arms, and return to their allegiance on such honorable terms as the victors may offer to the vanquished. The few vigorous public utterances of Gen. HOOKER are to this effect, and should be sufficient, together with his record in the field, to define his position.
headline: {'main': 'GEN. HOOKER', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GEN. HOOKER', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: on Peace Democrats and the War; Brief History of; On Chicago Platform and Democratic Party; Speech at Union League Club, New-York; History of
snippet: on Peace Democrats and the War; Brief History of; On Chicago Platform and Democratic Party; Speech at Union League Club, New-York; History of
lead_paragraph: The following characteristic speech was made last week before the Union League Club by Gen. CUTLER, of the "Iron Brigade," who has been long identified with the Army of the Potomac, and who recently distinguished himself at the battle of Reams' Station. At the conclusion of the regular business of the evening, the General was introduced to the Club by Capt. NOYES and Mr. WARREN, who had been appointed a committee for the purpose, and was cordially welcomed on their behalf by Mr. JOHN JAY who temporarily occupied the chair. The General was greeted with enthusiasm, and a reference to his recent services in the seizure of the Weldon Railroad, a success which, among the recent achievements of the war, ranks next in importance to the capture of Atlanta, called forth warm applause.

abstract: The strong point in the American character is its openness. The fact is one which no disinterested and intelligent observer from DE TOCQUEVILLE downward has failed to record and emphasize. The excess of the virtue has often been the subject of satire, its absence never. The native villain is usually neither deep nor heavy. His crimes as a rule, are not of the darkly mysterious order. They are rarely the result of prolonged meditation or miracles of cunning and deceit.

abstract: Spain and Peru
snippet: Spain and Peru
lead_paragraph: Spain and Peru are very far from having settled their differences. The former persists in charging the Government of the latter with complicity in an attempt to rob and poison her Minister, and declares that she will retain possession of the Chincha Islands till the Peruvian Executive shall have demonstrated its innocence. The Peruvian Secretary of State replies in spirited and energetic language to this demand. He refuses to humiliate and dishonor his nation by placing its Government in a worse position than that of a common delinquent, and expresses a doubt whether there is another State in the world that would dare to make a similar requisition.

abstract: In fifty years we have made no material progress in militia organization. Constant failure is presumptive evidence of wrong methods. The temper of our people is more mercurial than that of our Canadian neighbors or of the English people. But while we have been repeating our failures in militia organization, they have heen quite successful. Their methods have been radically different from ours, and to this single fact, doubtless, their success is attributable.
lead_paragraph: In fifty years we have made no material progress in militia organization. Constant failure is presumptive evidence of wrong methods. The temper of our people is more mercurial than that of our Canadian neighbors or of the English people. But while we have been repeating our failures in militia organization, they have heen quite successful. Their methods have been radically different from ours, and to this single fact, doubtless, their success is attributable. The annual muster of the militia in this state is an utter [???]zzie. Save in some of the Western States, there is no thorough, efficient and popular militia organization in the country. A well-trained militia is needful to the security of the country against either insurrection or invasion. Had the militia organizations of the Free States been in an effective condition when the rebellian broke out, as effective as they were in some of the cities and one or two States, it is altogether probable that the early disasters of the war would have been averted. Massachusetts gained no small distinction and praise by her promptness in sending her troops to the field in the Spring of 1861. The result was accomplished by the willingness and energy of her officers and people, and by the perfectness of the organization of a few of her regiments of State militia. Our experience at the outset of the war, as well as since, has shown the advantage, if not the absolute necessity, of the constant maintenance of a well-trained body of militia.

abstract: Sympathy with of Democratic Party; Sympathy with the Soldiers
snippet: Sympathy with of Democratic Party; Sympathy with the Soldiers
lead_paragraph: The soldier's vote is an element in the present contest which the Chicago Convention felt could not be disregarded, and yet they were animated by no love for those who were to cast that vote. Every man in all the Northern States who voted against allowing the soldier to cast a ballot was represented in that body. The soldiers' vote has always been solid against them, and they dreaded and hated it, and if they had been governed by their feelings they would have openly expressed their hostility. The leaders, however, knew very well that this would not do, but that on the other hand they must do something, if possible, to turn the edge of that hostility which every true soldier must feel for a party which embraces every peace man in the country -- and so they paid some attention to the soldiers. There was very little in the speeches. Gov. SEYMOUR did indeed endeavor to flatter them a little, but made sad work of it. Said he: "It was a soldier upon whom our Savior bestowed his only commendation when he hung on the cross and Pharisees mocked his sufferings. It was a soldier alone who discerned his divinity when he heard him pour forth a prayer for mercy and forgiveness for the authors of his sufferings." The last ground of commendation may be allowed, although it was not when our Savior poured forth the prayer of which the Governor speaks, but at His death, that the centurion discerned His divinity; and to say that he was the only one who discerned it, is a severe assault on the Apostles. But as to the first tem of praise, unless the Governor has seen the Wandering Jew, and derived from him the fact not stated in the Scriptures, that the penitent thief was a soldier, it seems to us that he was mistaken about it entirely. Nor should we think that soldiers would feel complimented by proof that a certain thief, though he was penitent, was one of their number.

abstract: -- The investigation into the cause of the boiler explosion on board the steam tug R.B. Sanders, on Friday, as reported in the Times, was begun by Coroner COLLIN yesterday. An inquest was instituted upon the body of JAMES DOYLE, pilot of the tug, but as several of the most important witness were absent the inquest was postponed until Tuesday morning next at 10 o'oclock. The engineer was badly scalded, but will probably be able to attend the inquest on Tuesday, at which time it is thought some further facts regarding this terrible affair may be arrived at.

There may possibly be no connection between the two statements, but it is certainly "a coincidence" that we should have them both on the same day.

abstract: The only news from the Army of the Potomac is a dispatch giving the particulars of a dash by rebel cavalry upon cattle corral on the James river, near Harrison's Landing, in which the rebels succeeded in driving off about 2,000 head of cattle, nearly all these were in the drove. Our cavalry were immediately sent in pursuit, and it was believed they would be overtaken, and most of the cattle re-captured. The rebels show their desperate need of food by desperate measures.

abstract: -- American history and the early annals of the European colonists of the New World still continue to occupy the attention of European scholars, though the din of war makes us at present less attentive than formerly to what is done abroad in elucidation of our early history. Among the latest enterprises set on foot relating to this subject is "Bibliotheca Americana," a collection of rare or inedited works on America, issued by the Parisian bookseller, M. FRANCK. Two volumes have already appeared. The first is a poem by the Captain FERNANDO ALVAREZ DE TOLEDO, one of the conquering army, "On the Conquest of Chili by the Spaniards," in 1546. It is printed for the first time from the author's autograph MS. The second volume, just issued, comprises Travels in the North of Brazil, undertaken in the years 1613 and 1614 by the Father YVES D'EVREUX. This is reprinted from the only known copy of the original edition, preserved in the Imperial Library, Paris.

abstract: Nearly fifty-two years have elapsed since the first steamboat that ever floated on the Western rivers (the Orleans, built by Messrs. FULTON and LIVINGSTON at Pittsburgh, in 1811.) made her first and only trip from Pittsburgh to New-Orleans. She did it in fourteen days. This was in the Winter of 1812. The Orleans continued to make regular trips between this port and Natchez until July 14, 1814, when she was wrecked near Union Rouge, on her upward-bound passage, by striking a snag. The Orleans was very different in construction from the steamboats in these days. She was furnished with a propelling wheel at the stern, and two masts; for Mr. FULTON believed, at that time, that the occasional use of sails would be indispensable. FULTON then had a very inadequate idea of the wonderful power of steam, properly applied. In this, STEPHENSON, the engineer of the Liverpool and Manchester Railroad, was like FULTON, for STEPHENSON, if we recollect rightly, calculated on attaining a speed of only seven miles an hour on the railroad, whereas a speed of 45 miles an hour is now regularly attained on the London and Great Western and other English railroads, and it is not uncommon for Express trains to travel at the rate of 60 miles an hour.

lead_paragraph: Union Square was witness to another extensive and expensive mass meeting, in honor of the Democratic candidate for the Presidency. It is very doubtful if the distinguished Major-General whose stolid features illuminated by tallow candles formed such a feature of the display, ever smelt so much gun-powder in the whole course of his military career. Indeed if the Peace party would find as many ball cartridges at the gunnery as they have blank cartridges for the sake of the noise, the war would soon end; or if all the little boys who were obliging enough to carry Chinese lanterns through the streets last night, would enter the army as musicians, the rebels might be drummed into the Gulf of Mexico in less than a month. This was, undoubtedly, as noisy, numerous, and heterogeneous an assemblage of men, women, little girls and babies, as has been gathered in since the City Fathers gave their annual exhibition of fireworks on 4th of July last. The fact was that the meeting lacked stamina. Instead of earnest men, eagerly seeking instruction upon national topics from the leaders of their party, a crowd of men, women, and children, collected to look at the illuminations and pyrotechnics, eat peaches and oranges, and have a good time. Much gratitude they undoubtedly felt to the managers for the entertainment afforded them, but apparently the last thing thought of was listening to the speakers.

abstract: At a recent meeting of the Legislature in Annapolis, one of the members stated that there had been a vote of the soldiers taken at the hospitals, and the result was in favor of MCCLELLAN. One of the other members disputed the statement, when it was referred to an officer present from the hospitals, who said that he knew of nothing of the kind having been done. Some of the members expressed a desire to have the vote taken, and asked the officer if he would have it done. The following is the result. The officer who took the vote says that the soldiers in those hospitals represent regiments from all parts of the country. He himself has lost a leg:

abstract: Yesterday was one of unusual bustle for the Fifth Corps. Nothing is so monotonous as the daily camp routine of the soldier's life. We can imagine with what eagerness and curiosity they were assembled around a large platform, overshadowed by a square-shaped music stand. The entire corps was under arme, making an imposing display with brightly-burnished weapons and well-brushed clothes. To every man in the rank and file the occasion was one of peculiar interest.
