abstract: at Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning as complainant against JOHN DOLAN, a young Irishman, 24 years of age, whom he charges with having relieved his pockets of a gold watch valued at $80. Complainant said he was at the mass meeting at Union-square on Saturday evening, and, that while standing on the corner of Broadway and 14th-street, looking at the fireworks, he felt some one pulling at his watch-chain, and turning round saw DOLAN with, as he believes, the watch in his hand. DOLAN broke away from him, and ran, and when overtaken by Sergt. MANGIN of the Ninth Precint, the watch was not found on him. DOLAN was committed by Justice LEDWITH for trial, in default of $500. He says he is not guilty of the crime charged against him.

abstract: The Secession journals convert the marriage of Miss BELLE BOYD into a first-class romance. But Capt. HARDINGE, it seems, was always a Secessionist in principle, and it is difficult to see where the romance lies, Mr. MOORE, of the Confederate service, has just married at Baden Baden, the second daughter of Mr. LUDLUM, of Richmond and New-York. The newspaper correspondents at Baden Baden speak in raptures of the sumptuousness of the marriage ceremonies and of the beauty and elegance of the bride. The papers also speak of the forthcoming marriage of the eldest daughter of Mr. SLIDDEL to M. ERLANGER, the negotiator of the Confederate loan. After ten months' pleading before the Cardinals at Rome, the demand of M. ERLANGER for a legalization of his divorce from M'lle. Laffite has been granted.

abstract: -- SAMUEL BOWMAN and THOMAS DURONLY, had an altercation at the house of the latter, No. 22 Catharine-street, on Saturday night, when Bowman drew a dirk knife and stabbed Duronly in the neck, inflecting a probably fatal wound. abstract: For many years we have not had so complete a calm in the political world as at the present moment. The Emperor is absent at the Champ of Chalons with the Prince HUMBERT of Italy, the politicians are off at their country places, and the calm that pervades France appears to reign equally all over Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Fiday, Sept. 2, 1864.

abstract: Atlanta Campaign--What Next ?
snippet: Atlanta Campaign--What Next ?
lead_paragraph: In the congratulatory order issued to his soldiers by Gen. SHERMAN when his army entered Atlanta, he says, after reciting the various steps in the triumphant campaign; the capture of Atlanta "completed the grand task which had been assigned us by our Government." What the entire scope and precise limitation of these words may be, it is difficult to say. We suppose the capture of Atlanta was the task assigned to our brave Western army when it set forth from Chattanooga in May last, and beyond that work it was impossible at that time to draw out any fixed line of military action. So far, it was definite, simple and essential; but, Atlanta once attained, our further progress would depend upon the condition of our army, upon the condition of the rebel army, upon its position and line of retreat, and upon the general aspect of the war. East and West. If the campaign had closed with the destruction of HOOD's force, the farther advance of Sherman's army, as a mass into Georgia, would have been unnecessary: if, on the other hand, the rebel force were borne away intact, SHERMAN's plans and movements would still remain to be dictated by great variety of circumstances.
headline: {'main': 'What Now for Sherman?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What Now for Sherman?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Public Career and Present Views
snippet: Public Career and Present Views
lead_paragraph: The Union party of this State having, at its late convention, nominated the Hon. REUBEN E. FENTON as its candidate for Governor, it may not be uninteresting to review briefly his antecedents and past political record. Mr. FENTON is a native of Chautauqua County, where his father was settled, one of the earliest pioneers in the extreme western part of the State. He was born July 4, 1819, and is consequently forty-five years of age, in the prime of his physical and mental manhood. His early years having been spent in agricultural pursuits, with such occasional advantages as could be obtained by attending the District Winter schools, and a few quarters at an academy, Mr. FENTON can be emphatically called a self-made man. in 1838 he commenced the study of law, more for instruction, than with any design of making it a profession, which continued until 1840, when he actively engaged in mercantile pursuits, which, for fifteen years, he followed up with such steady industry and energy as to achieve for himself a successful issue. During all this lime he was engaged in politics, constantly holding some county office, that indicated the confidence and esteem of his fellow-citizens. In 1849, the Democracy of Chautauqua presented him as a candidate for the Assembly from a district hitherto strongly Whig, and, after a severe contest, he lost his election by only 21 votes. In 1852, after another fiercely contested canvass, he was returned as a Representative in Congress, and took his seat in that body, the first Democratic member sent from that District. In 1854 he declined being a candidate for reelection until two days before the election, and although he polled a heavy vote, the time was too short to give sufficient notice throughout the district and he was defeated by the Know-Nothing candidate, Mr. EDWARDS, by a small majority. In 1855 and 1856 Mr. FENTON was actively engaged in the organization of the Republican party, and was President of the first convention of that party in this State. In 1856 he was nominated and elected to Congress on the Republican ticket, by upward of 8,000 majority. From that time to this he has continuously retained his seat by increased majorities, and is now serving his tenth year as a member of the House.
headline: {'main': 'THE UNION CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK.; Hon. Reuben E. Fenton. HIS PUBLIC CAREER AND HIS PRESENT VIEWS OF PUBLIC AFFAIRS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE UNION CANDIDATE FOR GOVERNOR OF THE STATE OF NEW-YORK.; Hon. Reuben E. abstract: National and Private Enterprises
snippet: National and Private Enterprises
lead_paragraph: The colonies of Australia were the first in our time to organize and foster a system of emigration by means of public subsidies. Their enterprise has been amply rewarded. In 1850 the entire population of New South Wales and Victoria was but 237,000. To-day the population of the colonies exceeds 1,800,000 -- an increase, in less than a decade and a half, of nearly eight hundred per cent. The venue has increased in the same time even in a greater ratio. Fourteen years ago the exports of Victoria amounted to about $6,000,000; to-day they exceed $90,000,000. The gold discoveries, it is true, contributed largely to this extraordinary growth, but the first impulse given to the settlement and industrial enterprise of the colonies was derived from the results which followed the public provision in aid of emigration.
headline: {'main': 'National and Private Emigration Enterprises.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'National and Private Emigration Enterprises.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Model Order on Atlanta
snippet: Model Order on Atlanta
lead_paragraph: -Gen. SHERMAN has surpassed all the newspaper correspondents as a military writer. He is not as picturesque, nor as effective, in a popular point of view, as some of the gentlemen connected with journalism; but for conciseness, perspicacity and comprehensiveness, with brevity, he is a perfect model. The congratulatory order which he issued to his army at Atlanta, on the 8th instant, is a superb example of this. In less than a page of an ordinary duodecimo book, he surveys the grand four months' campaign which opened by the march from Chattanooga and was consummated by the fall of Atalanta. Lest some of our stylists, or students of style, should have overlooked this historical gem, we give it a setting here:

abstract: The rebel cavalry dash upon a cattle corral near Harrison's, Landing on the James River, appears to have been entirely successful. Gen. GREGGS' cavalry were immediately sent out in hot pursuit; but, although it was rumored that the entire herd had been recaptured, it was generally believed that the raiders had too long a start to be overtaken, and that the rumor was without foundation.

abstract: The funeral of Dr. GEORGE POTTS took place yesterday from the church over which he recently presided as Pastor. Some time before the commencement of the exercises every available place in the edifice was filled up by members of his congregation, distinguished citizens and clergymen of all denominations, who gathered there in testimony of the high honor in which the deceased was held. After a dirge from the choir, and a prayer by Rev. Sr. SHEDD, Dr. KREBS delivered an address.

abstract: By the arrival of the Sidon at Halifax, and the Hibernian at Father Point, we have advices four days later from Europe. Rumors of an armistice between our Government and the rebels had produced a feeling of panic in financial circles, as it was feared that, on the opening of the Southern ports, the influx of cotton would seriously aggravate the existing pressure for money. It is rumored that Louis Napoleon intends to establish a new nobility, as a counterpoise to the democratic sentiment. The negotiations between Denmark and Germany were in danger of being broken off in consequence of Denmark's stubbornness in certain financial points. The Queen of Spain has graciously received the new Mexican Minister.

abstract: A correspondent of the Chattanooga Rebel, now published at Griffin, Ga., gives the following account of the rebel losses in the battle of Peach  tree creek, where the enemy attacked Hooker and was so terribly repulsed. "My limited observation of what transpired then, confines me to the operations of this (Scott's and Gen. Featherstone's, brigade of Loring' division. Our steps were marked with blood our march was strewn...
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Chattanooga Rebel, now published at Griffin, Ga., gives the following account of the rebel losses in the battle of Peach tree creek, where the enemy attacked Hooker and was so terribly repulsed. "My limited observation of what transpired then, confines me to the operations of this (Scott's and Gen. Featherstone's, brigade of Loring' division. Our steps were marked with blood -- our march was strewn with dead and wounded. Of this brigade -- numbering, perhaps, one thousand -- there were killed and wounded three hundred and ninety. One company of the Fifty-fifth Alabama went into the action with four officers and thirty-six men, and came out with only six men. Another, that went in with two officers and thirty men, came out with only four men. Of those left behind, all were either killed or so desperately wounded as to be unable to walk. There were none captured who were not thus disabled. Featherstone's brigade suffered a loss of one-half lacking one man. It lost, I think, six hundred and two aggregate."

abstract: Views of American Society
snippet: Views of American Society
lead_paragraph: The editor of the London Reader -- a remarkably candid and philosophical publication -- has recently been devoting several articles, with sober purpose, to "the tendency to rowdyism in American society," and the growing exhibition of what he calls "Manhattanism " in our literature. The discussion appears to be a genuine one on the part of the editor, and to have grown out of a certain novel -- unknown to most persons here -- written by "Manhattan," describing the rowdy elements of New-York, but of such doubtful character as to be suppressed; the said novel, however, having since been republished in England, and gone through two editions, in consequence of a critique by the London Times, recommending it as a truthful picture of American society!

abstract: And his Party--The General and the Cause
snippet: And his Party--The General and the Cause
lead_paragraph: We are afraid that undue attention is given by some of our Union friends to the military career of McCLELLAN. It seems to us really to be but a minor objection. If the civil policy of the Copperheads is correct, McCLELLAN'S military policy was good enough. Were we disposed to be a copperhead at all, it would certainly not be prevented by anything that Gen. McCLELLAN either did or failed to do.

abstract: Rio Grande; Union Troops Assisting Cortinas
snippet: Rio Grande; Union Troops Assisting Cortinas
lead_paragraph: We have a strange and startling story from the Rio Grande by way of New Orleans and Cairo. It would doubtless be interesting, as well, if we had the particulars in an intelligible form. The salient points, however, would seem to be this: On the 6th inst., the French army advanced from Bagdad to attack the Juarist force under Gen. CORTINAS at Matamoras. At a place called White Ranche, CORTINAS met the enemy and gave him battle. The result, according to the narrator who is a Sergeant of the 91st Illinois Reg't., stationed at Brazos, was a victory for the Juarist force. The French fell back some distance to a more defensible position, and at this point, while CORTINAS was giving them battle a second time, Col. FORD, the rebel commander at Brownsville, crossed the Rio Grande, attacked the Jaurez troops in the rear, but -- as the story goes -- notwithstanding the odds thus gained by him, CORTINAS drove the French behind their entrenchments, turned upon the rebel assailant in his rear, and compelled FORD and his men to retire.
headline: {'main': 'A Strange Story from the Rio Grande.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Strange Story from the Rio Grande.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out on the third floor of the building known as No. 596 Broadway, just above the Metropolion Hotel, near Houston street. Owing to the time in the morning at which the alarm was given, and the further fact that many of the firemen had not returned from a fire uptown, considerable time elapsed from the first striking of the bells, before there was much force of firemen on the ground. The flames spread with great rapidity, and soon all the upper portion of the extensive building extending through to Crosby street, was one sheet of flame.

abstract: The news from the Department of the Gulf is of great interest and importance. CORTINAS has crossed the Rio Grande, at the head of 2,000 men with sixteen cannon, and occupied Brownsville, Texas, after driving out the rebels under Col. FORD. It appears that the French moved from Bagdad on Matamoras,...
lead_paragraph: The news from the Department of the Gulf is of great interest and importance. CORTINAS has crossed the Rio Grande, at the head of 2,000 men with sixteen cannon, and occupied Brownsville, Texas, after driving out the rebels under Col. FORD. It appears that the French moved from Bagdad on Matamoras, on the 6th inst., and on the route encountered CORTINAS. A severe artillery duel ensued, in which the French were compelled to fall back. Soon afterward the Imperial forces were joined by the rebels under FORD, who was endeavoring to furnish the former with supplies. CORTINAS, however, succeeded in putting both rebels and Imperialists to flight. His artillery being unable to cope with the heavy guns of the French shipping, he crossed a large portion of his men to the American side of the river, took possession of Brownsville, and hoisted the Stars and Stripes where the rebel flag had lately waved. A later report says that CORTINAS has espoused the cause of the Union, and has sent an aide to Gen. CANBY with a tender of his army and artillery and his personal services.

abstract: A grand Union ratification meeting of the Twenty-second Ward was held last evening at the hall corner of Broadway and 27th-st. At an early hour the hall was well filled, and at 8 o'clock was literally packed. In point of respectability, the audience would compare favorably with any ever held in this City. A great many ladies were present. An excellent band was provided, and, with the exception of a few ruffians, McClleanites, who entered the hall for the purpose of creating a disturbance, and by annoying the speakers, and yelling for MCCLELLAN, to break up the meeting, but who, thanks to he efficiency of the police, were quickly quieted and put out. The utmost good feeling prevailed. At 8 o'clock the meeting was called to order, and GEO. T. BRABFORD, Esq., was chosen President, who, after a few introductory remarks, introduced the Rev. H. Mattison, who opened the meeting with prayer. After which the Vice-Presidents and Secretaries were elected, and the following resolutions adopted.

abstract: accompanied by several friends, made a pleasure trip from this city, to Weehawken, New Jersey. Arrived at the landing on the Jersey shore, the party went back a short distance from the river, where they engaged for a short time in an innocent game on the lawn. During the play, three rough-looking men made their appearance, and in a very abrupt and boisterous manner intruded themselves within the ring, which had been formed by the Germans, and their ladies who, were present. Mr. SCHMIDT very politely requested them to retire and cease their annoyance to the party. One of the intruders there upon seized SCHMIDT by the shoulders and dealt him a heavy blow on the head with a club or stick nearly four feet in length and about two inches in diameter SCHMIDT fell to the ground, and remained a long time insensible from the effects of the blows. The father of DANIEL SCHMIDT, being present, interfered to save his son's life, when the same ruffian assaulted him with a club and beat him in a most unmerciful manner. Several other men who expostulated with the intruders shared the same fate. The three men then leisurely left the ground, but after proceeding a short distance, the man who had dealt the blows, turned, and discharged several shots from a revolver, at the Germans. Fortunately none of the shots took effect.

abstract: On Sacrifices of his Comrades, and Chicago Platform
snippet: On Sacrifices of his Comrades, and Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: in his letter of acceptance, confesses that he "could not look in the faces of his gallant comrades" and tell them that "their labors and the sacrifices of so many of our slain and wounded brethren had been in vain." Now, the Chicago platform, on which he stands, explicitly requires him to do precisely the thing that he says he cannot do. He must say the war is a "failure," the blood of our soldiers lost, the wounded wounded in vain, the treasure wasted. He must say it to the soldiers; he must say it to the people; he must say it to other nations. Now let him back up to the front and utter it; for he cannot say it with his face to the auditors. He don't believe it; but he must say it. The infallible Chicago Democracy has decreed it, has ordered all their votaries to utter it; yet he knows that his confession of it would kill Chicago. He had better save his conscience, come out from among the abettors of the rebellion, and work where he can speak the truth like a soldier, and "look the soldiers in the face."

abstract: The Western Union Telegraph Company, who in conjunction with the Russian Government, have this great enterprize in hand, are actively engaged in fitting out an expedition under the immediate supervision of Capt. C.S. BULKLEY, U.S.A., for Oregon,the coast of Russian America, and the country beyond Bhering's Straits to survey the route of the telegraph line and make other needful arrangements to put the whole extent of the line under contract the ensuing year; and we understand that the projectors of the enterprise are sanguine that the line will be in successful operation between New-York, San Francisco, St. Petersburgh and London, by the middle of 1866. Mr. HIRAM SIBLEY, Esq., President of the Western Union and of the Russian Companies, sails in company with Mr. COLLINS, the enterprising projector of the Russian-American telegraph line, in the Scotia to-day for Liverpool and St. Petersburgh, with a view to complete the arrangements already iniated with the Russian government for expediating the early completion of the line.

abstract: There has never been a season for very many years, when there has been as many infected foreign ports, or a season when so many vessels infected with yellow fever, have arrived at this port. Owing to the close surveillance and great precautions adopted by Dr. SWINBURN, Health Officer, and his deputies, Drs. WALSER and BURDETT, not a single case of the fever has occurred in this City or Brooklyn traceable to Quarantine. A very few cases have occurred in the City, but they were directly traceable to the schooner Christopher Pendleton, from Key West, which put into New-London, Conn. Rigid as may be considered the regulations of Quarantine, their entire enforcement in regard to infected vessels and vessels from infected ports, alone has saved us from the terrible scourge of yellow fever.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a season for very many years, when there has been as many infected foreign ports, or a season when so many vessels infected with yellow fever, have arrived at this port. abstract: The Bureau of Public Instruction of the Citizens' Association having visited and inspected all our Public Schools, pay attention in their report to the number of hours the children, especially the younger ones, are required to study. They say that five or six hours of quietude and muscular inactivity, with only occasional variations of position, and during...
lead_paragraph: The Bureau of Public Instruction of the Citizens' Association having visited and inspected all our Public Schools, pay attention in their report to the number of hours the children, especially the younger ones, are required to study. They say that five or six hours of quietude and muscular inactivity, with only occasional variations of position, and during this time continued attention and mental [???] by very young children, say from six or seven to ten years of age, is a process against which nature and reason protest by every indication or restlessness weariness and languid listlessness. It is not uncommon to find the young children in the public schools of this City falling asleep in the middle of a lesson, utterly exhausted by the unnatural tax upon their powers, while others are restless, eager for mischief, or anything else that will serve to break the routine of exercises which overstrains their faculties and gives no scope for the muscular activity which nature craves. The evil effects of the common bodily constraints during long hours in school are seriously manifested on girls and especially on those of frail constitutions. The evidence is abundant that the aggravation of children's ailments is due to the forced inactivity and constrained positions of the school, and the best teachers tell us that children between seven and ten years of age do not and cannot retain a bright, voluntary attention on the average longer than two hours in the morning and one in the afternoon, or after dinner. This whole subject needs careful revision, and a wiser adaption of time and methods of instruction to the natural wants and capacities of children, and to the laws of physiology and sanitary science, and we confidently hope that our Bureau of Public Instruction may be instrumental of salutary improvements in the public schools of this city.

abstract: The steamship City of London arrived here yesterday from Liverpool with dates to the 8th instant. Her news has been anticipated by the Sidon at Halifux and the Hirbernia at Father Point. The news of the arrest of the alleged murderer FRANZ MULLER at New-York caused very general satisfaction throught England. The papers have nothing new to say on American [???]. The action of the Chicago Convention was awaited with much interest. The organs of the Austrian Cabinet seem greatly annoyed at the dispatch of a special ambassador to the Italian Court by the Emperor MAXIMILIAN, on the ground that it will give great offence at Rome. The Mexican minister to Switzerland presented his credentials to the Federal Council on the 6th instant.

abstract: The recepts of Live Stock show a supply of 5,567 beeves, 149 milch cows, 2,799 calves, 25,051 sheep and lambs, and 11,105 swine, making a total of 46,671 animals. The aggregate weights are nearly 8,000 heavier than last week, there being an increase of all kinds of stock except beef cattle. The number of beef cattle offered this week is nearly 1,500 less than the previous week, but receipts were then unusually large....
lead_paragraph: The recepts of Live Stock show a supply of 5,567 beeves, 149 milch cows, 2,799 calves, 25,051 sheep and lambs, and 11,105 swine, making a total of 46,671 animals. The aggregate weights are nearly 8,000 heavier than last week, there being an increase of all kinds of stock except beef cattle. The number of beef cattle offered this week is nearly 1,500 less than the previous week, but receipts were then unusually large The market at Forty-fourth street has been fairly active at a slight advance on former rates, on the best offerings, if not on the lowest class of cattle. While medium to good quality bullocks have sold at about 15c.@18 1/2c., a few of the choicest of the market have reached 19c.@19 1/2c.; a few, on large estimates, have doubtless brought 20c. for the four quarters; 8c.@14c. has been obtained on the lower grades. Sheep have arrived in much, larger numbers than last week, and show a slight decline, but good sheep are still commanding high prices, selling at 8 1/2c.@9c., and a few at 9 1/4c. Sales of 3,038 lambs at $5 16 head. They rate at 10c.@10 1/2c. lb., live weight, for those of good quality. Swine show an improvement in price as well as in receipts; the advance being mainly in prime corn-fed hogs, which are quoted at 14c.@15c.; live weight; still-fed at 12c.@13c.; stock, 7c.@9c.

abstract: "We begin to get some light," says the Independence Belge, upon the conspiracy which the Austrian police has discovered in the Italian Tyrol and Venetia. It appears that the party of action in Italy had in reality planned, some months ago a general rising in arms. It had its arms and its soldiers all ready, and its ramifications and projects extended beyond the hortiers of Italy. The first blows were to be struck in the Austrian possessions. This plan was postponed or abandoned during the stay of Garibaldi at Ischia; but the plans and the depots of arms existed, and the Austrian police put on their track has begun to arrest the persons most compromised. After arrests upon arrests, it has proceeded to make a complete razzia, not only among the adherents of the party of action, but even in the ranks of the moderate party, which naturally desire the reunion of the country to Italy, but without looking to conspiracies for the realization of its hopes. A crowd of young men of the best families, who can only be accused of holding patriotic opinions have been taken beyond the Alps to the fortress of Innspruys where there awaits them a monstrous trial, the result of which, which, whatever it may be, will add nothing to the moral force or the security of the Austrian Government!

abstract: Victory in the Valley
snippet: Victory in the Valley
lead_paragraph: The signal victory in the Shenandoah Valley on Monday is one of that class which permits no cavil either as to its scope or its completeness. At the opening of the battle EARLY'S force, which, by Confederate accounts, has been positively put down at 27,000, was posted mainly at Bunker Hill, near Winchester, and at Darkesville. The Upequan creek was between our forces and the rebels and their works extended at some points on the centre and left to within three miles of the river. SHERIDAN's line extended, early in the engagement, over five miles in length, from Berryville towards Bunker Hill. The attack was made by our cavalry under AVERILL by gray daylight on Monday, BRECKINRIDGE's division, posted near Darkesville, having been steadily driven a distance of seven miles, by one o'clock in the afternoon. The attack of our main army also commenced early in the morning at the point where the Opequan Creek is crossed by the Berryville turnpike. From this point our forces, by a series of stubborn and sanguinary engagements which lasted until 5 o'clock in the afternoon, compelled the rebels te fall back, completely defeated EARLY's main army, and drove it from one defended line of works to another, until what remained of the routed force, as Gen. STEVENSON tells us, was "sent whirling through Winchester;" all their dead, most of their wounded, and two thousand five hundred prisoners being left on our hands. The wounded in Winchester alone are found to number three thousand, and if the dead are counted in, the rebel loss will be found to exceed six thousand, or about one-fourth of the entire army under EARLY. In trophies and material our gain is also notable; fifteen army flags and five pieces of artillery having fallen into the possession of our army.
headline: {'main': 'The Victory in the Shenandoah Valley.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victory in the Shenandoah Valley.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: William P. Dinsmore agt. Gustav P. Cluseret. This was a motion to vacate the injunction heretofore obtained restraining the defendant from publishing a paper known as the New Nation. abstract: THE GREAT TROTTING RACE AT THE FASHION COURSE TO-DAY -- HEALTHY BETTING. -- The great trotting race that comes off at the Fashion Course to-day between those renowned horses, Gen. Butler, Lady Emma, John Morgan and Prince, is creating a perfect furore in the sporting circle, and from the fame, number and diversity of opinions concerning the merits of the horses, the betting is diversified and truly immense in quantity. Butler was up to recently the leaning favorite, but within a day or two Lady Emma has come with a rush and passed him in the betting. In the pools sold at Lafavette Hall on Monday evening, she brought $1,000, Butler $600, Prince $400, and John Morgan $150. The rates of those sold on the Union Course to-day were relatively $150 for Emma, $80 for Butler, Prince $52, Morgan $20. In outside betting $3,000 to $1,000 was offered, that Emma beat Morgan in the race, and $2,000 to $1,000 that she beat Butler. The pools sold on the course this forenoon, will, however, give the correct cue to the market price of each. The attendance, if the day is fair, will be immense, and those who desire to avoid the crowd and dust will do well to take an early departure by road or rail. A large attendance of ladies is anticipated, for whom ample preparations have been made. A large Metropolitan police force will be in attendance.

abstract: Brigadier-General DAVIS A. RUSSELL, who fell in the battle of Sept. 19th, near Winchester, was  a native of  New-York. He graduated at West Point, in 1845. As served in the Mexican war, and was brevetted "for gallant and meritorious conduct in several affairs with guerilleros, at Paso Ovejays, National Bridge and Corro Gordo." He went into the psesent war against the rebels as Lieut.-Col. of the Seventh Massachusetts Volunteers, attached to the Sixth Army Corps. He served with distinction through the campaign on the Peninsula, and was commissioned a Brigadier General in December, 1862, just after the battle of Fredericksburg. He afterwards commanded a brigade, in Gen. HOWE's division, Sixth Army Corps, and subsequently commanded the division. He was a brave and meritorious officer, and his loss will be deeply felt.
lead_paragraph: Brigadier-General DAVIS A. RUSSELL, who fell in the battle of Sept. 19th, near Winchester, was a native of New-York. He graduated at West Point, in 1845. abstract: with Rebels, Bearings of; World, N Y; On Armistice With Rebels
snippet: with Rebels, Bearings of; World, N Y; On Armistice With Rebels
lead_paragraph: Speaking on Friday of the danger of an armistice between us and the rebels, we said: "Nor are the probable consequences of an armistice between us and the rebels surrounded by any mist or uncertainty. These are just as well known as the probable consequences of jumping off a housetop into the street. An armistice, failing all stipulations to the contrary -- and it is not for the party asking for it, and confessing in the same breath that his fighting has been 'a failure,' to impose conditions -- leaves the belligerent forces in precisely the same position as that in which it finds them."

abstract: Name used by Copperheads; Flourishes About the Union
snippet: Name used by Copperheads; Flourishes About the Union
lead_paragraph: As the cat hid herself under the meal when all other expedients failed, so the Copperheads now hide themselves under profession for the Union. But the shift won't answer. The people know exactly what is concealed there. There has never been a time when VALLANDIGHAM and FERNANDO WOOD and SEYMOUR did not profess an unalterable determination never to give up the Union. On that matter we can cheerfully bear witness that their record is clear from the start. They have always protested the necessity of keeping the Union unbroken. VALLANDIGHAM framed the Chicago platform, and turned out the first resolution about unswerving fidelity to the Union, with as little hesitation as any other.

abstract: The country will be electrified this morning by the announcement of another brilliant victory -a most complete, telling and decisive route of the rebels under EARLY in the Shenandoah Valley, who were attacked on Monday morning by SHERIDAN, in their chosen and fortified position, and after a most sanguinary battle, lasting till dark, the rebels were driven back and through Winchester, with the loss of three thousand prisoners, fifteen battle-flags, five pieces of artillery, while their killed and wounded all fell into our hands. The battle began on the Opequan Creek, between Bunker Hill and Winchester, at about 12 o'clock on Monday, SHERIDAN making the attack in splendid style, his columns massed, and advancing with colors flying and bands playing. The battle raged until dark, the defeat of the rebels being complete. They were driven back through Winchester, with a loss of not less than five thousand killed and wounded, beside their prisoners. Among their losses are Gens. RODES, GORDON, WHARTON and RAMSOUR killed, and BRADLEY P. JOHNSON and YORK wounded. SHERIDAN'S loss was also severe. Gen. RUSSELL, commanding a division in the Sixth Corps, was killed, and Gens. UPTON, MCINTOSH and CHAPMAN wounded. The cavalry bore a most conspicuous part in the battle, and made the final successful charge of the day. The reader must look to our full accounts for the details of this splendid achievement.

The battle raged until dark, the defeat of the rebels being complete. They were driven back through Winchester, with a loss of not less than five thousand killed and wounded, beside their prisoners. Among their losses are Gens. RODES, GORDON, WHARTON and RAMSOUR killed, and BRADLEY P. JOHNSON and YORK wounded. SHERIDAN'S loss was also severe. Gen. abstract: Mr. GROVER has every reason to feel satisfied with the results, both here and in Brooklyn, of the first week of German opera under his management. Notwithstanding the occasional hostility of the elements, he has succeeded in attracting overflowing audiences to no fewer than six performances. To obtain this amount of work he has been compelled to materially strengthen his company, and as the run is still upon "Faust" it is sometimes necessary to relieve one set of singers by substituting another in their places. This was the case at the Matinee on Saturday, when the Mephistophiles and the Siebel were both different to what we had on Thursday -- the former being played by Herr WEINLICH and the latter by Fraulein CANISSA. As a matter of choice we prefer the first incumbents of the parts, but it is none the less creditable to Mr. GROVER to be thus stronghanded. The attendance on Saturday was extremely brilliant, all the pretty girls were there, and their bright toilettes made the parquet look like a bed of flowers.

abstract: Address on State Sovereignty, at Yale College; Ruggles' Address; Ruggles', S B, Address on, and Washington's Letter
snippet: Address on State Sovereignty, at Yale College; Ruggles' Address; Ruggles', S B, Address on, and Washington's Letter
lead_paragraph: What then were the surrounding accessories, and what the immediate antecedents, which gave to our Class of 1814 its form and features? Historically and chronologically speaking, nearly all of our number were born shortly after the foundation of our present National Government. All of us lived in the atmosphere breathed by WASHINGTON. Many of our number first saw the light during the French Revolution, amid the horrors of the Reign of Terror. When the good king, Louis the Sixteenth, the friend of American independence, was beheaded, some of the Class were old enough to hear the widespread groan, coming heavily across the Atlantic. While at school we heard the shouts of the victors at Aboukir and Trafalgar. We followed on our maps, "the Little Corporal" from Lodi to Marengo, to Jena and to Austerlitz. In the year 1810, when we entered college, the French Emperor had reached the summit, the very culminating point of his victorious career. He stood pre-eminent and aloft, at once the dominant power and the terror of the world. Europe was ringing with the crash of its ancient thrones, and he was rebuilding on their ruins the Western Roman Empire of Charlemagne, and ambitiously imitating that of Augustus.

abstract: Academy reopened yesterday for the First Term of the Academic Year 1864-5. The attendance of members of former classes who had been promoted to higher ones at the last examination, and of graduates of Ward Schools newly admitted into this institution, was full, amounting in the aggregate to 720. It may interest the public as well as these young men, to learn that ELISHA RIGGS, Esq., banker, of the firm of JEROME & RIGGS, has by a generous donation of $1,000, founded two gold medals, to be awarded annually, forever; one to the author of the best English Prose Composition in the Senior Class, the other to the author of the best in the Junior Class. This liberal gift, while most honorable to Mr. RIGGS, cannot but greatly stimulate the ardor of the students in this highly important branch of education.

abstract: Serenaded at Washington, and Defines his Position; Ex-Secretary, and B F Wade; Speeches of
snippet: Serenaded at Washington, and Defines his Position; Ex-Secretary, and B F Wade; Speeches of
lead_paragraph: Ex-Secretary CHASE defined his political position at the present crisis in a speech which he delivered to a popular assemblage in Washington on Monday evening. As a matter of course, he took high and patriotic ground in favor of President LINCOLN, the Baltimore platform, and the Union party. He said that the names of LINCOLN and JOHNSON "represent to-day principles and a policy, designs and purposes, by which alone this country can be saved. If all the voters would take my advice, there would not be a vote cast except for these two gentlemen;" and he added that, in his judgment, a large majority of votes would be given for them. Mr. CHASE then proceeded to discuss the Baltimore platform, and closed this point by asking: "Which of the planks in our platform do you want taken out? Do you want any one shaved a single particle? No, no; let it stand as it is. It is all good. Let us maintain it all." He farther announced that he proposed soon to go to his own great State in the West, there to advocate the cause so dear to us all.

abstract: at the book-trade sale yesterday afternoon, at 4:30 o'clock, on the question of the next Presidency. All the members of the trade present in favor of LINCOLN mere requested to stand, and forty-three gentlemen immedietely rose and stood, a solid and compact body. Those in favor of MCCLELLAN were asked to stand up, and seven gentlemen -- a sorry representation -- rose up in different parts of the room. Three rousing cheers were then given for the next President, A. LINCOLN.

abstract: on National and State Sovereignty
snippet: on National and State Sovereignty
lead_paragraph: In another portion of to-day's issue, we make room for a valuable extract from the Semi-Centennial Address, recently delivered by Mr. S. B. RUGGLES, at Yale College, to the Class of 1814. After a full review of the academic progress of the college, in science and letters, a condensed and logical argument is presented, -- under the unpretending form of a historical review, -- of the vitally important question now convulsing the country, of the supremacy of the sovereignty of the American Union, accompanied by historical references of much interest. We commend it to careful consideration, and would particularly call attention to the line of demarcation drawn with almost mathematical precision between the portion of "sovereignty" clearly carved out, and expressly granted to, and irrevocably vested in the "General Government of the Union," -- and the remaining portion or residuum embracing the residue, and only the residue, or "residuary" sovereignty over the portion not granted to the Union but reserved to the States or the people.

abstract: Movements; Rebel Press Ideas on
snippet: Movements; Rebel Press Ideas on
lead_paragraph: We quoted the other day from the Richmond Examiner an article giving the rebel idea as to what were and would be GRANT'S present and future military movements. The Richmond theory was, that since the fall of Atlanta, GRANT had set to work bringing troops from SHERMAN's army into Virginia, and that when he got sufficient force concentrated in the latter State, he would open a great course of military operations against Richmond. This idea has taken firm hold of the rebel mind; and their journals continue to write about it with great earnest ness, and with an evident impression that there would be imminent danger to the rebel capital and the rebel Confederacy if the plan which they fear be really adopted. The Examiner of last Friday says that "an impression prevails, and it is fortified by several concurring considerations and circumstances, that Petersburg and Richmond are to receive the force of the shock;" and of the circumstances that lead to this conclusion is the information the rebels have that "Federal troops are hastening up the Mississippi, and that recruits are being sent to GRANT and SHERIDAN as fast as can be brought." After giving this news, the Examiner remarks:

abstract: Action of Three Great Powers on
snippet: Action of Three Great Powers on
lead_paragraph: -- There is a report by the Persia of great interest, if it can be considered true, that France, England and Russia have at last agreed upon a decided policy in regard to Denmark, which will save her from the absolute spoliation marked out for her by the German Powers. The report receives some confirmation from the complaints of the Vienna press, and from the cotemporaneous visit of the Prince of Wales and the eldest son of the Emperor of Russia to Elsinore. It seems not unlikely that the whole question will be brought under revision.

abstract: Prisoners at Washington Cheer McClellan Flag
snippet: Prisoners at Washington Cheer McClellan Flag
lead_paragraph: last a squad of rebel prisoners was marched through Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, on their way to their place of detention. Passing under the LINCOLN and JOHNSON flag, they greeted it with hisses and groans; but on reaching the MCCLELLAN and PENDLETON banner they stopped and gave it three hearty enthusiastic cheers. Our "Democratic" brethren ought to have provided for letting this portion of our "present adversaries" vote in November. Probably they would have done so where they had the power, if they had supposed we should have had so many of them in our hands. GRANT, SHERMAN, SHERIDAN, and CO. have sadly interfered with their calculations.

abstract: A salute of thirteen guns was fired here this evening in honor of SHERIDAN's victory, and an immense concourse gathered at the City Hall, where addresses were made by Col. FITZGERALD and A.G. CATTELL, Esq., of Philadelphia. After the meeting adjourned, the whole assembly marched to the residence of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, and cheered enthusiastically for the Generals, the army and navy, and the Union, the band in the meantime playing national airs.

abstract: As the details of Gen. SHERIDAN'S victory come to hand, its proportions and completeness are largely increased.
lead_paragraph: As the details of Gen. SHERIDAN'S victory come to hand, its proportions and completeness are largely increased. The latest intelligence from Gen. SHERIDAN is contained in a dispatch from Gen. STEVENSON, at Harper's Ferry, to Secretary STANTON, which announces that on Tuesday at three o'clock, our army was in vigorous pursuit of the rebels, and had already crossed Cedar Creek, eighteen miles south of Winchester. There was no fighting at that hour. The number of prisoners had been swelled to five thousand by additional captures. The indications are that the rebels will not make a stand short of Staunton. The following list of rebel Generals killed and wounded is correct: Gens. Rodes, Ramsour, Gordon, Terry, Goodwin, Bradley Johnson and Fitzhugh Lee.

abstract: Requirements by, and Democratic Party
snippet: Requirements by, and Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: The Democratic party having pronounced the war a failure, but being still as determined as ever not to give the Union up, the obvious inference is, that it means, if it gets into power, to restore it by talking to JEFFERSON DAVIS. What they have to say to him is simplyto request him to come back under the Constitution. And their grand resource, in case he neglects or refuses to comply, is to ask him again. Their idea, no doubt, is, that the Confederates can be bored into a resumption of their allegiance. They imagine that if a few of the Democratic orators, such as make night hideous now and then on Union-square, could get a good chance at the rebel Congress, the rascals would cry for mercy, and take the oath before their persecutors had got half through. We are sorry to say, however, that we cannot concur in this view of rebel susceptibility. We are satisfied that the great mass of Southern traitors are tough enough to stand any amount even of Democratic speech-making. The chance of subduing them by dint of rant is infinitessimally small. If the tongue is to bring them back at all, it must be by offering something substantial. And what can our Democrats offer? There's the rub. What they now propose to offer is "the Constitution as it is -- the old Constitution." But JEFF. DAVIS has tried the old Constitution, and has not found it to suit him. He had it when he seceded. He knows all about it; just what it can do, and what it can't do. Our Peace party cannot offer to make any changes in it, because their grand cry is, that it cannot be changed; it cannot be improved; that it is perfect; that, as the World says, it is in politics what the Gospels are in religion. Besides, it is the Northern people who are tampering with the Constitution; it is they who have violated, and are violating it; it is they who, by their designs against its integrity, are bringing ruin on the country. It would never do for Democrats to lay violent hands on it. So DAVIS must take "the Constitution as it is."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The sale of private boxes for the forthcoming season of the Italian opera, under Mr. MAX MARETZEK's management, opened yesterday, and the few hours result which we can report were eminently satisfactory. In "the memory of the oldest inhabitant" there has never been such a "rush" for the favored locations. It was so sweeping that, we are informed, but few boxes remain to be sold. Indeed the eagerness of certain parties was so great that premiums were offered for privileges that could not be conceded in that way -- Mr. MARETZEK's rule being that the first who comes shall be the first who is served. To-day the sale of reserved seats commences, and to-night we shall know something more of the rage that prevails for musical entertainments. It is pleasant to feel -- whilst in the midst of this excitement -- that we have now a manager who will repay all the generosity of the public Mr. MARETZEK's European artists, by the way, are expected on the Persia -- now due at this port.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Persia at this port, last evening, we have European advices to Sept. 11. The news is very important. It is reported that a new and formidable rebel privateer had arrived at Bremerhaven, from Bordeaux, that she had a crew of 300 men, is pierced for 40 guns, and is to be commanded by Capt. SEMMES, lately of the Alabama. Three vessels of the same class are also said to be in process of construction at Bordeaux. Mr. BATES, the injured owner of the captured ex-pirate Georgia, has received an official notification from Lord RUSSELL in answer to his complaint against the Niagara, that he had better apply to a U.S. Prize Court for redress. Marshal MCMAHON has been appointed Governor General of Algeria. The Danish question develops fresh difficulties, owing to the reluctance of Denmark to submit to the demands of the German Powers, and it is rumored that an alliance has been formed between Russia, France and England to preserve Schleswig at all hazards to Denmark. There are reports that Austria will soon recognize the Kingdom of Italy, and King George of Greece.

abstract: has received orders from Washington to begin the draft in the First and Tenth Districts to-morrow. abstract: By the Persia the exciting news comes that a large steamer is reported to have put into Nieuwe-diep on Saturday, the 3d instant, with French colors flying. Having signaled for a pilot, she had one put on board, and immediately thereafter she sailed, under Prussian colors, for Bremerhaven, the outer port of Bremen. At Bremerhaven the steamer hoisted the Confederate flag. To this report the rumors are added that the vessel still remains at Bremerhaven; that she steams ten miles an hour at half speed; that she is commanded by SEMMES; was built at Bordeaux; has three hundred men on board and forty guns -- a formidable craft, if the story be true, which is extremely doubtful.

abstract: The demand for discount at the Bank on the 9th inst, was extremely heavy, owing to an exceptional pressure occasioned by the large amount of India bills payable on Sept. 10. Ordinary Banks and discount brokers manifested great caution, but there was no difficulty in negotiating sound commercial bills at the existing rates, with exceptional transactions at a fraction lower.

lead_paragraph: Pursuant to an order of Major-Gen. SANDFORD, a Court-martial, consisting of Col. POSTLEY, President, Third New-York; Col. WARD, Twelfth NewYork, and Col. WILCOX, Ninth New-York, met yesterday afternoon, at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, to try Col. JOACHIM MAIDHOFF, Eleventh New-York, on certain charges preferred against him by Col. HAMILTON, Division Inspector. The charges grow but of the alleged refusal of Col. MAIDHOFF to proceed with his command to Washington, under the call for one hundred days men. Major CHARLES A. RAPPALO appeared as Judge-Advocate, and Mr. HENRY R. CUMMINGS attended in behalf of the accused.

abstract: Victory in the Valley
snippet: Victory in the Valley
lead_paragraph: The clear supplementary reports which we publish this morning from our special correspondents and from official sources, so far from detracting from the importance of SHERIDAN'S victory, do but illustrate the carefullyconceived plans, the matured purpose, the resolute action, and the matchless valor by which the national army achieved its triumph.The modest statement of SHERIDAN does scant justice to the brilliancy of the achievement, but in truth the story needs no coloring. In its simplest and baldest form, it supplies a record of skillful generalship, executive energy and decision, such as will well compare with the most brilliant of the war. Even the partial miscarriage (for in every grand engagement there will be some miscarriage) of one part of the commanding General's plan of action only brings into stronger relief the quickness of his perception, the wealth of his resources as a tactician, and, above all, that readiness of decision to which the foremost of English Generals attributed his success. The Nineteenth Corps should have come up with the Sixth at Opequan Creek two hours earlier than it did. To an irresolute or purblind leader those two hoors would have been fatal. To SHERIDAN they brought inspiration. Resigning his first plan of striking out heavily with his left on the extreme right flank of the enemy and getting in his rear at Winchester, he ordered as powerful a diversion as could be made by our cavalry on the enemy's left, between Darkesville and Bunker Hill. By this EARLY was prevented from striking the isolated Sixth with sufficient force to turn those critical hours to account. The three corps, (WRIGHT's, EMORY's and CROOK's,) in spite of all the delay, were concentrated across the Opequan in ample time to hurl back the powerful force now thrown out from EARLY's right, and thenceforward the tide of victory rolled on with uninterrupted success. How perfect in all its details, how far-reaching in its results, this triumph will prove to be, we shall learn anon. SHERIDAN is not to allow the grass to grow under the feet of his army. The battle of Monday ended at near sundown, and weary-worn as his men must have been, they seem to have taken up the line of march with scarce an hour's interval of repose. By 3 o'clock on Tuesday, SHERIDAN had pursued the retreating rebels almost to Strasburgh. In spite of this vigorous pursuit, however, the routed army, shattered and broken as it was, and relieved of most of its many incumbrances, would seem to have made sufficient use of its legs to avoid a second battle. The official report represents it as altogether demoralized -- a fact entirely appreciable when we read in the latest telegrams that seven of EARLY's best Generals are either killed or put out of the field. These Generals include such names as RODES, RAMSEUR, GORDON, TERRY, GODWIN, BRADLEY, JOHNSON and FITZHUGH LEE. And along with these there fell in battle or were captured of the rebel rank and file not fewer than six thousand five hundred.

abstract: Cemetery commenced yesterday. The graveyard has been closed for about fifteen years. During that time some of the bodies have been removed by their friends and relatives to other cemeteries. There are at present the remains of about one hundred and fifty of the dead to be carried away. When the cemetery was closed, the trustees of St. Mark's purchased two acres in the Evergreen Cemetery, where the bodies not disposed of by their friends will be removed. The remains of two dramatic notables, BARNES and PRICE, of the Old Park Theatre, have been removed from this cemetery.

abstract: Interfere with Elections by their Victories
snippet: Interfere with Elections by their Victories
lead_paragraph: We understand that complaints of undue military interference are no longer confined to the Copperheads. The Union Committees for the Presidential Campaign find their labors rendered superfluous by the achievments of our military authorities. It is very clear that if Secretary STANTON continues the vigorous movements of the last few weeks, the election may be regarded as a foregone conclusion. The Document Committee at Washington especially find that SHERMAN's and SHERIDAN's short reports of their victories throw into the background completely all the documents they have been able to circulate. They make Union voters a great deal faster than all the speeches ever made in Congress. It is pretty clear that GRANT is actually chairman of the only Union National Committee of much importance in the pending canvas. BELMONT will find him a troublesome customer to deal with.

abstract: MANUFACTORY. A VERDICT OF CENSURE. An inquest was held on Wednesday, by Coroner WILDEY, on the body of Miss MARY E. CLIFFORD, the young lady who fell through the hatchway of HERRING'S safe manufactory, on the corner of Hudson and West Thirteenth streets, on Monday evening last, as published in the TIEES.
lead_paragraph: MANUFACTORY. -- A VERDICT OF CENSURE. -- An inquest was held on Wednesday, by Coroner WILDEY, on the body of Miss MARY E. CLIFFORD, the young lady who fell through the hatchway of HERRING'S safe manufactory, on the corner of Hudson and West Thirteenth streets, on Monday evening last, as published in the TIEES. She died in a very short time after the accident. The testimony in the case showed that the hatch on the fourth floor, through which deceased fell, was wholly unprotected, and always had been in an unsafe condition. A portion of the premises were occupied by Mr. C.T. PORTER. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that MARY E. CLIFFORD came to her death from injuries received by falling through the hatchway, from the fourth to the first floor, of a building occupied by SILAS C. HERRING & Co., and CHAS. T. PORTER, at the corner of Hudson and West Thirteenth streets, on the 19th day of September, 1864. We would censure SILAS C. HERRING & Co., and CHAS. T. PORTER, for allowing said hatchway to remain in an unprotected and dangerous condition."

abstract: Public Record and Present Reticence; Working for the Union
snippet: Public Record and Present Reticence; Working for the Union
lead_paragraph: It is a fortunate circumstance that the Copperhead nominee for the Vice-Presidency has a public record relative to the war, so complete and so distinct. Gen. McCLELLAN has nothing of the kind. He has never been in any civil position, and probably would never have been thought of for any one of much responsibility, had it not been that his party believed it could turn his military fortunes to advantage. Never called upon to take part in legislation, he has never practically committed himself to any specific measures. We can look only to his words and his military acts, for his opinions about the war. But his words are vague generalities, evidently framed more to satisfy an easy trust than to express earnest convictions; and his military acts are either so inconsistent or so equivocal, that it is a matter of serious dispute what his war policy was, or whether in fact he ever had any heart in the war at all. Even to this day, though his party has made a perfectly open and square platform, his best friends do not know enough about him to say positively whether it tallies with his opinions or not.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Notwithstanding the attraction of Herr FORMES' name, and the addition of Mme. ROTTER to the cast, there was by no means a large attendance to witness the last performance of "Martha." The work has been rather frequently
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Notwithstanding the attraction of Herr FORMES' name, and the addition of Mme. ROTTER to the cast, there was by no means a large attendance to witness the last performance of "Martha." The work has been rather frequently played, and Thursday is not a good night for the average opera goer. Moreover, on this occasion it was sandwiched between operas that were decidedly more attractive, such as "Faust" and the "Jewess." It is always amiable to account for poor nights, although by no means pleasant to record their occurrence.

abstract: and British Panic; London Times Correspondent; London Times Correspondent Concocting Panics
snippet: and British Panic; London Times Correspondent; London Times Correspondent Concocting Panics
lead_paragraph: An English stock operator, dependent for success on his knowledge of American affairs, is certainly to be pitied. He reads the London Times -- especially the City Article -- with implicit confidence; he studies carefully the letters of the "special correspondent," and then makes his ventures. About six weeks ago he was duly instructed by these trustworthy informants, that a grand conspiracy was being contrived by which a Convention of all the States of our Union was to be called, and the Peace Democrats of the North were to unite with the whilom rebels of the South, and together they were to take possession, by force and fraud, of the Government at Washington, oust Mr. LINCOLN and disband the armies -- forming a new Union founded on Revolution.
headline: {'main': 'The British Panic.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The British Panic.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Secretary STANTON telegraphs that dispatches have been received from Gen. SHERIDAN up to 9 o'clock Wednesday night. A portion of the enemy's force which turned off toward Front Royal Gap, had been pursued and driven in disorder by our cavalry.
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON telegraphs that dispatches have been received from Gen. SHERIDAN up to 9 o'clock Wednesday night. A portion of the enemy's force which turned off toward Front Royal Gap, had been pursued and driven in disorder by our cavalry. The rebel infantry, under EARLY, had retreated to a point beyond Strasburgh, south of Tumbling Run, where they made a stand in an intrenched position known as Flint or Fisher's Hill. SHERIDAN attacked and carried the crest of the hill and held it at night. Secretary STANTON says there is reason to believe that later dispatches from SHERIDAN have been captured by MOSBY, who, as usual, is operating in our rear. The town of Strasburgh, in Virginia, beyond which point Gen. SHERIDAN's forces had driven the rebels, is a station on the Manassas Gap Railroad, eighteen miles southwest of Winchester. Staunton, the place toward which the shattered forces of the rebels are supposed to be retreating, is the capital of Augusta County, and lies southwest of Strasburgh. Its distance from Richmond is one hundred and twenty miles.

abstract: By order of the Chamber of Commerce a committee of that body, consisting of Messrs. GEORGE W. BLUNT, J.D. JONES and J.A. STAVRNS, Jr. have collected and republished a number of documents bearing upon the protection and preservation of our harbor. Most of these papers were originally compiled and written through the agency of a commission named by the State Legislature in 1855, but they have quite as important a bearing now as they did then upon the commercial interests of our City. In spite of the energetic and indefatigable labors of the Pilot Commissioners, in defiance of the stringent laws passed by the Legislature to prevent this very result, encroachments are constantly in progress, which, if allowed to continue, will ultimately seriously impair our harbor and deprive it of its supremacy. The reports of Superintendent BACH[???], of the United States C[???] Survey, with the various remonstrances and documents contained in this volume and the accompanying charts and diagrams, showing how the encroachments have progressed, and how they may be guarded against and remedied, deserve to be carefully studied and pondered by every ne of our citizens.

abstract: Union Speech at Brooklyn; Union Speech at Brooklyn; Union Speech at Brooklyn
snippet: Union Speech at Brooklyn; Union Speech at Brooklyn; Union Speech at Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The first of a series of patriotic gatherings to be held under the auspices of the Central Union Club of Brooklyn, took place last evening at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn. It was a grand success both in respect to enthusiasm and numbers. The spacious building was crowded from pit to dome, and all the available space either for sitting or standing, was fully occupied. Hundreds of ladies were compelled to stand during the entire meeting. Outside stands had been erected on Montague-street, from which speakers addressed immense gatherings of those who had been unable to get within the the building. Not less than twenty thousand people were assembled within and without, and the proceedings were protracted to a late hour.

abstract: on McClellan and the Democratic Party; were Southern Measures
snippet: on McClellan and the Democratic Party; were Southern Measures
lead_paragraph: is carrying on against sovereign States; of the violation of the Constitutional rights of sovereign States. Now, it is unnecessary to remind the country that the Monroe doctrine, the Mexican war, the annexation of Texas and the Cuba question were pet Democratic measures, and Southern measures per se. The animus of the Southern Democratic party, as involved in these policies, was, that any attempt on the part of England to acquire Texas, or Spain to regain Mexico, or France and England to hold Cuba, was a menace to the National security and dignity in which the South then shared. The North backed the doctrine. Cuba, for instance, belonged to Spain, but the South said she had no right to do as she pleased with her own, and the Democratic party stood ready to fight the world on this issue of National dignity, National right, and National security. These Southern leader are now preparing to do on this Continent, that very thing against which they demanded the opposition of the United States Government. They propose to establish a Nation as the rival of American power, and this rival nation is to rest on European alliances for support. When these disunionists formed this so-called Confederacy, they sought to create a nation based upon alliances and complications far more threatening to the United States than the tripartite convention about Cuba, or the French occupation of Mexico, or the English scheme in Texas. The United States Government is not making war upon States. The disunionists formed their so-called nation on the 4th of February, 1864, Mr. LINCOLN was inaugurated on the 4th of March afterwards. It is confronting the very issue which the Democratic party has always said justified war. We are fighting for our nationality.

abstract: Soon after 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a serious and probably fatal shooting affray occurred in the parlor of Dr. ISSACHER ZACHARIE, the well-known chiropodist, residing and doing business at No. 768 Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Soon after 10 o'clock yesterday morning, a serious and probably fatal shooting affray occurred in the parlor of Dr. ISSACHER ZACHARIE, the well-known chiropodist, residing and doing business at No. 768 Broadway. The injuries inflicted on Dr. Z. are of an aggravated nature. The facts and circumstances, so far as we have been able to learn them, are as follows: For some time past, Dr. ZACHARIE and Mr. SAMUEL M. BARNETT, also a chiropodist, had been practicing as partners in the City of Philadelphia. Recently the partnership was dissolved, and BARNETT came on to this City, bringing with him the copartnership books and papers, also other personal property -all of which were temporarily placed in the possession of Dr. ZACHARIE. A little over a week since the latter was called to Washington. Before leaving, he requested BARNETT to take charge of his office, and transact his business until he returned -- all of which BARNETT did. Last Monday morning Dr. Z. reached his home in this City, and BARNETT soon after called on him and paid over to him such moneys as he had received in a professional way during the Doctor's absence. ZACHARIE received the money and offered BARNETT hail of it for his services. BARNETT threw the money back, and in an angry tone of voice said he wanted none of his money. Dr. ZACHARIE then asked him what he did want. An insulting reply was received in answer to this question, whereupon the two became involved in a very angry discussion, curing which BARNETT was ordered by the Doctor to leave his premises, and admonished never to return. BARNETT started to leave the room, and as he was going out, said to the Doctor that if he would go with him to the street, he (BARNETT) would have his revenge. Dr. ZACHARIE followed his opponent down stairs, but nothing further of importance transpired at that time. Yesterday, BARNETT again made his appearance at the Doctor's office and asked the latter for the books and papers which he said belonged to him. As Dr. ZACHARIE was in the act of taking them from a drawer, BARNETT arose from a seat, and deliberately drawing a live barreled revolver, said, "My time has come." or words to that effect, and suddenly discharged two shots. One of the balls entered the right cheek of Dr. ZACHARIE just below the eye and close to the nose, going so far into his head as to be beyond the reach of the probe. Dr. PARKER was immediately called in, and he made an examination of the wound. It was his opinion that possibly the ball could be extracted, and the life of the injured man saved. The wound is, however, regarded as a very dangerous one.

abstract: Fernando Wood Says he Represents the Democratic Party
snippet: Fernando Wood Says he Represents the Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: FERNANDO WOOD on Saturday evening, in his speech of full adhesion to the Chicago nominees, gave just and conclusive reasons for the course he has decided to adopt. "If elected," said he, "I am satisfied that he [Gen. MCCLELLAN] will entertain the views and execute the principles of the great party he will represent, without regard to those he may himself possess. He will then be our agent and the creature of our voice." This is perfectly true and the sequel will show it. How, indeed, can he be anything else? He is nominated solely and exclusively because he is the representative of the party which adopts him. He is made their candidate only because he is to be their agent. Mr. WOOD stated the simplest and most unquestionable maxim of practical politics, when he asserted that the nominee of a party becomes the representative of that party when, with his own consent, he becomes its candidate. When BUCHANAN was nominated, he stated that he was "no longer JAMES BUCHANAN" -- he was the representative of the principles and purposes of the party which had put him in nomination. This was true of him -- and it must be true of every man who permits himself to be made the candidate of a political party.

abstract: Very soon a valuable report will be given to the public by the citizens association, showing the Sanitary condition of the city in detail. The  healthiest and most unhealthy parts of the city, the different kinds of disease, and the causes thereof. Especial attention will be paid to the "fever nests" where because of the avariciousness of land...
lead_paragraph: Very soon a valuable report will be given to the public by the citizens association, showing the Sanitary condition of the city in detail. The healthiest and most unhealthy parts of the city, the different kinds of disease, and the causes thereof. Especial attention will be paid to the "fever nests" where because of the avariciousness of land lords, people are crowded into buildings erected with such an eye to every inch of ground and room, that ventilation and cleanliness are impossibilities. The details will astonish the public, and there will be less surprise at the disproportionate numbers of those who are young. The association intend to give to this matter of tenement houses the most thorough examination, and to use the strongest efforts to secure an-entire reform. In occupied portions of some buildings examined. daylight scarcely enters; fresh air never; fetid poison constantly. In these, which are termed "fever dens," disease and death have it all their own way, and old and young fall before them. It would be well if property-owners, who propose erecting tenement houses, would drop into the rooms of the association, and see the plans which are proposed. While they would secure the health of the inmates, they would prove more economical in construction and profitable in income, than with but few exceptions, those now in use.

abstract: and Gen. Grant, Correspondence at Opening Virginia Campaign
snippet: and Gen. Grant, Correspondence at Opening Virginia Campaign
lead_paragraph: letters that passed between President LINCOLN and Lieutenant-General GRANT, prior to the opening of the Virginia campaign last Spring, are published in our columns to-day. The President expressed freely to Gen. GRANT a perfect confidence in his military ability; told him that he neither knew nor desired to know the particulars of his plans, nor to obtrude any restraints or constraints upon him, and added earnestly: "If there be anything wanting that is within my power to give, do not fail to let me know it." Gen. GRANT acknowledges the President's compliment with soldierly pride, and makes this just acknowledgment; "From my first entrance into the volunteer service of the country, to the present day. I have never had cause of compalaint, have never expressed or implied a complaint against the Administration or the Secretary of War, for throwing any embarrassment in the way of my vigorously prosecuting what appeared to be my duty." How different is this from the wrangling, jangling, fault-finding, complaining, whining, pitiful, badgering, censorious, insulting manner in which Gen. GEORGE BRINTON MCCLELLAN thought fit to talk and write to the President and Secretary of War. How much more manly, soldierly and noble are the words of Lieut.-Gen. U.S. GRANT.

abstract: Our Western naval station at Mound City, Ill., is being greatly improved and enlarged. About fourteen acres of land have been inclosed by a substantial fence and gates ornamented with balls and shells, supposed to be naval trophies.
lead_paragraph: Our Western naval station at Mound City, Ill., is being greatly improved and enlarged. About fourteen acres of land have been inclosed by a substantial fence and gates ornamented with balls and shells, supposed to be naval trophies. Four large and superior frame buildings have been erected, and a fifth is in course of construction. Two of these are used as ordnance storehouses, one for officers and quarters, and the rest for paymaster's supplies. In addition to these are a watch-house, telegraph office, mess-room, kitchen and commodious stable. The marine barracks at the main entrance, are also of frame, and are occupied by an efficient garrison. An extensive saw-mill, railway and foundry are conveniently located and in the employ of the yard. The Alonzo Child, an old Mississippi steamer, whose engines were recently captured in the monster rebel rain Tennessee, has been converted into a machine and carpenter shop. All the shops are afloat and the houses on piles. The flag-ship Black Hawk, is at the station awaiting Admiral PORTER'S return from the East. The famous iron-clad Cincinnati, has been taken from the ways and is fast being refitted. The Tuscumbia is lying in ordinary, and the Milwaukee, a sister iron-clad to the Winnebago and Chickasaw, now at Mobile, is ready for service. Recruiting is very brisk, the Great Western, receiving ship at Cairo, having registered 1,500 men in twenty days.

abstract: Yesterday morning, Dr. ISSACHER ZACHARIE, a well-known chiropodist of this City, was shot in his own house, No. 760 Broadway, with a fivebarreled revolver in the hands of Mr. SAMUEL M. BARNETT. Two shots were fired. One ball en-
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, Dr. ISSACHER ZACHARIE, a well-known chiropodist of this City, was shot in his own house, No. 760 Broadway, with a fivebarreled revolver in the hands of Mr. SAMUEL M. BARNETT. Two shots were fired. One ball entered the Doctor's cheek on the right side of his nose, and passed into his head beyond the reach of a probe. It is feared the wound will prove fatal. BARNETT immediately after delivered himself up, and Justice SHANDLEY committed him to await the result of the injuries. There are several different versions as to the cause that led to the a[???]ray, and at present there is a mystery surrounding the affair, which will no doubt be hereafter unraveled. BARNETT is an Englishman, a single man, aged thirty-two years. Dr.ZACHARIE is a native of Charleston, S.C., aged about forty-five years, and has a wife and several children residing in this City.

abstract: On the War for the Union; and the War; McClellan was the Failure
snippet: On the War for the Union; and the War; McClellan was the Failure
lead_paragraph: The black-hearted traitors and the palehearted poltroons who combined at Chicago to nominate MCCLELLAN and PENDLETON, the man who always delayed the war and the man who always opposed it, had styled the war a failure, and called for its abandonment. Few, if any, of these creatures had ever participated in it personally. Not one of them knew anything of what they affirmed save as it was prompted to them in their own coverts, by either the basest motives or the meanest instincts. Precisely so did Judas account Christianity a failure. Precisely so did BENEDICT ARNOLD, in his letter which we printed on Monday, declare the Revolutionary War a failure. The evidence is as worthless as its origin is detestable.

abstract: The Hebrew congregation Shaaray Tefila, which for fourteen years past have occupied a house of worship in Wooster-street, dedicated a new synagogue yesterday afternoon with the usual c eremonies of the Jewish ritual. The new edifice erected by this congregation is situated in Broadway, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth streets, and Is in every way a suitable and comfortable building. The interior is fitted up with great taste and at considerable expense. The woodwork is grained in im[???]a[???]ion of oak. The altar, the ark and the vall are of beautiful workmanship, and elaborately ornamented with gold and silver bullion letters and embroidered. The service of dedication in the Hebrew church is very solemn and imposing. After the psalms had been chaunted by an excellent German choir under direction of Mr. WOOLF, and the prescribed passages of Scripture had been read, the priest and deacons carried the scrolls of the law, in procession, three times around the synagogue, finally depositing them in the ark. The services concluded with an impressive address by the Rev. S.M. ISAACS, minister of the congregation. The building was crowded by a large and attentive audience.

abstract: Conspiracy to Push Forward the War, Copperheads Discover
snippet: Conspiracy to Push Forward the War, Copperheads Discover
lead_paragraph: The Copperheads have discovered another deep-laid plot on the part of the Lincoln Government to carry the Presidential election. Some of the more sagacious men of the "Democratic" party begin to suspect that the recent movements of SHERMAN, FARRAGUT, SHERIDAN and GRANT, are intended to secure the re lection of Father Abraham! They regard this as taking a most outrageous advantage of the Chicago party in this contest. When the draft was ordered they fondly hoped it would simply make the Administration odious, and so give them a chance to overthrow it; but they find it is being actually used to swell the ranks of the Union armies, and thus put them in condition to crush the rebellion. And that is fatal to the hopes of the Chicago Confederates!
headline: {'main': 'A Base Conspiracy!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Base Conspiracy!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
