abstract: Dishonoring Our National Credit
snippet: Dishonoring Our National Credit
lead_paragraph: Philosophers in all countries have wondered at and lamented the extent to which party spirit will carry its subjects. Probably no country has ever beheld it working in greater virulence than our own. Here, for instance, is one of our Democratic cotemporaries -- the most of whose readers, poor and ignorant as they may be, would be immensely damaged by any weakening of the public credit, and whose patrons would be ruined by the success of its own efforts -- laboring in a two-column article by exaggerated estimates and misstated facts, to show that the United States never can pay its debt. And then, if it could, we are assured, in conclusion, that the people of this country would probably repudiate it, because their forefathers repudiated the Continental money! This attack by the World on the honor of the Republic -- which will be republished, no doubt immediately, by our financial friends in the City columns of the London Times -- is made purely and solely to deal a blow at the Administration.
headline: {'main': 'An Attack on American Honor.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Attack on American Honor.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Great Victory
snippet: Great Victory
lead_paragraph: To-day's bulletins of battle are as brilliant as any we have ever had in the course of the war. SHERIDAN has fought and won another battle, has wrested from the enemy another strong and important position, and, if the reiterated and very decided statements of the official dispatches may be credited, has routed the rebel army of the Shenandoah. It was on Thursday that he came up with the retreating army of the rebels, which, after the disastrous defeat it met with on Monday, had skedaddled some thirty miles and taken up a strong position on FISHER's Hill (or Round Hill), a short distance south of Strasburg. The great strength of the position was well known to all our officers who had campaigned in the Shenandoah valley, and a very desperate struggle was there anticipated. The greater part of Thursday was spent in manoeuvering before the rebel line, and it was not till four o'clock in the afternoon that SHERIDAN could lead forward his whole army in general assault. But the two hours of daylight were put to awfully glorious use by this distinguished soldier. The gallantry and fury of his attack, the skill and of his tactics, and the effectiveness of his work, can best be judged of by his own words. He opens by announcing the "achievement of a signal victory," and closes by proclaiming that the "victory was very complete." He says that CROOK, who operated on the enemy's left, "carried everything before him," "swept down behind their breastworks," and "drove them in the greatest confusion." He says that the Sixth and Nineteenth Corps assailed the rebel works in front, and though they appeared almost impregnable, we achieved such decided success that the enemy "fled in the utmost confusion," and their "whole army appeared to be broken up." It was only darkness, he tells us, that "saved the whole of EARLY's army from total destruction." In the manner Gen. STEVENSON telegraphs that and "affair is complete and overwhelming," and "id in all probability, the finale of Gen. EARLY."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. HALSEY'S opera of the "Jewess" is one of the most trying in the modern repsrtoire, both for the artists engaged in the representation and the manager who produces the work.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- HALSEY's opera of the "Jewess" is one of the most trying in the modern repertoire, both for the artists engaged in the representation and the manager who produces the work. The score is exceedingly full, and the mise-in-scene is highly important. There is much for the ear, and much for the eye. When all has been done, it is doubtful if the public will appreciate the effort and labor that have been expended in the cause. For the "Jewess" is an opera of reputation rather than of popularity. Musicians speak well of it and justly, for it contains the essence of a dozen of ordinary operas. It exhausted the fancy and imagination, of its composer, and has furnished suggestions for all of his successors. But the general public have never warmed to the work, and hence its place in the repertoire is determined entirely by the energy and liberality of the manager. If we may judge by the perfectly overwhelming attendance that filled the Academy last evening, Mr. GROVER has chosen the right moment for submitting it to his patrons. Few managers with so brief a season would thought of encountering the obstacles and expenses of such a revival. Mr. GROVER's pluck entitles him to the reward which we are glad to find he is so promptly receiving.

abstract: James Laird vs. G.W. Laird. This was an action brought to decide the right to use, as trademarks, the names of "Bloom of Youth" and "Liquid Pearl." The parties to the action are father and son, ...
lead_paragraph: James Laird vs. G.W. Laird. -- This was an action brought to decide the right to use, as trademarks, the names of "Bloom of Youth" and "Liquid Pearl." The parties to the action are father and son, and plaintiff obtained an injunction to restrain defendant from manufacturing or selling any rejuvenator of declining beauty under the name referred to. On motion to dissolve the injunction the defendant showed that in 1861 the plaintiff had transferred to him all his interest in the sale and manufacture of the cosmetic, and that since that time the business had been entirely in defendant's name. The plaintiff claimed that defendant had only been employed by him as a clerk, but that he had nominally sold the business to him in order to protect his (plaintiff's) property. Family difficulties having arisen, defendant took the business into his own hands. His Honor held that as plaintiff had transferred his right to the Boom of Youth some years ago, and as the business had been carried on in his son's name, with the consent of plaintiff, it was too late now for him to step in and revoke his sale. The defendant, G.W. Laird, alone has the right to use the trade marks "Bloom of Youth" and "Liquid Pearl," and the injunction must be dissolved. L.C. Marsh for plaintiff; Edwin James for defendant.

abstract: City Inspector BOOLE and Comptroller BRENNON, on Thursday opened the following proposals for 'freighting and removal without the limits of the City," of all the street dirt, ashes, garbage and rubbish collected within it.
lead_paragraph: City Inspector BOOLE and Comptroller BRENNON, on Thursday opened the following proposals for 'freighting and removal without the limits of the City," of all the street dirt, ashes, garbage and rubbish collected within it. The contract is to be made for a period of from four to five years, as may be determined upon by the City Inspector and Comptroller. Heretofore, different temporary contracts for the work have existed. Each proposal designated whether the stuff was to be taken from all the dumping-grounds, or particular ones, (there are seven dumps in all -- two on the North, and five on the East river) and whether the parties would pay for the privilege, do the work free or require a price for it. The offer of HE RY HAMILTON was accepted. His conditions are, to take all rubbish from the North River and Roosevelt-street dumps, and pay the City five cents per cart-load, and one cent per cart-load for all the rubbish from the remaining dumps. Mr. HAMILTON is personally unknown to either the City Inspector or the Comptroller, and as he omitted to give his residence in his letter of proposal, his presence is desired at the office of either of these officials to-day.

abstract: Another signal defeat has been inflicted by Gen. SHERIDAN on the forces of EARLY a defeat so erushing and overwhelming that nothing but the approach of night saved the demoralized and flying remnants of the rebel army from entire destruction. Pursuing the retreating rebels with ...
lead_paragraph: Another signal defeat has been inflicted by Gen. SHERIDAN on the forces of EARLY -- a defeat so erushing and overwhelming that nothing but the approach of night saved the demoralized and flying remnants of the rebel army from entire destruction. Pursuing the retreating rebels with great vigor after his first victory over them near Winchester, Gen. SHERIDAN came up with them on the. 22d, at Fisher's Hill, where they occupied a very strong position. After a good deal of manoeuvering, Gen. CROOK, whose command had been meanwhile transferred to the right of the line, made a terrible onslaught upon the left of the enemy's line, and carried everything before him. The enemy fled in the greatest confusion. The Sixth and Nineteenth Army Corps at the same time attacked the Rebels in front, and drove them back with irresistible impetuosity. Sixteen pieces of artillery, a great many caissons, artillery horses, &c., were captured. Gen. SHERIDAN continued the pursuit immediately. EARLY's command embraced the elite of the Rebel army.

abstract: -- The Crayon Art Gallery, corner of Broadway and Eighth-street, was thronged on Wednesday evening last by a select and fashionable company, invited to a private view of CARPENTER's picture of "President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation before the Cabinet." The expressions of enthusiasm which fell from the lips of the delighted spectators must have been most gratifying to the artist. The picture must take a high rank among the historical paintings of the day. It is now on public exhibition at the corner of Broadway and Eighth-street.

abstract: On Friday, the 16th inst., the firemen of Hoboken had a grand time. Washington Hook  Ladder Co. No. 1, one of the oldest and best companies in the city, that day received and brought home their new Truck. At two o'clock in the afternoon the ...
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the 16th inst., the firemen of Hoboken had a grand time. Washington Hook & Ladder Co. No. 1, one of the oldest and best companies in the city, that day received and brought home their new Truck. At two o'clock in the afternoon the members of the company assembled at the truck house, formed, and accompanied by Chief Engineer ROBERT A. REED, Asst. Engineer L, KENNEDY; MYERS' excellent band and a number of invited guests, marched to the ferry and embarked on board the ferry boat Newark which Mr. STEVENS had placed at their disposal. The boat was beautifully dressed with flags &c., and after the men were all on board she steamed down the river around the battery, and landed the party in Brooklyn, at the Wall street ferry, they then formed again and marched up to the factory of Mr. J.S. WORTMAN, the maker of the truck. Here they were met by Assistant Engineer SIMPSON and a number of prominent Brooklyn firemen. After the truck had been inspected and admired, the firemen of Brooklyn took charge of the Hoboken boys, and treated them very handsomely, after the good things had all been disposed of they all returned to the factory and the truck company took possession of their truck. They then formed again, and accompanied by more guests from Brooklyn, including Mr. WORTMAN, the maker, and Mr. SPITTLE, one of his principal workmen, who had carefully superintended the building of the truck, re turned to the ferry and again embarked on the Newark. On board the boat a collation was served, to which all did good justice. Arriving at Hoboken, they were received by the entire Fire Department of the city, a number of prominent firemen from New-York. At about 8 o'clock, the procession being formed, commenced to move, and then commenced probably the grandest torchlight procession ever seen in Hoboken. Rockets, Roman candles, and fireworks of nearly every description filled the air. Many houses along the line of march were illuminated, guns were fired, cheers upon cheers given, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed. After the march was completed, and the apparatus safely housed, the ceremony of christening the new truck was performed. The firemen were formed in a circle, their guests, very many of whom were ladies, filled the rest of the house, and the band was stationed near the door. MISS MINNIE PLOWMANTHE, the beautiful and accomplished relative of Mr. JOHN W. MITCHELL, was then led forward by him to the platform which had been prepared for her, supported on either side by Foreman EDWARD G. JEWETT and Assistant Foreman M.H. REDDING. Mr. MITCHELL then handed her the bottle of wine. When, after naming the truck "Washington," and adding a very beautiful little sentiment, she broke the bottle over the new name plate, completely deluging it with the delicious wine. The band then immediately struck up, and nine hearty cheers were given for the new truck, and the young lady who had christened it.

abstract: BODY RECOVERED The body of a colored boy, named JAMES FRANKLIN, was picked up in the Atlantic Dock Basin yesterday. He was identified by his mother as one of the victims of the boiler explosion on the tug-boat B.B. Sanders, some day last week.  His face had been blown off and his bowels torn out. His mother identified him by a ring on one of his fingers.

abstract: One of the most valuable union organizations in this City is the Loyal Publication Society, of which Dr. FRANCIS LIEBER is President, and JOHN AUSTIN STEVENS, JR., Secretary.
lead_paragraph: One of the most valuable union organizations in this City is the Loyal Publication Society, of which Dr. FRANCIS LIEBER is President, and JOHN AUSTIN STEVENS, JR., Secretary. Without having any other political character than such as attaches to loyalty, this Society is doing an excellent work in the publication of tracts, essays and addresses calculated to arouse devotion to the country, loyalty to the Government, and determined resistance to the enemies of the Union and of human rights. Its list of publications, including several in German and French, number above fifty pamphlets and tracts, written by the ablest statesmen and scholars. These may be obtained at cost price, on application to the Society, at No. 833 Broadway, where information in regard to the objects and working of the institution will be readily given. The Loyal Publication Society deserves the support of every patriotic citizen who appreciates the importance of enlightening public sentiment as to the real objects of the war and the duties of a true loyalty.

abstract: In the pools sold on Tuesday evening Lady Emma took a decided lead as first favorite, fetching $250, to the $180 of General Butler, the $145 of Prince, and the $45 of John Morgan. The action was still more decided on the course on Wednesday morning, when Prince came ...
lead_paragraph: In the pools sold on Tuesday evening Lady Emma took a decided lead as first favorite, fetching $250, to the $180 of General Butler, the $145 of Prince, and the $45 of John Morgan. The action was still more decided on the course on Wednesday morning, when Prince came with a rush and ejected Butler from the position of second, favorite Emma bringing $305, Prince $115, whilst Butler receded to $80, and Morgan to $30. A more brilliant display was never witnessed on any race track on Long Island than that presented on the Fashion course as the hour of starting approached. It was computed by good judges of numbers en masse that over eight thousand people were assembled on the ground when the bell rang.

abstract: The Approaching
snippet: The Approaching
lead_paragraph: As early as in last July, we indicated that Gen. GRANT would find it among the necessities of his military position, to march an army up the Shenandoah Valley, with its objective point, Lynchburgh. And we ventured to remark that Gen. SHERMAN, having taken Atlanta, would have open before him, in a few weeks, three or four different lines of advance -- one toward Mobile, in connection with FARRAGUT; one toward Augusta, and then down the Savannah River to Savannah; another to Charleston; and finally, the most important of all, a return through East Tennessee on Virginia, debouching toward Lynchburgh, to cooperate with GRANT in the final attack on Richmond and LEE. The Express at the time was pleased to sneer at it as a most rose-colored strategy, and to doubt whether any one of these events was among the military possibilities.

abstract: The executive of the Union and Emancipation Society have issued an address to "the people of Great Britain and Ireland" on "the progress and prospects of the great struggle for freedom in America," in reply to a document which has been circulated for signatures by the Southern Independence Association. The address expresses confidence that the people of this country will never give their "sanction to any proposition, even in the holy name of peace, that seeks to bolster up and sustain an infamous slave power." The address further points out the great progress which has been made during Mr. LINCOLN's presidency in the work of emancipation, and concludes by declaring that "not until Slavery is anninilated throughout the United States can come the longed-for era of peace, -- a true, holy, and lasting peace, founded on union, freedom, justice, and humanity."

abstract: The latest news from Gen. SHERIDAN is a dispatch dated at Woodstock on Friday morning, at 8 o'clock, in which he says he cannot as yet give any definite account of the results of the battle of yesterday. Our loss will be light. Gen. CROOK struck the left flank of the enemy, doubled it up, and advanced down their lines.
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Gen. SHERIDAN is a dispatch dated at Woodstock on Friday morning, at 8 o'clock, in which he says he cannot as yet give any definite account of the results of the battle of yesterday. Our loss will be light. Gen. CROOK struck the left flank of the enemy, doubled it up, and advanced down their lines. PICKETT's division of the Sixth Army Corps swung in, and joined CROOK. GETTY's and WHEATON's division took up the same movement, followed by the whole line, and, attacking beautifully, carried the works of the enemy. The General says he cannot at present give any estimate of prisoners, as he pushed on regardless of everything. The number of pieces of artillery reported captured is sixteen. Gen TORBERT was ordered by Gen. SHERIDAN to push his cavalry down the Luray Valley, which, if promptly done, must produce very important results. Gen. SHERIDAN says there never was an army so badly routed. A despatch from Gen. STEVENSON, dated Harper's Ferry, Saturday morning, announces that two thousand Strasburgh prisoners reached Winchester Friday night. He also states that 1,600 of the prisoners captured on the 19th inst. near Winchester, arrived at Harper's Ferry yesterday morning, and that 1,600 more are yet to come. A later dispatch received from Gen. STENVENSON. announces that 1,600 more prisoners, aptured at Strasburgh on the 22d, reached Winchester yesterday morning.

abstract: on McClellan; Quint; Chaplain on
snippet: on McClellan; Quint; Chaplain on
lead_paragraph: The last number of the Congregationalist contains a long and able letter from Rev. A.H. QUINT, formerly chaplain of the Massachusetts second Regiment, and a Democrat, on the question, "How shall we vote?" Mr. QUINT expresses strong affection for Gen. MCCLELLAN as a man and great admiration for him as an officer, believing him to be the best General in the service and a much abused man. He says he would gladly vote for him if it were not for the Chicago platform, and MCCLELLAN's associate on the Presidential ticket. To vote for MCCLELLAN is to vote for his associate, PENDLETON, who wants a dishonorable peace and has persistently opposed the war from the start, and who, if MCCLELLAN were now in the field, would vote against sending him men. To vote for MCCLELLAN would be to vote for the Chicago platform, and on this point Mr. QUINT remarks:

abstract: Four Platforms of the Democracy, The; Chicago, Union-square, >amp;c.
snippet: Four Platforms of the Democracy, The; Chicago, Union-square, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Before the Convention at Chicago had proceeded to the business proper for which it had assembled, WASHINGTON HUNT, of this State, offered to the assembled delegates the outline of a platform, which was informally adopted by the Assembly, as embodying the essential views of the Democracy. Mr. HUNT asked the Convention to declare, "that in the future, as in the past, we will adhere with unswerving fidelity to the Union and Constitution, and insist on maintaining our national unity," &c. The resolution thus accepted in open council, was referred to the Committee on Resolutions, and by that committee it was adopted, with the exception of the words we have italicized. "To insist on maintaining our national unity," was considered too decided an expression of loyal and resolute purpose. The committee, therefore, brought forth their platform with the objectionable passage erased, and the essential resolution of the platform was made into a milk-and-water declaration, "that in the future as in the past, we adhere," &c. This was simply changing the active transitive into the active intransitive. At the first blush, however, no one would notice the difference, Mr. HUNT himself, even if he might have certain vague notions of the duty of making some positive declaration for the Union, would hardly discover, on the spur of the moment, that there was any essential difference between one party adhering to a given compact itself, and compelling another party to adhere to that compact as well. Be this as it may, whatever Mr. HUNT or those who most loudly professed adhesion to the Union at Chicago, thought, they accepted the change made by the VALLANDIGHAMS and other members of the committee on resolutions, at one grand bolt, and made no bones of it. Yet, VALLANDIGHAM got all he wanted when he proposed that the Democracy of the North should themselves "adhere" to the old Union covenants, instead of seeking to "insist on maintaining the national unity."
headline: {'main': 'The Four Platforms of the Democracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Four Platforms of the Democracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The rapidity with which, in our days, men can build works that required years formerly to bring them to a completion, is a subject of wonder to those who know how much matter there is to resist the will of man, and what distance divides the realization of an idea from its conception.
lead_paragraph: The rapidity with which, in our days, men can build works that required years formerly to bring them to a completion, is a subject of wonder to those who know how much matter there is to resist the will of man, and what distance divides the realization of an idea from its conception. Besides, we have thought that our readers would like to know, as we do, by what concurrence of will and means, the building of a railroad to the camp of Chalons, 20 miles in length, between the Strasburg line, from which it runs off, and Mourmelon, the commune, on which is laid out the camp of Chalons, has taken only 65 days!

abstract: Union Victories and Copperhead Discouragements
snippet: Union Victories and Copperhead Discouragements
lead_paragraph: The news of a victory just now is a heavy blow and a great discouragement to our Cop per head brethren. Every gun fired to cele brate it sends a pang through the true Copperhead heart. Every flag waving in its honor is as smoke to their eyes. They grown over it as men in London or Richmond groan over it. To hear that but few friends of their neighbors and friends in the army have been killed or wounded, and many of the enemy, is for them the saddest tidings that can reach them, and what gives the draft most of its bitterness is that they have to pretend to like it. To swallow physic is hard, but to smack one's lips over it and pretend that it tastes like champagne or claret, is hardest of all, and yet this is what the unfortunate supporters of GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN have to do just now.

abstract: There is now in the Confederacy a stock of Cotton of at least 3,000,000 bales, of which probably not less than one-third is in a condition fit for immediate exportation. Of a large proportion of this the government is the direct owner.
lead_paragraph: There is now in the Confederacy a stock of Cotton of at least 3,000,000 bales, of which probably not less than one-third is in a condition fit for immediate exportation. Of a large proportion of this the government is the direct owner. If instead of this property the Government had the value, even at only sixpence a pound, in gold, who can doubt that the Confederate currency would never have lost a specie basis? Why should not a cotton basis., equally available for present purposes, be adopted? Grant that the precious metals are abstractly immeasurably superior to a perishable commodity as a standard of values. But if one cannot have what one wishes, why not make use of what one has? Suppose the Government, in its future disbursements at home as well as abroad, should give promises to pay cotton, instead of promises to pay gold? it is under any conceivable circumstances better able to keep the former than the latter. An order on the Government store-keeper for $100 of cotton at peace prices would therefore, at worst, be more intrinsically valuable than an order for gold on, the Treasury to the same amount. If the experiment succeeded, the cotton promises might be gradually exchanged for the gold promises already issued. To give these cotton promises a saleable value abroad, it would only be necessary to exempt the holders from certain restrictions, whether present or prospective, on the exportation. Already the Government has undertaken to pay the interest on one description of its domestic funded debt in cotton; why not extend this expedient to the principal of its future unfounded debt? The plan would be condemned by a certain class of shallow political economists, who, when they have learned the formulas of the application of its laws. But must it be necessarily condemned because of being exceptional and anomalous by the practical statesmen of a country in which everything is at present anomalous and acceptional?

abstract: This war-worn veteran is enjoying the hospitality of quite a number of our leading citizens. He is at present spending two or three days at the country seat of R.B. MINTURN, Esq., in New-Jersey. On Friday the General made a short visit to a personal friend at Peekskill, on the Hudson, and during the evening was the recipient of a very flattering ovation from the people, in the shape of a salute, serenade and illumination of fireworks, which drew forth from him one of his characteristic and happiest speeches. The people of Peekskill fully showed their appreciation of the General's efficient services. Gov. ANDREW and Senator WILSON have tendered him an invitation to attend the great meeting at Fanueil Hall in Boston, on Friday, but it is not yet accepted.

abstract: The Fourth New-York State Volunteer Cavalry was raised and mustered into service as a regiment on the 27th of August, 1861. It entered the field early in September of that year, under command of Col. C. DICKEL, who remained in command until June, 1862.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth New-York State Volunteer Cavalry was raised and mustered into service as a regiment on the 27th of August, 1861. It entered the field early in September of that year, under command of Col. C. DICKEL, who remained in command until June, 1862. He was succeeded in September, 1862, by Col. Count LOUIS PALMA DI CESUOLA, at present commanding Second Brigade, First Cavalry Division, to which his regiment Is attached.

abstract: Influenced by the rapid fall in gold on Saturday, produce and merchandise were lightly dealt in at, in most instances, much lower prices. Flour fell off 50c. per bbl.; Wheat, nominally, 8c. ...
lead_paragraph: Influenced by the rapid fall in gold on Saturday, produce and merchandise were lightly dealt in at, in most instances, much lower prices. Flour fell off 50c. per bbl.; Wheat, nominally, 8c.@10c. and Corn 1c. per bushel; Cotton 5c.@10c.; Lard 1c.@2c.; Butter and Cheese 1c.@2c. lb.; Whisky 2c. gallon. Groceries, Dry Goods, Wool, Hides, Leather, Oils, Metals, Fruit and Spices were also cheaper and quite irregular. Very light freight engagements were reported, with 435 vessels of all classes in port. At the Produce Exchange the announcement of the fall in gold to 205 1/4 toward the close of the business session, was received with a round of cheers, which, for a moment, drowned the noise of the sonorous gong.

abstract: The Liverpool Mercury says that Mr. and Mrs. HARDINGE, (Miss BELLE BOYD.) who were married in London on Thursday, have arrived in Liverpool, and are staying at the Washington Hotel, preparing for a speedy departure to the Confederate States, where, inspite ...
lead_paragraph: The Liverpool Mercury says that Mr. and Mrs. HARDINGE, (Miss BELLE BOYD.) who were married in London on Thursday, have arrived in Liverpool, and are staying at the Washington Hotel, preparing for a speedy departure to the Confederate States, where, inspite of the blockade, Mr. HARDINGE intends to convey a portion of the wedding-cake for distribution among his friends. Relative to the withdrawal of Mr. HARDINGE from the service of the North, the Morning Post says Mr. H. needs no excuse for the step he has taken in renouncing his allegiance to the Federal cause, and espousing the fair "rebel," whom he has now sworn to love, honor and cherish. Though in obedience to the wishes of his father he served for some time in the Federal Navy, in which service he rose to be Lieutenant, his Southern sympathies were notorious in the North, where it was well known that he had long tendered his resignation,which Mr. Secretary WELLES refused to accept, and thus he was forced to continue in a service which he would gladly have renounced long since. Though more than suspected of Southern sympathies, he kept his word when he promised the executive of the Federal navy that the name he bore -- a name which had descended to him from a long line of ancestors in Great Britain and America -- should not be disgraced, an proved his readiness to perform his duty on many occasions, especially by heading a body of 120 men sent ashore to storm a breach at Wilmington, and capturing the fort, though when the muster-roll was called afterwards only 25 survivors could respond. He did not escape, as he received a severe wound in the chest, and will carry his honorable scar to the grave. Having now finally quitted the service of President LINCOLN's Government, he intends to signalize his devotion to Secessia by entering the ranks of her army, and thus winning his way to confidence and that command which his birth and education gave him a right to expect. The command he might long since have obtained, for, although only twenty-two years of age, a Major's commission in the Federal Army was offered him as the price of the renunciation of his intended wife and his Southern sympathies.

abstract: Georgia Pirate, the; Mr Bates' Purchase
snippet: Georgia Pirate, the; Mr Bates' Purchase
lead_paragraph: We fear that Mr. BATES, the purchaser of the Georgia, has made a bad investment of the $80,000 which he paid for the ex-pirate. His attempt to obtain the intervention of the British Government is indeed proof that, whatever may have been his original opinion on the subject, he now entertains grave doubts himself touching the validity of the sale. On the merits of his case, however, be they ever so questionable, the gentleman will have to take his stand, for his application to Earl RUSSELL has been in vain. The British Foreign Secretary will have nothing to do with the matter, but coolly informs the applicant that "the case of the Georgia must go before the Prize Court in the United States," and that he "must be prepared to defend" his "interest therein." The party to the suit then will be JAMES BATES, ship-broker, of Liverpool, not the British Government. But what will be the nature of the bill of indictment which Mr. BATES will bring against the Republic of the United States? Why, that on a certain day, which, of course, will be specified, the American frigate Niagara seized the British merchantman Georgia off the port of Lisbon, notwithstanding that said vessel was, at the time, sailing under the British flag, possessed of a bona fide British register, the property of a natural-born British subject and engaged in lawful traffic. On which grounds the plaintiff will demand not only the restitution of the vessel, but even compensation for damages sustained. Well, Count BENTINCK, of Kniphausen, advanced similar charges, and made similar claims in the case of the ex-Dutch frigate Minerva, yet Lord STOWELL refused to countenance them, and we suspect that, for similar reasons, the charges and claims of Mr. BATES' quoad the Georgia will fare no better.
headline: {'main': 'The Case of the Georgia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Case of the Georgia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The history of the first attempt to construct and submerge a deep sea line of telegraph between England and America is a highly interesting one, and by no means devoid of instruction.
lead_paragraph: The history of the first attempt to construct and submerge a deep sea line of telegraph between England and America is a highly interesting one, and by no means devoid of instruction. However brief the triumph, it established a momentous fact, as eternal as the great Atlantic itself, that beneath its tempestous billows there was laid once upon a time a way for the "lightning of thunder." However heavy the expenditure, the sacrifice and the dissipated hopes, the Atlantic cable was nevertheless the pioneer in whose gigantic stride others have followed, and will again follow, until success shall have crowned the noble and glorious effort.
headline: {'main': 'The Advantage of Ocean Telegraphing.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Advantage of Ocean Telegraphing.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: BANNER RAISING IN THE THIRD WARD. Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock there was a very spirited meeting in the square, at the corner of Washington and Reade-streets.
lead_paragraph: BANNER RAISING IN THE THIRD WARD. -- Yesterday afternoon at three o'clock there was a very spirited meeting in the square, at the corner of Washington and Reade-streets. The gathering was occasioned by the announcement that a banner, bearing the names of ABRAHAM LINCOLN for President, and ANDREW JOHNSON for Vice-President, would be raised, and that Gen. HOOKER and Gov. NOBLE would address the assemblage. At the hour stated the banner, one of the largest and most costly yet raised in the City, was swung across Washington-street, a few feet from Reade-street, amid the cheers of several hundred people. Mr. E.H. GARBUTT was appointed Chairman, and introduced Mr. H.B. DUTCHER, who spoke in glowing terms of the achievements of Gen. SHERIDAN, and our recent victories in the Shenandoah Valley. C.S. SPENCER, Esq., was the next speaker introduced. He said that no portion of the country was more interested in a speedy attainment of peace than the people of New-York, but they did not think the best way to obtain peace was to pronounce the war a failure. The speaker referred to the Chicago platform, and said that SHERMAN, FARRAGUT and SHERIDAN had, by their noble deeds, pronounced against it. In the glorious tide of victory was it the time to ignominiously lay down our arms? Mr. SPENCER spoke at some length, and was loudly cheered during his remarks. A gentleman, introduced as Adjutant HAGERTY, made a short speech, and was followed by BENJAMIN F. BRUCE, Esq., who was interrupted in his remarks by a drenching rain, which compelled an adjournment of the meeting. The proceedings throughout were of an enthusiastic character. The absence, however, of Gen. HOOKER and Gov. NOBLE was a serious disappointment.

abstract: as a Patriot; Moldo-Wallachia and Prince Couza
snippet: as a Patriot; Moldo-Wallachia and Prince Couza
lead_paragraph: A little while ago the Moldau-Wallachian Hospodar was known only as a turbulent and insubordinate feudatory of the Porte, as a spoliator of Monks and monastic establishment -- now he appears in a new role -- now he figures as patriot, liberator, and champion of the oppressed. The present Czar has acquired immortal fame by the emancipation of twenty millions of Sclavonic serfs. Why should not Prince COUZA imitate, at an humble distance, his great contemporary, and break the bonds of his Roumanian peasants? Well, so he has, and has just issued a proclamation declaratory of their freedom. In this instrument, which is in the form of an address to his people, the Prince assures the Moldau-Wallachian cultivators that forced labor is abolished forever in both provinces. "From this day," says he, "you are free proprietors in the places you inhabit, within the limit prescribed by existing laws....From this day you are masters of your arms, you have a portion of land which is your own property, and you have a country to love and defend." The boon is, beyond doubt, of a most precious nature, and will, of course, be duly estimated by its recipients. But though the Hospodar deserves much credit for having carried out this great reform, and may, as the concocter and accomplisher of it, have as fair a claim to the title of patriot as some others who are in the enjoyment thereof, still it is rather questionable whether he was solely moved to undertake the work of amelioration by commiseration for the lot of the peasant. ALEXANDER JOHN was a politician ere he became a philanthropist. The paramount object of his life has been to emancipate himself and his principalities from dependence on the Sultan. The hour for striking the blow has not yet indeed arrived, but in the meantime, what better way could the Hospodar have gone about making, preparation for the contemplated struggle than by conferring privileges on the mass of his subjects, which have led them to regard him as a benefactor and father, and have endeared to them his person and his cause? An insurrection, with the people disaffected, or apathetic, and sustained merely by a hireling force, would overwhelm himself and his adherents with destruction, but an insurrection, supported by a people, ardent, enthusiastic, and ready to shed their blood in vindication of their right to autonomy and liberty, no power, at the disposal of the Moslem, could suppress. Taking into account then the ambitious aspiration of COUZA, and the evident interest that he has in strengthening his influence with the Romaniam Democracy, is it not perfectly allowable to assume that his measure of emancipation was as much the offspring of policy as of philanthropy? Throughout the management of the whole matter, in fact, the Prince has displayed a tact and astuteness which would have done credit to a veteran diplomatist. During his visit to Constantinople, he so wormed himself into the good graces of the Sultan, and so won on his enemies in the conference, that, though he was summoned to the capital as a criminal to answer for his misdeeds, he yet triumphed over his accusers, and obtained, both from his Suzerain and the representatives of the guaranteeing powers, full permission to carry out his project of amelioration. Verily, the Moldau-Wallachian Hospodar is a "smart man."
headline: {'main': 'Prince Couza as a Patriot.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Prince Couza as a Patriot.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: From Capt. WM. ALPHEUS SMITH, one of the Pioneers of the Reese River Country, who is now in this City, we have an interesting account of the settlement and progress of this new mining region, situated in Nevada Territory, about one hundred and sixty miles east of Washoe, immediately on the Overland Road. Although but about eighteen months has elapsed since attention was first attracted to this point, it now contains over 10,000 inhabitants, while the City of Austin boasts about 3,000 population. The mines are being rapidly and successfully developed, the ore in the majority of cases paying from $200 to $500 per ton, worked by the ordinary mill process. There are some dozen fine mills in operation, and a number in course of erection.

abstract: Cor (Druid) on Rebel Resources
snippet: Cor (Druid) on Rebel Resources
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore correspondent of the World, "Druid," feels that it is important in some way to break the force of what Gen. GRANT has written about the exhaustion of the rebel resources. He feels that if that statement is accepted as correct, the chances of helping the rebel cause by the election of a President on the platform of a cessation of hostilities, are at once very much weakened. And so he comes to the rescue with a statement about the number of men yet in reserve in JEFF. DAVIS' dominions, which we think would astound that worthy, if he were to see it. If "Druid" could only make his figures true, he might claim any reward which it was in the power of King Cotton to grant.

abstract: Resignation as Postmaster-General
snippet: Resignation as Postmaster-General
lead_paragraph: -- Hon. MONTGOMERY BLAIR, as our readers already know, has resigned his position as Postmaster-General. We believe it is universally conceded that no one of his predecessors has surpassed him in the energy, ability and fidelity with which he has discharged the duties of his office. His resignation is due wholly to political causes. We do not credit the report that he tendered his resignation immediately after the Baltimore Convention, or at any other time, on the ground of any dissent from the policy pursued by President LINCOLN, and indorsed by that convention. On the contrary, that policy has had no more firm defender than he.

abstract: Recommendation for Congress
snippet: Recommendation for Congress
lead_paragraph: In our advertising columns may be found a recommendation signed by many hundreds of the most respectable citizens of the Third Congressional District in Brooklyn, in favor of the nomination of the wellknown merchant, S.B. CHITTENDEN, as the Union candidate for representative to Congress. It is a nomination preeminently fit to be made. It would be hard to name any civilian in this region who has contributed more liberally for the aid of our armies, or has more faithfully served the Union cause. And that we consider to be the very highest of all qualifications for public trust in these critical times. But to this supreme merit, Mr. CHITTENDEN unites financial knowledge, great general intelligence, and excellent speaking abilities. The method of nomination is as good as the nomination itself. Were the intelligent citizens of our great cities to make it their practice to designate in this manner their choice for nominatians, instead of leaving them to the manipulations of a few bargaining politicians, these cities would soon secure a more creditable class of representatives, both in our State and our National halls of legislation -- a representation which should be the most, instead of the least, influential portion of the body.

abstract: DEDICATION OF THE PASSIONIST FATHERS AT WEST HOBOKEN -- The ceremony of dedicating the new monastery of the Passionist Fathers at West Hoboken, took place yesterday afternoon in the presence of a large concourse of people. At present the main building (only) is erected, situated on Montgomery-avenue, near West Hoboken, on a high eminence of ground overlooking New-York, Long Island, the bay and far up the North River. The main building is built of granite rock, in the Norman style of architecture 102 feet front by 37 feet deep, four stories a[???]asement in height. The basement is designed for a dining-room, kitchen, carpenter shop, store-room, bath-room, [???] On the first floor are two parlors, porter's room, community room, public chapel, community chapel, tailor's room, &c. On the second floor are sixteen rooms, to be occupied chiefly by the supervisors of the institution and priests. On the third floor are sixteen rooms for the accommodation of the professors and students, and on the fourth floor the same number of rooms, to be occupied by the "community." There are also to be erected two wings, one to be 100 feet in length by 60 feet deep for a chapel, and the other 100 feet by 40, for the use of gentlemen wishing to retire for a longer or shorter period. The dedicatory services commenced yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock, and the following was the order of the ceremony: Vespers; Celebrant, Very Reverend Father DOMINICK SURLATINI, Provincial Superior; Deacon, Rev. ADDONIS MAGNO, Pastor; Sub-Deacon, Rev. JOHN BANDINETTI, from Dunkirk, N.Y.; Master of Ceremony, Rev. THOMAS O'CONNOR. After vesper at St. Mary's Chapel, the procession formed in the following order, and marched to the Monastery: Sunday School children; Guild of the Sacred Passion; members of the Palogians Community, 78 in number; citizens. On arriving at the new Monastery an address was presented to the Provisional Superior by the President of the Guild, Mr. PATRICK WELDON, in the name of St. Mary's congregation; the new Monastery was then blessed without and within, and the services closed with a benediction. Those present were then invited to visit the edifice. Services will be held in the new chapel attached to the monastery to-day, (Monday,) Tuesday and Wednesday, at 5:30 o'clock P.M.; preparations for the feast of St. Michael on Thursday, 29th, when high mass will be sung in the same chapel at 10 A.M.; vespers, with benediction, at 5 P.M. The object of this religious institution is for forming missionary societies for preaching the gospel and promote devotion to the passion of our Divine Saviour.

abstract: TENEMENT HOUSES.--Reference was made the other day to the efforts which were being made to improve tenement houses, and secure cleanliness, comfort and health to their inhabitants. To insure such improvements, however, would require the active cooperation of the City Government with the association which has taken an interest in the mat-
lead_paragraph: TENEMENT HOUSES. -- Reference was made the other day to the efforts which were being made to improve tenement houses, and secure cleanliness, comfort and health to their inhabitants. To insure such improvements, however, would require the active cooperation of the City Government with the association which has taken an interest in the matter. If the Common Council and the heads of the departments would some day take a ride around and visit the different buildings referred to, it can scarce be doubted, but that they would lend themselves earnestly to a work the success of which involves so much life, health and happiness. It is their duty to protect those who have not the means to protect themselves in the matters of choice of dwellings. They can do it by wise and careful legislation, and they can help much now by strict enforcement of the laws at present existing. The subject is a very serious one. Little attention has hitherto been paid to it, and the weekly lists of mortality show the result of the neglect. If owners of tenement houses would look at their own interests, to say nothing of that of humanity, they would find increased incomes from buildings affording the comforts and health sought for. It is well said by those urging the improvements: "We plead for improved dwellings for our industrial classes. We plead for such dwellings for the sake of the general cause of health, virtue, order and public interest. We plead for them for the sake of the tens of thousands of children and youth now growing up in homes which forbid wholesome and hopeful culture. And we plead for them for the sake of multitudes of worthy wives and mothers, who would, if they had suitable dwellings, make their homes bright and happy centres of refining, elevating influence to all their families."

abstract: IDAN keeps the ball rolling in the Shenandoah Valley. He seems to have routed and thoroughly broken up EARLY'S army, which numbered from thirty to forty thousand men, and constituted a very large part of LEE'S disposable force.
lead_paragraph: IDAN keeps the ball rolling in the Shenandoah Valley. He seems to have routed and thoroughly broken up EARLY'S army, which numbered from thirty to forty thousand men, and constituted a very large part of LEE'S disposable force. The Government meantime seems to be sending him supplies and reinforcements -- with the apparent intention of having him push up the Valley, cleaning everything before him as he goes, and finally seizing and holding Lynchburgh. When that is done, LEE's stay in Richmond will be short.

abstract: And Gov. Brown's Withdrawal of Militia; Withdraws Georgia Militia from Rebel Army
snippet: And Gov. Brown's Withdrawal of Militia; Withdraws Georgia Militia from Rebel Army
lead_paragraph: We have had various and sundry rumors of late, through both Union and rebel mediums, of an independent movement on the part of the rebel authorities in Georgia, to secure a "cessation of hostilities" in that State, or, in other words, to secure peace. It was first said on this side that a peace commissioner had been sent from Georgia; then the rebel papers asserted that Gen. SHERMAN had sent an informal request to Gov. BROWN, Vice-President STEPHENS and Ex-Senator JOHNSON to come to Atlanta and confer with him on the subject of peace; then we have a positively worded telegram to-day from Louisville that Gov. BROWN has offered to Gen. SHERMAN propositions for peace -- all assertions to the contrary notwithstanding: then again, on the rebel side, we had a very earnest article in the Ricmond Dispatch, expostulating with those who desired separate State action, and asserting that "it had been agitated of late in more quarters than one." The Dispatch asked, "Will Georgia abandon Virginia now, after having dragged her into this war?" And answered by saying that it could not and would not believe it, adding: "The Governor of Georgia ought at least to recollect that his State was one of the first (the first after South Carolina) to secede from the Union, and that if she now treats of peace on her own terms, as a sovereign State, she withdraws from the Confederacy, and leaves her sisters the bag to hold, after having got them into the scrape."

abstract: To-night HALEVY'S opera of the "Jewess" will be given for the second and last time. Mr. GROVER announces that it has had the benefit of additional rehearsals, and that the costumes will be new being a part of those recently imported for the company.
lead_paragraph: -- To-night HALEVY'S opera of the "Jewess" will be given for the second and last time. Mr. GROVER announces that it has had the benefit of additional rehearsals, and that the costumes will be new being a part of those recently imported for the company. To-morrow night "Don Giovanni" will be played, and the German season will positively close. The caste of the opera is unusually strong, embracing the names of nearly all the artists. FORMES appears in his great role of Leporello, and HERMAN is the commandatore. Herr LEEMAN (a new addition to the troupe) is the Don Juan, and FRAULEUR DZINBA (her first appearance) the Zerlina. FREDERICI and JOHANSEN are the Elvira and Anna, and Herr HABLEMAN is the Count. Altogether the performance promises to be an unusually effective one. "Robert le Diable" was played at the matinee on Saturday. The house was well attended, although not so crowded as it would have been had the weather been less threatening. The opera was given with a great deal of spirit, and we were glad to notice that Mme. ROTTER, was in much better voice than heretofore. She was frequently and justly applauded. Herr FORMES' Bertram was admirable.

abstract: The, and Montgomery Constitution; Montgomery Constitution and the Copperheads
snippet: The, and Montgomery Constitution; Montgomery Constitution and the Copperheads
lead_paragraph: It was originally a fiercely disputed point in the conclaves of the traitors whether the rebellion Should be made under the old flag, and on the ground of the old Union, or whether it should be made under a new flag and for an independent government. The one course had the recommendation of superior facilities, and an easier method; the other of more stable and satisfactory results. A rebellion by the South under the pretext of regaining and securing constitutional rights unjustly denied, it was urged, would be upheld by the Northern Democratic organization, which had always stood by the South, and would be strong enough to give it the complete rule of the country. But on the other hand, it was urged, that the Northern ballot-box would yet remain, and that there could be no security; that the Northern Democracy itself could long stand; that the "Democracy," at all events, would not fight the South, and would divide the North; and that so far as positive external help was concerned, enough of it could be found in Europe.

abstract: As might have been expected, the nominations of General McCLELLAN has given entire satisfaction to the organs of the rebellion in England. LINCOLN and his policy, says the ...
lead_paragraph: As might have been expected, the nominations of General McCLELLAN has given entire satisfaction to the organs of the rebellion in England. LINCOLN and his policy, says the London Times, have received a heavy check, the Convention having chosen MCCLELLAN, "the man whom LINCOLN endeavored to put down -- the man most able to repair the errors and arrest the ruin plainly impending."

abstract: The congregation of this Church having outfit a new and very handsome edifice, on the corner of Thirty-fifth-street and Madison-avenue, and having sold their old edifice, corner of Twenty-eighth-street and Madison-avenue, to Rev. Dr. OSGOOD's congregation, the closing services were held there last evening. Rev. Drs. MONTGOMERY and HOUGHTON officiating. The history of the Church is one of the most interesting of any in the City. It was built some fourteen years ago by the congregation of Grace Church, called the Chapel of Grace, and intended for the many poor of the congregation who could not afford to pay pew-rent. The Rev. Mr. HARWOOD, now Rector of Trinity Church, at New Haven, was its first rector. In March, 1855, Rev. Dr. MONTGOMERY first entered the church as its rector. He commenced the performance of his duties with great zeal and energy, and has never flagged for a moment since, and his efforts have been crowned with the success they so fully deserved. Under his guidance, and through his efforts, the congregation, in about three years from the time he first came among them, purchased the edifice from Grace Church, paying them for it its original cost. Grace Church used the purchase money to build another church for the poor, in a neighborhood where one was much needed, viz: in Thirty-first-street, near Second-avenue, and of which Rev. Mr. DICSON is now Pastor. In March, 1863, Rev. Dr. MONTGOMERY, in his anniversary sermon, proposed to his congregation the building of a new church. The large and growing congregation rendered it almost necessary, and, in accordance with this suggestion, a meeting was sailed, and it was decided to build a new church, with the provision that $50,000 should first be subscribed by responsible parties. This amount was soon obtained, a site secured corner Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, and the new building commenced. It is now nearly completed. The new church is of the early decorative Gothic order, and is intended to seat about twelve hundred people, without the side galleries. It is built of Newark stone, the dressings and weatherings of Cleveland stone; the Chancel of Apisdal, and lighted from above. By its side is the organ-chamber, in which is to be placed a superb organ, manufactured by STAMBRIDGE, and to cost about $8,000. The organ, and a lot of ground valued at about $2,000, is a gift from one member of the congregation. The wheel of the organ is to be turned by a running stream of water, a new style, and one which it is said will produce a greater evenness of sound. A peculiar feature of the building will be a beautiful series of memorial windows. The Church is to have a spire some 185 or 190 feet high, and its cost, without the spire, will be about $130,000.

abstract: Defeat of Early
snippet: Defeat of Early
lead_paragraph: Nothing further of importance has been received from the Shenandoah Valley. At the latest accounts Gen. SHERIDAN was pushing up the valley in untiring pursuit of the flying and demoralized rebels, who so recently were threatening a raid into Maryland and Pennsylvania; and it is thought that they will nowhere be able to make an effective stand against our victorious troops. Deserters to the Army of the Potomac say, that the rebels are very much disheartened by the unexpected defeat of EARLY's picked troops. Richmond papers admit the defeat in the Valley, and give their loss at 2,400 men.

abstract: The Jewish Synagogue erected for the congregation, Aderath Eb, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The edifice is situated in Twenty-ninth-street, between Lexington and Third-avenues, built of brick, and capable of accommodating about fire hundred people. The interior fittings are neat and handsome, without being gaudy. The services yesterday were the customary dedication exercises, according to the Hebrew ritual. The sacred scrolls of the law were carried in procession three times around the Synagogue, and the perpetual lamp lighted in front of the arch while the Chazan and the choir chanted the Psalms of David. Addresses were delivered by Dr. RAPHAEL and Dr. L.M. ISAACS, Capt. BURDICK, and a squad of the Twenty-first Precinct Police, rendered efficient aid in preserving order at the door and keeping out unbidden guests.

The edifice is situated in Twenty-ninth-street, between Lexington and Third-avenues, built of brick, and capable of accommodating about fire hundred people. The interior fittings are neat and handsome, without being gaudy. The services yesterday were the customary dedication exercises, according to the Hebrew ritual. The sacred scrolls of the law were carried in procession three times around the Synagogue, and the perpetual lamp lighted in front of the arch while the Chazan and the choir chanted the Psalms of David. Addresses were delivered by Dr. RAPHAEL and Dr. L.M. ISAACS, Capt. BURDICK, and a squad of the Twenty-first Precinct Police, rendered efficient aid in preserving order at the door and keeping out unbidden guests.

abstract: Prices; Public Confidence Revived
snippet: Prices; Public Confidence Revived
lead_paragraph: The enemies of the Administration have cited the high price of gold, and the consequent high price of all the necessaries of life, as evidence of the failure of the Administration. It was proof, they said, that the people had no faith in their ability to put down the rebellion. To a certain extent the assertion was true. Gold has gone up as confidence in the Government went down. Setting aside the natural and inevitable effect of large issues of paper money, and the efforts of speculators also to create an artificial demand for coin, the price of gold is a fair measure of the public confidence in the Government. While the people believed, or feared, that we could not put down the rebellion, -- that the war would go on without restoring the Union,their faith in the value of Government bonds of necessity grew less and less, and the comparative value of gold grew more and more.

abstract: A large and enthusiastic Union meeting was held last night. At the close, several hundred disorderly partisans of McCLELLAN attempted to head off and break up the procession. A general riot seemed imminent; but the forbearance of the assailed and activity of the police prevented it. Only one man was injured.

abstract: Victories in the Shenandoah
snippet: Victories in the Shenandoah
lead_paragraph: On Friday Morning SHERIDAN, having pursued the retreating rebels from Fisher's Mountain during the night, found it necessary to rest and issue rations to his men at Woodstock. To that point the commanding general had pressed torward with the whole of the Sixth and Nineteenth Corps; General TORBERT having meanwhile pushed up the Luray Valley with a powerful cavalry force, intended to intercept the panic-stricken remnants of EARLY's men before they could reach Harrisonburgh. Much importance is attached by General SHERIDAN to this cavalry advance by his left. If TORBERT has rightly interpreted his orders great results are confidently promised. But even already SHERIDAN's victory has assumed proportions beyond his reckoning. The rebels, he tells us, after the attack on our position at Fisher's Mountain, threw down their arms and fled in the greatest confusion, abandoning most of their artillery. Gen. SHERIDAN does not believe there ever was an army so badly routed; and as an evidence of how complete is its demoralization, he finds the soldiers EARLY has picked up in the Valley hiding away in great numbers and returning to their homes. What the absolute loss to EARLY in men will ultimately prove is thus made difficult of computation, by the fact that the unwilling conscripts, no longer afraid of the Richmond military despotism finding the means or opportunity hereafter of enforcing its decrees among the farmers of the Valley, are eagerly taking advantage of the rout, either to get back (each in his own way) to their homes, or to get effectually beyond the reach of their rebel taskmasters.
headline: {'main': 'The Victories in the Shenandoah.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victories in the Shenandoah.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Late yesterday afternoon a quarrel took place in Whitehall-street, between PHILIP CAUSLAND and THOMAS FLYNN, an Irishman. During the trouble FLYNN drew a dirk knife and stabbed his opponent in the heart. The latter was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he was pronounced fatally injured. FLYNN has been arrested by the First Ward Police, and is held to await the result.

abstract: By the arrival at Farther Point of the steamship North America, from Liverpool, we have European news to the 12th inst. The news of the nomination of Gen. MCCLELLAN had reached England, and formed the most prominent topic of discussion in the London and local journals. The rebel organs welcome the nomination as one likely to give a "heavy check to Mr. LINCOLN and his policy." The Prince and Princess of Wales are receiving enthusiastic demonstrations in Denmark. They are expected to visit Sweden and St. Petersburgh. Prince HUMBERT, of Italy, reached Southampton on the 12th, and immediately proceeded to London.

abstract: EXTENSIVE FIRES -- DESTRUCTION OF THE BROOKLYN WHITE LEAD WORKS -- THE CATHOLIC CHURCH OF THE ASSUMPTION GREATLY DAMAGED -AND SEVERAL DWELLINGS INJURED. -- An extensive fire broke out yesterday afternoon about 4 o'clock, in the Brooklyn White Lead Works, which occupied the block bounded by Washington, Adams, Front, and Water streets, and consisted of several brick buildings and a number of wooden sheds. The flames spread rapidly and communicated to all the structures, including stable, worshops, &c., embraced in the space occupied by the company, excepting only the houses on the seperate four corners, which were saved. The fire originated in the corroding sheds fronting on Water-street, and then extended to the other buildings within the block, which were of wood, and all were destroyed. The buildings on the different corners, consisting of the residence of Mr. D. FARLEY, the superintendent, the store house, cooper shop, and mill room were saved. All the structures within the block were destroyed.

abstract: Journals on their Late Disasters
snippet: Journals on their Late Disasters
lead_paragraph: The rebel journals are trying to keep up rebel spirits under late disasters. The Richmond papers of Saturday, strange to say, had not heard of the great rout of EARLY at Fisher's Hill, on Thursday, but insisted even then that Fisher's Hill was impregnable to attack from the front. The Dispatch is happy to say that the spirits of the people generally have not been materially affected by late occurrences. They have become accustomed to the casualties, of war, and know that unvarying success cannot be expected. The Dispatch, however, seems to fear that Old Virginia is going to be left in the lurch by some of her sister Southern States, and makes the following significant remarks: " The State of Virginia is as determined this day to persevere until her, independence, and that of her sister States, be secured, as she was on the day that she seceded from the Union. We speak only for Virginia." The other Richmond papers, of which ast night we received a large bundle, talk in a similar desperately cheerful tone of rebel prospects.

abstract: We beg leave to congratulate our readers upon the information we have received, from a source we deem unquestionable, that the President of the Confederate States has tendered to Gen. BEAUREGARD the command of the army in Georgia. Of course, he must accept It. This result, we learn, has been brought about by the earnest intervention and counsel of Gen. LEE. We regret that the counsel of any one was necessary to occasion an appointment so "fit to be made." But it is well that it is made; and must allay the disgust which the supercession of Gen. JOHNSON, and the appointtment of Gen. HOOD to the command of this army produced. Let the President now support Gen. BEAUREGARD in all the measures practicable to give him success. Let him allow Gen. BBAUREGARD freely to choose his own staff, and carry out his recommendations, and throw into his hands all the reinforcements which can be spared from every quarter. The spirit of our people will rally to the support of our cause. The deep depression our late disasters produced will be changed for a cheerful and lively hope. The gallant "General, whose star has ever led to victory by his very name, inspires congdence of success. Let the people everywhere rise up and go forth to the great struggle for their liberties and existence, prepared to follow wherever he shall lead, and our redemption will be accomplished. We cordially support President DAVIS in this appointment.

abstract: Theological Society of Catholic Clergy; Archbishop Spalding's Letter to
snippet: Theological Society of Catholic Clergy; Archbishop Spalding's Letter to
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the New-York Theological Society, composed of Catholic clergymen, was held, for the transaction of business, at St. Xavier's College, in Sixteenth-street, on Thursday, the 22d inst. Rev. Dr. CUMMINGS, President of the society, opened the meeting with a few brief remarks. He stated that the idea of the society had originated with some of the younger members of the clergy. He has cordially lent his approval and cooperation to such noble purposes, and reluctantly consulted even to act as President of the society. There was no particular class or school that could control it for any purposes of its own -- no inside organization or understanding. Its meetings were to be held with open doors, and every priest in the country was free to attend, offer suggestions, and participate in the fruits of brotherly and learned interchange.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council were in session yesterday. In the Board of Aldermen, two messages were received from the Mayor, and referred to Committees. One related to the difficulties about the the fire telegraph, and recommended that steps be taken to effect a settlement with Mr. ROBINSON, the patented and owner of the dial boxes used; and the other related to [???]melting. In the latter message, Mayor CUNTHER vigorously sets forth his reasons for declining to convoke the Board of Health. Inthe same Board, a solution to donate [???] 000 to the Thirty-seventh Regiment, N.Y. S.N.G., to procure new uniforms, was presented and referred. This efficient corps have never been the recipient of a dollar from either the State or City, except for hire of drill-rooms and armory, and very recently all their property, including band uniforms just purchased, were lost by fire. They are entitled to sympathy and merit substantial aid. The Street Commissioner reported that the Manhattan Gas Co., in addition to the Metropolitan Co., have raised the price per street-lamp to $50 per year, and recommends that, as formerly, contracts be made for street gas, so as to have fixed prices. Both Boards passed resolutions by Alderman JONES, thanking our soldiers and sailors for the recent victories, empowering special committee of ten to have the public buildings illuminated, and requesting the Mayor to invite, by proclamation, our citizens to cooperate and make the illumination general in honor of these victories. Both Boards adjourned to Thursday.

abstract: Last week Brig.-Gen. ASHBOTH, with a Yankee cavalry force, went from the Navy Yard, Pensacola, for the purpose of capturing one of our scouting parties; but hearing that the Fifteenth Confederate cavalry was in motion to intercept him, fell back in haste. In crossing the ford at the mouth of Big Bayou after dark, he neglected to make proper signals to the gunboats at that point. Mistaking him for a Confederate, they opened a fire of grape and canister, and the result was that twenty-seven of his command were killed and a considerable number wounded.

Mistaking him for a Confederate, they opened a fire of grape and canister, and the result was that twenty-seven of his command were killed and a considerable number wounded.

abstract: Onward March
snippet: Onward March
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERIDAN was six miles South of Newmarket on Saturday evening, or about ninetysix miles South-west of Harper's Ferry. His men probably had ten hours rest at Woodstock. Certainly not more. What rations were served out to them, we apprehend, must have been carried in their knapsacks. It is barely probable the supply train could have come up with them before they left Woodstock. SHERIDAN evidently pushed forward to Newmarket in the sure hope that his parallel column of cavalry under TORBERT, dashing up the Luray Valley, would intercept the retreating army either on the road which crosses the Peaked Mountain Ridge and connects Luray Court House with Newmarket, or head them off where the Shenandoah Valley proper and the Luray join near Harrisonburgh. SHERIDAN's movements were doubtless turned to meet the conjuncture thus pre-ararranged. And for energy, decision, and exactitude, this advance of a large body of infantry -- comprising the two full Corps under EMORY and WRIGHT -- has scarcely been equalled in the history of the war.
headline: {'main': "Sheridan's Onward March.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Sheridan's Onward March.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: General HAMPTON'S late foray upon the larder of GRANT was a very useful, as well as a very brilliant, affair. It furnishes our army with about one million of pounds of the best beef which the Yankee markets affords, and will feed them full for some time yet to come. GRANT has proved nearly as serviceable to LEE in his quality of commissary and quartermaster as BANKS did to JACKSON in times gone by.

abstract: Captured, by Rebels
snippet: Captured, by Rebels
lead_paragraph: An official bulletin from Secretary STANTON says that on 11 o'clock Saturday night Gen. SHERIDAN'S army was six miles south of Newmarket. He had driven the enemy from Mount Jackson without being able to bring on an engagement. The enemy were moving rapidly, and he had no cavalry present to hold them. TORBERT had attacked WICKHAM'S force at Luray, and captured a number of prisoners. SHERIDAN found rebel hospitals in all the towns from Winchester to Newmarket, and was eighty miles from Martinsburgh. Twenty pieces of artillery were captured at Fisher's Hill, together with eleven hundred prisoners, a large amount of ammunition, caissons, limbers, &c, and a large quantity of intrenching tools, small arms and debris. Gen. STEVENS reports the arrival at Harper's Ferry of a train of our wounded, twenty captured guns, and eighty additional captured officers.

abstract: Help them by Fighting Copperheads
snippet: Help them by Fighting Copperheads
lead_paragraph: An officer in SHERIDAN'S army writes home to his friends: "Fight against the Copperheads -- crush them -- and by so doing you will greatly encourage the army and make us perfectly sure of success and that a speedy one." He is not the only one who has that feeling. Said Gen. HOOKER, in his speech at the Union meeting in Brooklyn last week, "Your victories are as dear to us in the front as the victories at the front are dear to you. The victories of last Fall were hailed with as much joy and as much enthusiasm in the army as though they had been achieved by other armies."

abstract: We did not think proper yesterday morning to make any remarks, except in the news columns of this paper, upon the reverse experienced last Monday by the army under General EARLY. We preferred to wait until we could gather more facts and form a more decided opinion from the concordance or discrepancy of such portions of the testimony as were presented to our observation. Even now, after the lapse of several days since the action, the materials for a correct judgment are very scanty. These facts, however, seem sufficiently clear:

abstract: Rumors and Electioneering Arts
snippet: Rumors and Electioneering Arts
lead_paragraph: The air will be thick with peace rumors of all shapes and colors until election day -the weak inventions of a desperate enemy. Ingenuity will be racked for new issues, or at least new semblances of issues, with which to distract and bewilder. We may look continually for a repetition, in every mode, of the Niagara attempt to get the President into a false position, by making him seem an obstacle to a reasonable and honorable reconcillation. This, in fact, is now the only resource of the Copperheads. They dare not charge, as of old, upon the Administration any inefficiency in conducting the war, in the face of the achievements of GRANT, and SHERMAN, and SHERIDAN, and FARRAGUT. On that score they are hopelessly silenced. Their shift now must be, not that the war is prosecuted with weakness, but that it is prosecuted without necessity. They will try every expedient to make it appear that blood continues to be shed, when a satisfactory peace might easily be secured by what MCCLELLAN styles the "resources of a wise statesmanship."
headline: {'main': 'Electioneering Arts and Peace Rumors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Electioneering Arts and Peace Rumors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Affairs on the
snippet: Affairs on the
lead_paragraph: -- There is no news from the Rio Grande by way of New-Orleans which throws serious discredit on the story of CORTINAS having driven the rebels out of Brownsville. The story of the "Illinois Sergeant," to which very general credence was given, was apparently founded upon the fact that a portion of the Mexican band, fighting under CORTINAS, deserted him after the failure to drive the French from Bagdad, and crossing the river, joined the United States forces stationed at Brazos Santiago. The deserters, however, are said to have numbered but three hundred; the remainder of CORTINA's army having stuck to the fortunes of their chief on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande. The original story, moreover, had this further foundation, that the rebels under FORD made an attack upon our small force commanded by Major NOYES, some distance from Brazos, after it had been joined by the Mexican deserters. But neither side appears to have gained much advantage in the engagements which followed.

abstract: a Word to
snippet: a Word to
lead_paragraph: -- A rigid economy on the part of housekeepers at this crisis in the gold market, would bring about a wonderful revolution in the general provision business, before the dawn of another Sunday morning. The fall in gold may stagger the dealers to some perceptible degree. But in order to strike a blow at the petty trade combination which they shall really feel; economy, rigid and systematic, is the grand requirement of the time. Most families could do with half the quantity of butter they consume, and feel as well as look the better for the abstinence. The same applies -- although in a less degree -- to heavy joints of meats which are often allowed to go to waste. Let economy be the order -- if only to see how the experiment will work.

abstract: It is well known that the light draft iron-clads have not come up to the standard anticipated by their designer. Twenty of them were commenced and got pretty well advanced on the stocks; one of the number was launched, and did meet the anticipations of the Navy Department. A commission was organized, among whom, we are told, were Admiral GREGORY, Capt. ERICSSON and others. The result of the investigation was, that fourteen of them will have their sides raised twenty-two inches, and the remaining six will have no turret, and be used as "torpedo boats" in harbors, having a single gun on the deck. Three of the light draft iron-clad are building at Greenpoint. The Modoc, at the yard of Mr. UNDERHILL, will be a torpedo boat, having no turret and but a single gun, otherwise carried out according to the original plan; Inspector LARNED superintends the work. The Cohoes, building at the Continental Work, will have her deck raised twenty-two inches. The Naubuc, building at Capt. PERINE's yard, will be a torpedo boat, similar to the Modoc, and will be launched in about a month.
