abstract: Denial of Cheers for Union Victory
snippet: Denial of Cheers for Union Victory
lead_paragraph: -- The Journal of Commerce takes upon itself to deny our statement that when the news of SHERIDAN's victory was posted on its bulletin, the crowd that gathered round cheered for President LINCOLN. We are not surprised at this, for the fact is a hard one for the Copperheads to get over. Certainly no one in the crowd thought of cheering for MCCLELLAN. But we allege again that the crowd did cheer for President LINCOLN, and if the Journal desires it the fact can easily be established by affidavit. And it is not hard to tell "what made them do it." It was because they felt that there was "an intimate connection," as the Charleston Courier says, between Gen. EARLY's forces and the followers of Gen. MCCLELLAN, and that the defeat of the former made surer the defeat of the latter; because they saw the long faces and sour looks of the McClellan men around them, and the rejoicing looks of the Lincoln men, and because they knew that those cheers grated as harshly on the ears of the Journal as did the cheers for the Union which rang around the same office a few days after the fall of Fort Sumter. The Journal says its "flag was simultaneously given to the breeze." So it was on that same 17th of April, 1861, and just about as heartily. Instead of the idea of a connection between the victory and the cheers for Mr. LINCOLN being "preposterous," as the Journal says it was, that connection was logically inevitable.
headline: {'main': 'THE CHEERS FOR PRESIDENT LINCOLN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE CHEERS FOR PRESIDENT LINCOLN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The latest news from the Army of the Potomac represents everything as quiet. Our correspondent at Gen. BUTLER's headquarters, whose statements can be implicitly relied upon, says that the recent victories over EARLY has resulted in rendering Confederate paper utterly valueless, -- that gold, which was selling at the rate of one dollar for thirty in paper before the battle, cannot now be bought at any price. He also states that LEE has sent one brigade and two regiments to reinforce EARLY -- all too late.

abstract: The first of a series of mass meetings to be held during the pending campaign, to aid in restoring the Union by the election of loyal candidates for the United States and State Governments, took place last evening at the Cooper Institute, within and without. Over thirty thousand persons were present to listen to the stirring addresses of the distinguished speakers. It was an enthusiastic demonstration, and the interest in the proceedings did not flag until nearly midnight, when the meeting adjourned.

abstract: On the 13th the demand for Discount at the Bank was moderate, and a general impression prevailed that for the present the period of greatest stringency had passed. Consols experienced another improvement of 1/8 cent., and were well maintained to the close. Money for short periods, was very abundant, both in the Stock, and in the open market. The Confederate loan recovered 1/8 cent of its previous decline, owing to the doubts thrown by the Times on the news of the capture of Atlanta.

abstract: Conference Closed
snippet: Conference Closed
lead_paragraph: The preliminary conferences of the delegates appointed to discuss the question of a Federative Union of the Provinces, have closed. Meetings of a more or less formal character have been held at the capital towns of the three Maritime Colonies, and the leading delegates who have been entertained at a public banquet in Halifax have partially broken the seal of silence heretofore imposed upon their deliberations. The sum of the revelation then is, that the scheme of Union, so far as it has been canvassed, is found to be practicable. The members present at the various conferences are united in their opinion as to the desirability of a Union, which, while it shall leave each Province a certain control in all matters of local concern, shall yet subordinate the whole to a strong central governing body. The general feeling is in favor of a federal system which shall designate the specific powers, functions and responsibilities of the local governing bodies; leaving all else to the absolute control of the central body -- our system inverted, as it were, in this essential feature. The whole scheme, however, is only yet conceived in the crudest form. Another meeting of the delegates will be held at Quebec, to consider something like a common basis of action for reference to the Legislature of each separate Province as they now stand. During the coming sessions of the Colonial Parliaments, the business of Federation will be dealt with in detail; and probably several sessions will be consumed in its discussion, before a final decision is reached.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. GROVER's short, but brilliantly successful season, came to an end last evening, when "Don Giovanni" was played to an extremely intelligent audience. We have rarely heard the opera to better advantage. The various artists were all in grand voice, and displayed an easy familiarity with the music, which tendered its interpretation pleasant to all concerned. Herr FORMES was admirable as Leporello. It is one of his finest roles. Herr HABELMAN was also excellent as the Count, and in the introduced aria of the first act, produced a genuine sensation. It was neatly phrased and artistically delivered. Mme. JOHANNSEN, as Donna Anna, sang with great spirit. The erlina of the evening was a debutante named DZIABA -- a bright and intelligent blonde, who is destined, we fancy, to become a favorite with the public. Her voice is not powerful, but it is musical, and will improve with study and practice. Don Giovanni found a good dramatic representative in Herr LEHMAN -- a gentleman who was formerly connected with the German stage, but who, possessing a good voice, has recently devoted himself to music. Herr LEHMAN has an agreeable organ, but it lacks power for so large a house as the Academy. He is, nevertheless, the best German Don Giovanni we have had on our stage. The orchestra and chorus were both in capital trim.

abstract: Fall in; and Prices of Goods
snippet: Fall in; and Prices of Goods
lead_paragraph: The "crash" so long predicted in these columns has at length begun. The currency, measuring by gold as its standard, has risen in value forty per cent. within a few days; that is, every person who receives money in wages or salary, or in any form in which paper is used, has nearly half as much income again as he had before. The purchasing power of the dollar ought to have risen forty per cent. So all who had accumulated stores of produce and provisions, or cotton and woollen fabrics, or manufactures, will generally find themselves worth forty per. cent less than they thought themselves. All values must fall which have been affected by the depreciation of the currency. Real estate will go down; stocks are already tumbling. Men that counted their property in certain stocks a few weeks ago, by the hundreds of thousand, must soon count by the fifties and sixties. It is true no one as yet can say, how far the railroad bonds and stocks represent, in their recent values, the immensely improved condition of the roads, and how far they are the result of inflated currency. But at present, people sell on the uncertainty. Government securities themselves go down slightly, though they have so much risen in real value, because people must have money in such times, and will sell anything. Many, no doubt, also sell "Governments" to buy into the very cheap railroad securities offered now on the market. Others calculate -- mistakenly we think -- on United States stocks being returned from the other side to be sold, before exchange has become so much in our favor as to make it a profitable transaction.
headline: {'main': 'The Fall in Gold and the Prices of Goods.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fall in Gold and the Prices of Goods.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Maj.-Gen. HOOKER received orders at a late hour on Monday night to report immediately to the Secretary of War for assignment to duty. The General accordingly left the Astor House yesterday morning, and arrived in Washington last evening. The exact nature or field of the General's future action is not yet known. The public, however, will be delighted to know that such a gallant leader is soon again to be in the saddle, aiding to give the finishing blows to the rebellion. The General's brief period of retirement has been a season of much needed rest and social enjoyment, and he returns with a renewed zest for vigorous service.
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. HOOKER received orders at a late hour on Monday night to report immediately to the Secretary of War for assignment to duty. The General accordingly left the Astor House yesterday morning, and arrived in Washington last evening. The exact nature or field of the General's future action is not yet known. The public, however, will be delighted to know that such a gallant leader is soon again to be in the saddle, aiding to give the finishing blows to the rebellion. The General's brief period of retirement has been a season of much needed rest and social enjoyment, and he returns with a renewed zest for vigorous service.

abstract: -- Col. G.A. PIERCE, Inspector U.S.A., is stopping for a few days at the Astor House, on his way to Hilton Head, S.C., where he goes on a tour of inspection, by order of the War Department. Col. PIERCE is just from the Ninth (Mr. COLFAX's) District of Indiana, and gives the most cheering news of the prospect there. Notwithstanding the large number of loyal men who are absent from the State in the army, Col. PIERCE is perfectly confident that Mr. COLFAX will be elected by an increased majority, and that the State will give a large majority for LINCOLN and JOHNSON in November.

The Chicago nominations, and the capture of Atlanta, formed the principal topics of discussion in the London papers. The signification of these events is variously interpreted, the rebel organs taking the ground that the capture of Atlanta sinks into insignificancebeside the nomination of MCCLELLAN, while the News and the Star takes exactly the opposite view. The Prince of WALES has abandoned his design of visiting St. Petersburg, on account of the lateness of the season. The statement that Capt. abstract: Rebel Peace Diversion in
snippet: Rebel Peace Diversion in
lead_paragraph: -- Gens. KIRBY SMITH and SHELBY, of the rebel army -- if we are to believe a variety of reports which we publish this morning -- have undertaken a diversion in favor of the Peace party in the State of Missouri. The statements of refugees and various nameless authorities from Pilot Knob and elsewhere, supply conjectural estimates of the number of the advancing rebels. These estimates allow a sufficient margin for possible errors. One story is, that the combined force of SHELBY & Co. "will be from ten thousand to twenty thousand, with sixteen pieces of artillery." Another "refugee" has information from Fort Pillow that KIRBY SMITH is encamped forty miles from that fort, with 15,000 men. This interesting news-dealer believes that SMITH's force is bound for Missouri. The story of the invasion altogether has a marine aspect about it. But such as we find it, it is the best election item the Chicago Copperheads have had since they constructed their platform. If SHELBY and KIRBY SMITH can keep their "ten or twenty thousand men" in Missouri till after the election, they will be all that number of votes the stronger when the returns come in. That is, unless Gen. ROSECRANS should meanwhile interfere with the arrangement, as it is not unlikely he may do. The militia of the State are called on to unite with the Commanding General in expelling the raiding force, be it great or small. And the expulsion of the electioneering party, we have reason to believe, will neither be a serious nor a prolonged task.

abstract: Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York
snippet: Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York; Union Speech in New-York
lead_paragraph: The first of the series of grand mass meetings in the City of New-York, to aid the cause of Union and Liberty, through the election of the candidates representing the loyalty of the American people, was held last night at the Cooper Institute. It was called for half-past seven o'clock, but at a quarter before seven, and before the doors were opened, a mass of people had congregated amounting in numbers, more than sufficient to fill the immense hall of the building. It was crowded in all its parts, there being neither room for sitting or standing auditor when the meeting was organized, more than were packed within its walls.

abstract: The inside meeting, in point of numbers, was to the outside as the pebbles on the beach to the sands of the sea shore. If the numbers were estimated, according to the arithmetic used at Copperhead meetings, they would be set down at 75,000 or more, but as that number could not stand in any public square in this city, we prefer to adhere to probabilities and call it 20,000.
lead_paragraph: The inside meeting, in point of numbers, was to the outside as the pebbles on the beach to the sands of the sea shore. If the numbers were estimated, according to the arithmetic used at Copperhead meetings, they would be set down at 75,000 or more, but as that number could not stand in any public square in this city, we prefer to adhere to probabilities and call it 20,000. Six stands, including one German stand, were erected for the accommodation of speakers, and all of them were surrounded, from 8 o'clock until 10 with a crowd of eagre listeners, who rent the air with one continual cheer for the Union candidates, and for the sentiments uttered by the speakers. Each of the stands was surrounded by a row of Chinese lanterns, on which were inscribed the names of the National and State candidates, together with appropriate mottos, such as, "The Union and the Constitution," "The Union and Liberty. "All men are born equal." "SHERMAN and HOOKER," "GRANT and FARRAGUT." etc. About nine o'clock the ward processions commenced pouring info the square, and soon filled the entire space between the various stands with one compact mass of humanity. First came the "Sixteenth Ward Union War Eagle," bearing in front a large banner with a spread eagle in the centre, around which was the following inscription: -- "The Old Game-Cock -- No White Feathers in my Tail." Next came the "Nineteenth Ward War Eagles," headed by three Express wagons, each drawn by six horses and filled with the Union patriots bearing aloft the banners of their candidates. The first wagon mounted a brass cannon which belched forth at intervels its war sentiments in thundering tones, to the great dismay of a mob of Peace Democrats who had spent the fore part of the evening in trying to interrupt the various speakers and quench the general enthusiasm by their feeble groans. So disgusted were they with the demonstration of the Nineteenth Warders, that they retreated to a corner grocery over on the Third-avenue, where, for the remainder of the evening, they entertained a collection of forty or fifty boys with cheers for MCCLELLAN, VALLANDIGHAM, JEFF. DAVIS, and others of that ilk, interspersed with coarse and obscene slang about the Union candidates. Among the other processions which followed the Nineteenth Warders were the "Eighteenth Ward Lincoln and Johnson Club," the "Twelfth Ward Union Club," the "Twenty-second Ward Lincoln and Johnson Club," the "Twenty-second Ward German Union Club," and various other organizations, all bearing significant and appropriate banners. We are informed that the "Twelfth Ward Union Club" were attacked near Forty-eighth street, on their way down, by a gang of MCCLELLAN rowdies, who threw stones and brickbats, injuring several members of the club severely.

abstract: The Government are taking decisive steps to arrest and bring to justice these pests of society. Yesterday seventy of these military miscreants were arrested and brought from Elmira to the Castle Garden Barracks, where they were delivered in safekeeping to the military authorities of our City at present located in the Castle Garden. Much praise is due to two officers and five men of the Brooklyn Fifty-sixth Regiment for bringing those "jumpers" to headquarters in New-York. They will be dealt with as their offence deserves by the Military Department at Washington, and it is stated that they will be sent to the headquarters of Gen. GRANT, where they will be placed in front of the first engagement.

abstract: If everybody would "let well enough alone," and not officiously or otherwise seek to mend it, everybody would be better off. While not impugning the charitable motives of certain ladies and gentlemen who insist on voluntarily visiting the different United States hospitals hereabouts, and distributing fruit and other luxuries to the sick, their good sense and discretion are open to severe criticism.
lead_paragraph: If everybody would "let well enough alone," and not officiously or otherwise seek to mend it, everybody would be better off. While not impugning the charitable motives of certain ladies and gentlemen who insist on voluntarily visiting the different United States hospitals hereabouts, and distributing fruit and other luxuries to the sick, their good sense and discretion are open to severe criticism. They do actual injury by a well meant but ignorant application of their charity. There is nothing wanted in any of the United States hospitals, either in the way of comforts, luxuries, or aught else, that the United States Government does not liberally supply; and as to the surgical and medical care, the nursing and the attendance, these are conceded to be of the very best. It is to be presumed that the surgeons in charge know better the condition of their patients and their requirements than occasional philanthropic visitors, who have neither the opportunity nor the inclination to inform themselves of the particulars and condition of individual cases. They visit the hospitals certainly with the best intentions, loaded down with fruit, jams, jellies, &c., etc., and indiscriminately and profusely turn them over to the sick, when in many cases such are of immediate and positive injury. We know of two instances of death caused by this thoughtless philanthropy. The Government, as we have said, furnishes all things in profusion -- fruit, vegetables, preserves, &c., &c., and they are dealt out to the patients with all the liberality their cases will admit of. No more tender care could be taken of the soldiers, nor more solicitude exhibted for them, and it is to be doubted if as much, by these well-meaning but indiscreet and touchey outsiders of either gender, than is evinced and exhibited by the U.S. officers in charge of them. This meddlesome intrusion, well-meaning it is, works no good, but actual harm, and we notice lately has induced a very untruthful and ungenerous reflection on our Government and its officers, in a paper which, were it better posted as to the facts, would better post the public on them.
headline: {'main': 'Killing with Kindness.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Killing with Kindness.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: London Times' Arguments for American Voters; London Times' Left-handed Compliment; London Times' Left-hand Compliment
snippet: London Times' Arguments for American Voters; London Times' Left-handed Compliment; London Times' Left-hand Compliment
lead_paragraph: The London Times has "gone into" our political campaign with a vehemence and persistency that almost make it look as if it were a President for England that is about to be elected, instead of a President of the United States -- the chief magistrate of a foreign land. The Chicago platform suits it to a dot, or rather, it lacks about a dot of suiting it. The Chicago declaration, that the war has been a total failure, is totally true. The declaration for an immediate cessation of hostilities, is at once consoling and noble. The proposition for an armistice is the proper thing to propose. The covert disunionism of the platform is admirable, as far as it goes, only it should not have been covert. Had Chicago boldly pronounced for disunion per se, it would have been altogether good; had it pronounced in favor of the next disruption after the present one, it would have been still better; had it pronounced in favor of a division of the great Republic into five, or twenty-five independent "Governments," after the plan drawn up by "Sir BULWER," it would have been as perfect as anything emanating from the Northern States of America. But, as it is, the platform of VALLANDIGHAM is good enough to command the ardent admiration and support of the London Times.

abstract: Tallahassee; Piety and Cowardly Outrages
snippet: Tallahassee; Piety and Cowardly Outrages
lead_paragraph: Those who wish to discover some of the beauties and amenities of Confederate privateering may read with profit the diary of a volunteer on board the Tallahassee, which we republish in full from two late numbers of the Richmond Dispatch. Capt. WOOD will be found to be a fine specimen of a peace rebel; -- one, moreover, who sets about his business in a truly christian and piratical spirit. It was Sunday, the 7th of August, when he started from Wilmington; and the historian of the Tallahassee tells us at the outset in most unctuous phrase, that it was a "calm quiet Sabbath day, and Capt. WOOD read service on the quarter deck to all hands." It seems to have been an occasion, too, for special thanksgiving; for, though half a dozen steamers gave chase to the pirate during the day, he providentially escaped. Prayers were in order also on Wednesday, for during a great portion of that day, if this pious narrator is to be believed, the Tallahasee had, by mistake, given chase to a United States frigate, only discovering that the anticipated prize was an armed man-of-war when the pursuer and the pursued were alongside of each other! This adventure took place close to our own doors, for on the following morning the Tallahassee was within twenty miles of Long Island. The same day was signalized by the capture of the pilot-boat No. 22, of New-York, which was at once turned into a tender to the Tallahassee, and served for two days in that capacity, fairly dividing the honors with the larger craft of bringing vessels to.
headline: {'main': 'The Cruise of the Tallahassee A Tale of Cowardly Outrages.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Cruise of the Tallahassee A Tale of Cowardly Outrages.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Some parties having attempted to make it appear that the Citizen's Association is antagonistic to Trades' Unions, and desires their breaking up, that Association is out with a positive disclaimer, saying that it desires no interference, direct or indirect, with the Trades' Unions, or with any of their regulations for the promotion of trade interests. The Association appeals to the working classes, simply as citizens, having vital interests in our municipal government; and all it asks of them is a hearty cooperation in securing a good one. In a great social movement like this, the members of the various trades can participate freely and earnestly, as citizens, without in the least compromising their position in their trade relations.

abstract: The County Convention summoned under the auspices of the Union General Committee, met at Hope Chapel last night. A temporary organization was effected, by the appointment of Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS as Chairman, J. SOLIS RITTERBAND and JAMES L. HASTIE, Secretaries.
lead_paragraph: The County Convention summoned under the auspices of the Union General Committee, met at Hope Chapel last night. A temporary organization was effected, by the appointment of Col. RUSH C. HAWKINS as Chairman, J. SOLIS RITTERBAND and JAMES L. HASTIE, Secretaries. The McLlellan Legion, which met in a lower room, being very enthusiastic in their demonstrations, at the suggestion of Mr. P. an answer was given by the convention by loudly cheering for LINCOLN and JOHNSON. Quite a discussion arose upon a motion to appoint a Conference Committee with the Citizens' Association and the Union Central Convention. A resolution was finally adopted appointing a committee of one from each Assembly District to confer with all Union Associations in this City, with a view of uniting on one ticket for local candidates. As expressive of their views, the convention proceeded to an informal ballot, with the following result:

abstract: Democrat of the Old School on the Chicago Platform
snippet: Democrat of the Old School on the Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: There are large numbers of candid Democrats who are no doubt carefully considering, at this time, on which side they shall deposit their votes. We commend to such a closer consideration than has yet been given, of that article of the Chicago Platform relating to a "Convention of the States." They are bound to conclude that the Platform of their party will essentially determine its policy, if it should come into power. The Peace-Democracy, having possession of the Government, will call a Convention of the States. But why do they propose this? Why was the measure made one of the resolutions of Chicago? It manifestly was not offered merely that an amendment of the Constitution could be discussed and passed -- some amendment, for instance, guaranteeing the power of Slavery. There were simpler methods of accomplishing this, laid down in the Constitution. Conventions in each of the States and votes of the Legislatures would have been the more natural and safer mode for attaining this end. Neither could it have been intended as a means of restoring the authority of the Union over the disaffected States. A Convention of the States would not secure this; would rather have brought about the opposite, for it would seem to agree with the very idea of Secession, that the States were everything, and the Union nothing.
headline: {'main': 'A Word to Candid Democrats.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Word to Candid Democrats.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met specially yesterday, to receive a report from the County Volunteer Committee, announcing that the quota of this county, under all calls, is filled, and that we have a surplus of twenty-eight enlistments.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met specially yesterday, to receive a report from the County Volunteer Committee, announcing that the quota of this county, under all calls, is filled, and that we have a surplus of twenty-eight enlistments. The filling of the last quota of 23,140, under the President's call for 500,000 men, has been accomplished with the modest outlay of $400,000. The brief report of the Committee, which we print elsewhere, embodies all the essential facts concerning the important task just completed. A detailed report is promised soon. The Board directed that the preliminary report be published, authorized the Committee to go on recruiting in anticipation of any future call, requested them to make renewed efforts to obtain further credits of naval enlistments due New-York, and passed a resolution requesting the Common Council to adopt the ordinance to prohibit recruiting here for other localities.

abstract: It is a good sign of success that the friends of the Union are almost everywhere putting in nomination for office, young, active, efficient men, who have the zeal, endurance, devotion and patriotism of youth. Especially is this the case in the nominations for Congress.
lead_paragraph: It is a good sign of success that the friends of the Union are almost everywhere putting in nomination for office, young, active, efficient men, who have the zeal, endurance, devotion and patriotism of youth. Especially is this the case in the nominations for Congress. HART, in Monroe; VAN HORN, in Niagara; POMEROY, in Cayuga; WARD, in Alleghany; CONKLING, in Oneida; DAVIS, in Onondaga; VAN EARNUM, in Cattaraugus; LARKIN, in Westchester; and KETCHUM, in Dutchess, have heretofore been marked instances of this partiality for "young men for action." A still later, and quite as satisfactory indorsement of the same feeling, is the nomination (for Congress) of Hon. ADDISON H. LAFLIN, in Herkimer. We believe Mr. LAFLIN has filled but one public office -- that of State Senator during the sessions of 1858 and '59; but his course there was so marked for intelligence and true statesmanship as to give positive assurance of a useful and patriotic career in Congress. He is certain to be elected, and we shall be surprised if he is not backed by a majority as proportionately large as that of any candidate in nomination.

abstract: Serenade and Union Speech
snippet: Serenade and Union Speech
lead_paragraph: It soon being noised abroad last evening that Gen. DIX was in the city, a crowd collected at the West House, and on Columbus-avenue, in front of it. The Union Band of Sandusky repaired to the house and played several airs, when the crowd, which was by this time very large, began calling for "DIX," "DIX," when he came out upon the balcony of the hotel, and was introduced to the crowd by Capt. STEINER as the man who early in the war uttered that noble sentiment -- "If any man dares pull down the American flag shoot him on the spot."

lead_paragraph: The Nova Scotian arrived at Father Point, and the Asia at Cape Race, yesterday, bringing three days' later intelligence from Europe. The London Times lectures the Australians for wanting to separate from England. NARVAEZ has formed a new ministry in Spain. The Weser Zeitung affirms that the supposed new privateer at Bremerhaven has been purchased by the Pussian Government.

abstract: Justice SHANDLEY has admitted SAMUEL M. BARNETT, who stands charged with shooting Dr. ZACHARIE, of No. 750 Broadway, on Thursday last, to bail, in the sum of $1,500. When all the facts of this case are taken into consideration, it would seem that attempts to murder in this City are (pecuniarily) matters of very small importance.
lead_paragraph: -- Justice SHANDLEY has admitted SAMUEL M. BARNETT, who stands charged with shooting Dr. ZACHARIE, of No. 750 Broadway, on Thursday last, to bail, in the sum of $1,500. When all the facts of this case are taken into consideration, it would seem that attempts to murder in this City are (pecuniarily) matters of very small importance. If there be any truth in the statements of impartial witnesses, Dr. ZACHARIE, at the time his life was sought, was seated quietly in his parlor, reading a morning paper, when unannounced the accused suddenly confronted him and demanded the rendition of certain documents which belonged to him, but which had been for sometime in the Doctor's possession. While the Doctor was at his bookcase, and in the act of complying with the demand, the accused, standing scarcely an arm's length from him, exclaimed. "I'll have my revenge," or words to that effect, and deliberately fired twice at the Doctor, the last ball from the pistol taking effect in the face of the assaulted party. The wound was at first thought mortal, but, although the surgeon has not succeeded in finding the ball, the injured man is slowly recovering. The release of the accused on so small bail has occasioned much surprise among those who are cognizant of the facts of the case; for it is argued that if he is guilty of a gross attempt to murder, the bond should have been in a much larger sum; and if, as has been intimated, he is insane, he should not be allowed his liberty either with or without bail.

abstract: A meeting of the Union County Nominating Convention was held last evening, at the hall corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street. At 8 o'clock the meeting was called to order, and Mr. HUGH GARDNER, of the Sixteenth Ward, was elected Chairman. Messrs. JOHN V. GRIDLEY and WM. ALLEN were elected Secretaries. The convention appointed a Conference Committee, consisting of one from each ward, to take into consideration the subject of harmonizing the various antagonisms in the Union organizations. Alter which it adjourned, subject to the call of the chair.

abstract: -- Mr. BRITTAN, of the Mansion House, corner of Bleecker and Crosby streets, several weeks since imported a lot of green turtles, They were killed shortly after their arrival, and nothing more thought of the affair, until yesterday, when about thirty young ones were found crawling about the premises. On examination it was found that several eggs had been laid near a wall heated by a range, and in that manner incubation had taken place. The little ones are quite a curiosity -- being probably the first native-born green turtles ever seen in this city.

abstract: Valley Campaign
snippet: Valley Campaign
lead_paragraph: The week's work of Gen. SHERIDAN, from Monday the 19th, when he set forth on his campaign, down to Monday evening of the current week, covers an advance of about a hundred miles up the Shenandoah Valley, -- the two battles and victories at the Opequan and Fisher's Hill, -- and the putting out of the fight of over ten thousand rebels. Dispatches this morning announce his arrival at Harrisonbugh on Monday last, and his intention to follow up EARLY, who was hastening toward Staunton, which point, it was thought, our army would reach on Tuesday evening. In two of Gen. SHERIDAN's dispatches concerning the victory of Thursday last, he stated that the total rout of EARLY's army depended upon Gen. TORBERT, who, with two divisions of cavalry, had been sent up the Luray Valley to strike the rebel flank or rear. But it seems that TORBERT met the rebel cavalry near Luray Court-house, and he was ,delayed until he could defeat them, which he did on Saturday Last; but the delay gave EARLY an opportunity to get out of reach, and, consequently, our cavalry effected a junction on Sunday with SHERIDAN's infantry force, near Newmarket, in the main valley.

abstract: Grandeur of the Struggle Against Rebellion
snippet: Grandeur of the Struggle Against Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The London Times has well remarked "that since the days of ancient Rome no question so important has been submitted to popular decision," as that which will be submitted to the people of the North at the coming election. It is two thousand years at least since the fall of an empire has been decided at the ballot box; but never before in the whole history of the world, has the entire male population of any country been called upon to fix their national destiny by their suffrages. In Greece and Rome none but a slaveholding minority voted, no matter how momentous the crisis in public affairs. We are about to furnish the first example of the deliberate and orderly submission to the judgment of the whole of a free and equal community, of the most important of all worldly questions, -- the rank to be occupied by a whole people among civilized nations, -the shape and complexion of their Government for ages to come.
headline: {'main': 'The Grandeur of the Struggle.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Grandeur of the Struggle.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Stockton, Cal; $30,000 Loss; Tallahassee; Complete History of her Depredations; Richmond Dispatch
snippet: Stockton, Cal; $30,000 Loss; Tallahassee; Complete History of her Depredations; Richmond Dispatch
lead_paragraph: During the month just passed there have appeared from time to time, many items about the Confederate eruiser Tallahassee, and extracts from the Northern papers regarding the doings of the pirate Tallahassee have been extensively copied. Perhaps the main facts have thus been made public, but only one side of the story has been told, and that, with all the exaggeration and falsehood of particular instances is incomplete. In order to make known the true story, taking into consideration at the same time the limited space allowed in a dally paper, I cannot do better than transcribe the narrative from my diary, written from day to day during the cruise. This I do literally and without alteration, which fact will be sufficient apology for its faults.

abstract: Lake Erie Pirates; Toronto Leader on
snippet: Lake Erie Pirates; Toronto Leader on
lead_paragraph: -- The Toronto Leader, having due regard to the possibility of the Lake Erie pirates being captured in Canada, takes occasion to warn the Provincial Government against the dangers which might arise from their extradition. It instances the case Of WILLIAM LYON MACKENZIE, in 1837, as one in which the surrender of a political fugitive was refused by the United States; but it conceals from its readers the fact that there is nothing approaching to a parallel in the two cases. MACKENZIE was claimed by the British Government on the ground of his having committed a mail robbery before he had taken refuge here. The refusal to surrender him was based on the fact, that at the time of the alleged robbery he was leading an armed band of insurgents, to whom the possession of the Government mail bags was an essential political gain. The act, or the alleged crime, was, therefore, necessarily adjudged to be political in its nature.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone or public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which, are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader: and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Conover, Commodore T. A.
snippet: Conover, Commodore T. A.
lead_paragraph: This gallant officer entered the navy from the State of New-Jersey, in January, 1812, and had consequently been in the service nearly fifty-three years. His first cruise at sea was on board the frigate Essex, commanded by the notable Captain DAVIS PORTER, in the war with England. His next service was under Commodore MCDONOUGH, on Lake Champlain, where he participated in achieving that glorious victory ever the English fleet, on the memorable 11th of September, 1814. Promoted to a lieutenantcy shortly after, he served with his gallant chief on board the Gurrierre in the Mediterranean, and subsequently in other vessels in various portions of the world until his promotion to a Commodore, about 1835, in which capacity he commanded the John Adams, sloop-of-war, some years. In 1848 he was promoted to the rank of Captain, and in the years 1857-8 he commanded the Coast of Africa Squadron, the old Constitution being his flag-ship. In July, 1862, on the creation by law of the grade of Commodores in the navy, he was commissioned as such.

abstract: The Isabella grapes raised at theCroton Point Vineyard by Dr. UNDERHILL are about as superb an article as can be imagined. They are very large, very delicate, and very luscious, with a peculiar, rich, aromatic flavor and odor. The skin is thin, and has a clear, cleanly appearance; and the grapes hang from the vine in huge clusters, like those of Eschol. The culture of the grape is now attracting great attention in this country, and so also is the making of wine; and certainly the liquor expressed from this Westchester County, grape ought to be of the first quality.

abstract: The Boston Advertiser says that on the occasion of the great Union meeting, Wednesday evening, at Boston, old Faneuil Hall was densely crowded with a vast multitude of citizens, who had repaired thither to testify their unswerving devotion to the cause of the Union, the preservation of the Government, and the vigorous prosecution of the war by which the Union and the Government are to be maintained. Long before the hour appointed for the meeting, the multitude, eager to secure available positions, had filled the hall, and overflowed into the square, for which event anticipatory pbeparations had been made in the erection of stands outside for speakers. The meetings, indoors and out, were in the highest degree enthusiastic. Probably no greater number of persons has ever before assembled at a political meeting in Boston.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. LOVEL'S five-act comedy of "Look Before You Leap" was revived here on Wednesday evening with very marked and well-deserved success. Although not free from the usual stiltedness of the school to which it belongs, it is nevertheless a fresh and interesting work. The characters are nicely drawn, the dialogue is well distributed.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- LOVEL's five-act comedy of "Look Before You Leap" was revived here on Wednesday evening with very marked and well-deserved success. Although not free from the usual stiltedness of the school to which it belongs, it is nevertheless a fresh and interesting work. The characters are nicely drawn, the dialogue is well distributed, and the colloquial points are clearly and sharply made. Such a piece can only be well played at one theatre, and that theatre is WALLACK's. The cast last evening was admirable. It had the special merit of introducing all the best ladies of the establishment, and of affording an opportunity for three gentlemen to make their first appearances. Several old members of the company also made their rentree on this occasion; notably, that delightful representative of old ladies, Mrs. VERNON, who, as Miss Brown, was as pleasant and active as ever. Mrs. JENNINGS, as Elenor Mortimer, was admirable. Mrs. FLOYD was received with favor, and her liege lord was a good Charles Rashleigh. These were the old favorites, and they have all good reason to be satisfied with the friendly recognitions bestowed on them. Of the new comers, Mr. NICOL MCINTYRE as the fop, Edward de Vers, made the best impression. His performance was well sustained and strongly marked throughout. Mr. WHITING, of whom we have had occasion to speak in terms of commendation during the early seasons of the Brooklyn Park Theatre, was the Henry Brandon. He is a quiet and gentlemanly young actor, who needs a better opportunity than was afforded to him on this occasion to display his ability. The part is both weak and embarrassing. Mr. WEIGHT, as Hardman, did not impress us favorably. His manner is somewhat too pronounced for the habitues of the theatre, but it is susceptible, we suppose, of modification. Among the regular artists of the company who displayed unusual exce'lence, were Miss MARY GANNON, and Miss HENRIQUES. We do not remember to have ever seen the last-named lady to greater advantage. The part of Clara is a good one. but aside from this it was not difficult to notice in Miss HENRIQUES, performance a very marked improvement on her efforts of last season. Miss GANNON was of course inimitable. Mr. GILBERT was very good as Mr. Coddington, and Mr. CHARLES FISHER deserves the same meed of praise. Indeed the comedy was charmingly rendered and will maintain a prominent place on the bills of the season. Its success warrants this presumption.

abstract: Gen. GRANT began yesterday morning a new movement against Richmond. He telegraphs to Secretary STANTON at 10:45 A.M., Thursday, that Gen. ORD'S corps, the Eighteenth, advanced in the morning and carried the very strong fortifications and long line of intrenchments below Chapin's Farm, some fifteen pieces of artillery, and from two to three hundred prisoners. Gen. ORD was wounded, though not dangerously.
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT began yesterday morning a new movement against Richmond. He telegraphs to Secretary STANTON at 10:45 A.M., Thursday, that Gen. ORD'S corps, the Eighteenth, advanced in the morning and carried the very strong fortifications and long line of intrenchments below Chapin's Farm, some fifteen pieces of artillery, and from two to three hundred prisoners. Gen. ORD was wounded, though not dangerously. Gen. BIRNEY advanced at the same time from Deep Bottom, and carried the Newmarket Road and intrenchments, and scattered the enemy in every direction, though he captured but few. He continued his march toward Richmond. These operations are all on the north side of James River, and are evidently conducted with a view of entering Richmond from that side.

abstract: Old England vs Young America
snippet: Old England vs Young America
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday and Wednesday of this week a match game of cricket was played at Hoboken, between the first eleven of the St. George Cricket Club, of New-York, and the first eleven of the Young America Cricket Club, of Philadelphia. The bowling and fielding on both sides was of the highest order, so good that but few runs could be made off the bat. We particularly noticed the fine bowling of HARRY and GEORGE WRIGHT, on the part of St. George; and of GEORGE NEWHALL and JOHNS, of the Young America. After a well contested game, the Young American were victorious, with four wickets to spare.

abstract: The Cessationist Candidate
snippet: The Cessationist Candidate
lead_paragraph: We are in the constant receipt of communications reviewing the military career of Gen. McCLELLAN. We must decline to publish them, partly because the subject has been exhausted already, but mainly because it has comparatively little to do with the real issue before the country. In the early days of the war, before our people had become accustomed to its character, when ten thousand men seemed an enormous force, and a man with epaulets who could ride a horse on parade was likely to be hailed as a great General, it was natural and excusable to mistake Gen. MCCLELLAN for a new NAPOLEON. But that day of early innocence has passed away. The glitter of regimentals has been tarnished. We have had since then too much experience of the realities of war to be longer deceived by its shams and shows. We have had Generals who could fight the enemy as well as parade their own troops; who could hurl fifty regiments of valiant men, like so many winged thunderbolts, upon the enemy, as well as sit in camp and calculate the chances of defeat or ride to the rear to look out safe resting-places for a beaten army. We have seen Generals who considered it their business to win victories as well as to plan campaigns, -- who deemed it their duty to support their Government instead of denouncing and assailing it, and who did not think that the art of war consisted wholly and exclusively in getting an army twice as large as they knew how to handle, and then whining and howling for more.
headline: {'main': 'The Cessationist Candidate.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Cessationist Candidate.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: American Institute, Annual Horticultural Exhibition
snippet: American Institute, Annual Horticultural Exhibition
lead_paragraph: The annual exhibition of this society, now in progress at Rooms Nos. 21, 22 and 23 Cooper Institute, is certainly one of the finest and most meritorious fruit exhibitions ever placed before the public in this City. A visit to the rooms yesterday afternoon fully convinced us that the few people in attendance, were enjoying a pleasure which will delight thousands of others, if they will simply take our advice and attend during this the closing day and evening. The exhibition of pears exceeds anything that has been seen here for ten years, while that of grapes was never excelled. No person of a refined and beautiful taste will forego this exhibition; nature is most lavish in her productions and adornments this year, and should not be scorned by the indifference of our people. Three large rooms are devoted to this disply, and the number and quality of the various apples, pears and grapes surprises even professional fruit-growers. We have space to notice but a few of the prominent features of the exibition. A bushel of pears, the Duchesse D'Angouleme variety, exhibited by F.L. DUBOIS, of Brooklyn, are the perfection in size and appearance -- nearly as large as pineapples, and attracting much praise.
headline: {'main': 'Horticultural Exhibition of the American Institute.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Horticultural Exhibition of the American Institute.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Last evening a fire broke out in the 5th story of the old American hotel building, corner of Broadway and Barclay street, opposite the Astor House, caused by the explosion of a gas pipe. Damage very small. It was put out by a private watchman by the name of CALLAHAN. The alarm was given by the blowing out of one of the windows on Barclay street.

abstract: on the Victories
snippet: on the Victories
lead_paragraph: Our Municipal Government is just now giving an amusing illustration of the efforts of the McClellanites to blow hot and cold on the war question. The Common Council, the great majority of which, of course, are for the Chicago nominee, felt the necessity, after the late victories, of doing something to clear him of the odious associations of the platform he stands upon. To that end they passed a resolution ordering the illumination of the various public buildings, and requesting householders generally to participate, in like manner, in this expression of joy. It was a a very nice plan, demonstrating, in the face and eyes of everybody, the war spirit of the party, and costing nothing but the expenditure of a little gas -- just the sort of material for the purpose.

abstract: The nineteenth century will be handed down by history as one in which science has made greater progress than any other. Discovery upon discovery has changed almost our entire system of living so much so that could our forefathers return to earth they would fully realize that a generation, inventive and progressive, had sprung up in the place of the one to which they belonged. Among them all, medicine has not been behind-hand.
lead_paragraph: The nineteenth century will be handed down by history as one in which science has made greater progress than any other. Discovery upon discovery has changed almost our entire system of living so much so that could our forefathers return to earth they would fully realize that a generation, inventive and progressive, had sprung up in the place of the one to which they belonged. Among them all, medicine has not been behind-hand. Many operations before considered impossible are now performed with success, and diseases considered incurable now yield readily under the hands of the skillful physician. A disease than which there is none more deleterious and insidious, carrying to premature graves hundreds annually, and which has heretofore baffled the skill of the most eminent physicians, is Catarrh. Few realize the fatal consequences from neglecting it. Consumption, that terror of terrors, is but the effects of it in its advanced stages. As many may have it in its incipient stage, and not be aware of it, we copy, for their benefit, the following paragraph from a treatise on it by Dr. ROWE, of No. 16 West Fourteenth-street, New-York:

abstract: Movement to North of the James
snippet: Movement to North of the James
lead_paragraph: As was expected, General GRANT has very promptly taken advantage of the splendid successes achieved by Gen. SHERIDAN in the Shenandoah Valley. Yesterday morning two of our Army Corps on the James -- the Eighteenth under Gen. ORD, and the Tenth under Gen. BIRNEY -- took up their line of advance for Richmond on the north bank of the river, leaving WARREN firmly planted on the Weldon Road below Petersburgh, and the other corps of the Army of the Potomac located -- we know not where. It is generally known to the country that we have had a small force stationed on the north bank of the James, about ten miles below Richmond, ever since our army reached its present position at Petersburgh; and it will be remembered that about the middle of last month a large body of infantry and cavalry, under HANCOCK and GREGG, was thrown over to Deep Bottom, and forced its way, through heavy fighting, up to within six miles of Richmond -- the real object of the movement, however, being simply to make a diversion while WARREN seized the Weldon Road.

abstract: Both boards of the Common Council met yesterday. The Aldermen passed the Fulton Railroad grant over the Mayor's veto. They also received and laid over a message from Mayor GUNTHER, vetoing the resolutions providing for an illumination of the public buildings, in honor of the recent victories on land and sea, and requesting him to issue a proclamation inviting ...
lead_paragraph: Both boards of the Common Council met yesterday. The Aldermen passed the Fulton Railroad grant over the Mayor's veto. They also received and laid over a message from Mayor GUNTHER, vetoing the resolutions providing for an illumination of the public buildings, in honor of the recent victories on land and sea, and requesting him to issue a proclamation inviting citizens generally to illuminate their dwellings on the same night. The Mayor's objections are chiefly that the proposed illumination would foment partisan feeling, and that it is contrary to the custom of mankind to rejoice over victories gained in civil wars. The veto, which will doubtless be widely and eagerly read, we publish in full elsewhere. The Councilmen transacted but little business, none of which was important. The Aldermen adjourned to Monday, at 1, and the Councilmen till to-day, at 2 P.M.

abstract: Fifty Days' Operations in the Valley
snippet: Fifty Days' Operations in the Valley
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer consoles itself for the defeat of EARLY in the Shenandoah by recalling the fact that STONEWALL JACKSON marched down the Valley and was driven back; that he again advanced and was obliged to retreat; that SIGEL marched up and was defeated, and that HUNTER, after gaining a complete victory over JONES, and after having penetrated to the defences of Lynchburgh, was also compelled to retrace his steps. The Richmond journalist draws from his recital of the facts the conclusion that history is again repeating itself in the case of SHERIDAN, and that it will be his turn to retreat anon. Be this reasoning correct or otherwise, it is worth while to recall the leading events in SHERIDAN's campaign thus far, that we may see by what line of military action he has hitherto been guided. The same day that SHERIDAN entered upon his duties as Commander in the Valley, (Aug. 7,) Gen. AVERILL attacked the rebels at Moorfield, Va., and succeeded in capturing five hundred prisoners. From this date forward, no rebel force, great or small, has been seen north of the Potomac.
